cetiyasantike.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where cetiya (shrine, stupa) serves as the upapada governing the postposition santike (near, in the presence of), indicating spatial proximity to a shrine or stupa.

pabbajjāliṅge.meaning_2: characteristic of novice ordination; feature of renunciation
pabbajjāliṅge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative singular, likely referring to the 'characteristic of pabbajjā' in a Vinaya context, such as signs or attributes of novice ordination.

aṭṭhasamāpattilābhinoyeva.meaning_2: only one who has attained the eight meditative attainments
aṭṭhasamāpattilābhinoyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'aṭṭhasamāpatti' combines 'aṭṭha' (eight) and 'samāpatti' (meditative attainment), and 'lābhī' (possessor) is suffixed before 'eva' (only). In Buddhist contexts, it refers to someone who has exclusively achieved the eight jhāna attainments.

guṇasampattiyā.meaning_2: possession of qualities; endowment with virtues; excellence through characteristics
guṇasampattiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form indicating 'by means of' or 'through' the endowment of qualities, commonly used in contexts praising moral or virtuous attributes.

guṇasampannenāpi.meaning_2: endowed with qualities; possessing virtues; accomplished in characteristics
guṇasampannenāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used to indicate 'even by one endowed with qualities,' emphasizing possession of virtues despite some implied contrast or concession in context.

adhikārasampannasseva.meaning_2: endowed with authority; possessing jurisdiction; qualified
adhikārasampannasseva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'adhikāra' (authority, jurisdiction) is qualified by 'sampanna' (endowed with). The form 'adhikārasampannasseva' is genitive singular with enclitic 'eva' for emphasis, likely modifying a subsequent noun in the sentence, indicating 'of one endowed with authority only'.

adhikārasampannassāpi.meaning_2: endowed with authority; possessing the right or qualification
adhikārasampannassāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sampannassa' (genitive singular of sampanna, 'endowed with') modifies 'adhikāra' (authority or governing rule). The entire form is genitive singular, likely translating to 'of one endowed with authority' in a grammatical or doctrinal context, emphasizing qualification or competence.

chandamahantatāya.meaning_2: on account of great desire; because of intense wish; by the greatness of intention
chandamahantatāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound abstract noun 'chandamahantatā', indicating cause or means, likely used in a context expressing motivation or volition due to strong interest or desire.

sakalacakkavāḷagabbhaṃ.meaning_2: the interior of the entire world system
sakalacakkavāḷagabbhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound extending 'cakkavāḷagabbha' (interior of a world-circle) with 'sakala' (entire), likely referring to the innermost realm encompassing all world-systems in a cosmological context.

bāhubalena.meaning_2: strength of the arm; physical power
bāhubalena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound bāhubala, indicating 'by the strength of the arm'. The word combines 'bāhu' (arm) with 'bala' (strength), often denoting physical might or prowess in Pāli texts.

veḷugumbasañchannaṃ.meaning_2: covered with bamboo thicket; shaded by bamboo grove
veḷugumbasañchannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where veḷugumba (bamboo thicket) is the object of the past participle sañchanna (covered with). The form is accusative singular masculine, likely modifying a masculine noun such as vana (forest) in the original context, describing a forest covered or shaded by a bamboo thicket.

byūhitvā.meaning_2: having arranged; having disposed; having arrayed
byūhitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form byūhitvā is the absolutive of the verb byūhati, used to indicate an action completed prior to the main verb in the sentence. It often appears in contexts describing preparatory actions, such as arranging troops or objects in a narrative.

sattiphalasamākiṇṇaṃ.meaning_2: strewn with spears and fruits; filled with weapons and fruits
sattiphalasamākiṇṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something (likely a place or surface) densely covered or scattered with spears (satti, weapons) and fruits (phala), evoking a scene of battle mingled with natural elements; the exact context from the sentence would clarify the imagery, but no sentence is provided.

akkamamāno.meaning_1: not stepping (on); not treading (on); not subjugating
akkamamāno.meaning_2: not stepping (on); not treading (on); not subjugating
akkamamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form akkamāmāno is the masculine nominative singular of the present participle with the negative prefix na-, indicating one who is not pressing on, not stepping onto, or not subjugating. The sandhi combination na + akkamāmāno > akkamāmāno is a common phonological adjustment in Pāli.

vītaccitaṅgārabharitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something filled or laden with flameless, glowing coals, likely in a metaphorical sense of subdued or smoldering anger or passion, given the context of 'vītaccita' implying without visible flames.

sumedhatāpasassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'the ascetic who is wise' or 'wise ascetic'; used to denote possession or relation to a specific sage or hermit in the text.

sīsabhāge.meaning_2: part of the head; portion of the head
sīsabhāge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sīsa' (head) is qualified by 'bhāga' (part), indicating a specific portion or section of the head. In Pāḷi texts, such compounds often refer to anatomical or metaphorical divisions.

maṇisīhapañjaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound: 'maṇi' (jewel) modifies 'sīhapañjara' (lion's cage), possibly referring to a decorative or jeweled lion-cage motif, or a specific architectural or symbolic element in context. Without the sentence, the exact usage is inferred from components.

ugghāṭento.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ugghāṭento appears to be a present participle nominative masculine singular of the verb ugghāṭeti, likely used in a descriptive context to indicate one who is opening or revealing something.

pañcavaṇṇappasādasampannāni.meaning_2: endowed with five-colored beauty products; possessing facial adornments of five colors
pañcavaṇṇappasādasampannāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound describing objects (likely cosmetic items or adornments) that are fully equipped with beauty products of five colors, in the neuter nominative/accusative plural form to agree with an implied noun such as 'vatthāni' (garments) or similar in a descriptive context.

sumedhatāpasaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'sumedha-tāpasaṃ', where sumedha (wise man, sage) modifies tāpasa (ascetic). The ending -ṃ indicates accusative case, likely used as the object in the sentence.

upadhārento.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upadhārento is the nominative singular masculine present participle of upadhāreti, indicating ongoing action of exploring or concluding, adapted to Pāḷi from the provided Sanskrit-like entry.

kappasatasahassādhikāni.meaning_2: more than one hundred thousand aeons
kappasatasahassādhikāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter plural nominative/accusative form of a compound adjective, likely modifying a neuter noun such as 'kappāni' (aeons) in context, indicating a vast duration exceeding 100,000 aeons.

uggatapaṃ.meaning_2: mighty heat; powerful austerity; formidable spiritual practice
uggatapaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form uggatapaṃ is the accusative singular of a compound adjective uggatapa, where ugga (mighty, powerful) qualifies tapa (heat or ascetic practice from √tap). In context, it likely refers to intense or formidable ascetic heat or spiritual exertion.

dutiyasāvako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound dutiyasāvako combines 'dutiya' (second) with 'sāvako' (disciple), typically indicating a secondary or companion disciple in Pāḷi texts, often in contexts of paired followers or sequential teaching.

aggasāvikā.meaning_2: chief female disciple; foremost female disciple
aggasāvikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'agga' (foremost, chief) with 'sāvikā' (female disciple) to denote a leading or principal female disciple in the Buddhist context.

dutiyasāvikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun where 'dutiyā' (second, feminine) modifies 'sāvikā' (female disciple), likely referring to a second or accompanying female disciple in a monastic or teaching context.

mahābhinikkhamanaṃ.meaning_2: great departure; the Great Going Forth; renunciation of worldly life
mahābhinikkhamanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'mahā' qualifies 'abhinikkhamanaṃ', referring to the Buddha's significant act of leaving home to pursue enlightenment, often called the Great Renunciation in Buddhist texts.

mahāpadhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where mahā (great) modifies padhāna (effort), referring to intense or supreme exertion, often in the context of spiritual practice or meditation in Pāli texts.

assattharukkhamūle.meaning_2: at the foot of the Bodhi tree
assattharukkhamūle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound assattharukkhamūla, meaning 'the foot/base of the Bodhi tree' (Ficus religiosa). The lemma assattha refers specifically to the sacred Bodhi tree under which the Buddha attained enlightenment, combining the literal senses of 'relief' or 'where horses stand'.

ṭhatvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ṭhatvāna appears to be an extended or variant form of the absolutive ṭhatvā, possibly with -na as an emphatic or connective element; in context, it denotes the action of having stood or placed prior to the main verb.

uggatāpanaṃ.meaning_2: causing burning; scorching; distressing; causing pain
uggatāpanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun combining 'ugga' (rise; ascent) and 'tāpana' (causing burning), likely referring to a painful or distressing rise, such as in the context of ascetic practices or tormenting elevation in a textual sentence.

kapilavhayā.meaning_2: named Kapila; called the one of Kapila
kapilavhayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form kapilavhayā is the instrumental singular of the compound kapilāvahaya, where avhaya is a present participle used adjectivally meaning 'called' or 'named', combined with kapila referring to the sage. This likely denotes 'by one named Kapila' or 'by the one called Kapila', possibly in reference to the sage Kapila in a contextual narrative.

padahitvāna.meaning_2: having stepped; having trodden; having placed the foot
padahitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound absolutive formed from the past participle pada + hitvāna, indicating an action of stepping or placing the foot before another action in the sentence.

ajapālarukkhamūle.meaning_2: at the foot of the tree of the goatherd; at the base of the goatherd's tree
ajapālarukkhamūle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative singular form, indicating location 'at the base of the goatherd's tree'. The primary member rukkhamūla is modified by ajapāla, which is itself a compound (aja + pāla).

nerañjaramupehiti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi compound where nerañjarā (name of a river) combines with upehiti (future of upeti, 'will approach'). The final -ā of the river name elides before the initial u- of upehiti, resulting in nerañjaramupehiti. This construction indicates approaching or arriving at the Nerañjarā river, as in the Buddha's context of reaching the riverbank.

paṭiyattavaramaggena.meaning_2: by the excellent path prepared for the supreme
paṭiyattavaramaggena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound paṭiyatta-vara-agga-magga, where paṭiyatta is the past participle used adjectivally modifying magga. The overall sense suggests a path or way that is prepared or arranged in an excellent and supreme manner, likely in a doctrinal or metaphorical context such as the Buddhist path.

bodhimūlamūpehiti.meaning_2: foot of the Bodhi tree; base of the Bo tree
bodhimūlamūpehiti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the first component of the sandhi compound bodhimūlūpehiti, which appears to be a nominal form with a future verbal element attached, likely meaning 'approaching the foot of the Bodhi tree' or similar in a contextual sentence involving arrival or approach to the sacred site.

assattharukkhamūlamhi.meaning_2: at the foot of the Bodhi tree
assattharukkhamūlamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This locative form indicates location 'at the base of the Bodhi tree', where assattha refers to the sacred Ficus religiosa under which the Buddha attained enlightenment. The compound is common in Buddhist texts describing key sites.

nāmupaṭṭhāko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'nāma' (name) modifies 'upaṭṭhāka' (attendant), likely indicating an attendant identified by name or a specific named attendant. The form suggests nominative singular, used as a subject or appositive in the text.

somanassappatto.meaning_2: reached (mental) pleasure; attained happiness; glad; joyful
somanassappatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound adjective indicating one who has attained a state of gladness or joy, combining abstract noun of happiness with past participle 'reached'; used contextually to describe a positive mental condition.

buddhabījaṃ.meaning_2: Buddha-seed; seed of the Buddha; Buddha-nature
buddhabījaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bīja' (seed) is qualified by 'buddha' (Buddha). In Buddhist contexts, it often refers to the latent potential for awakening or Buddha-nature.

evañcassa.meaning_2: thus and; and so; in this manner and
evañcassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form evañcassa appears to be a scribal error or sandhi variant for evañca + assa, where evañca means 'thus and' or 'and so', likely introducing a clause involving 'assa' (e.g., optative 'may be' or pronoun 'to him'). Without the full sentence context, the exact usage is inferred from common Pāli constructions.

heṭṭhātitthena.meaning_2: by the unsuitable ford; by the unsuitable crossing place
heṭṭhātitthena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form heṭṭhātitthena is the instrumental singular of the compound heṭṭhātittha, combining 'heṭṭhā' (below, under) with 'atittha' (unsuitable ford). This suggests a location or means involving an improper or inaccessible crossing below, possibly metaphorical for an unsuitable path or method in context.

dīpaṅkaradasabalopi.meaning_2: even Dīpaṅkara, endowed with ten powers; even the illuminator with ten supernormal powers
dīpaṅkaradasabalopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound combining the name of the Buddha Dīpaṅkara, the epithet dasabala 'endowed with ten powers', and the indeclinable api 'even' or 'also', likely functioning as an adverbial phrase in a list or emphatic reference to the Buddha. The form suggests vocative or nominative context, common in invocations or descriptions.

catusatasahassasaṅkhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where saṅkhā functions as a numeral suffix equivalent to 'myriads' or 'countless multitudes'; catu-sata-sahassa denotes 4 × 100 × 1,000 = 400,000, so the whole term means 400,000 (in the sense of 4 × 100,000). Commonly used in cosmological contexts to denote vast numbers of worlds or beings.

paṭikkantakāle.grammar: ind, adv, loc sg of paṭikkantakāla
paṭikkantakāle.meaning_2: at the time of returning; at the moment of coming back
paṭikkantakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative case functioning adverbially, indicating 'at the time of having returned' or 'upon returning'. Derived from the past participle paṭikkanta (returned) and kāla (time), commonly used in Pāḷi to denote specific temporal occasions.

puppharāsimatthake.meaning_2: on the top of a heap of flowers; at the summit of a pile of blossoms
puppharāsimatthake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of the compound noun puppharāsimatthaka, indicating location 'on/at the top of a heap of flowers'. The compound combines puppharāsi (heap of flowers) with matthaka (top, summit), likely describing a specific place or position in context.

sakaladasasahassacakkavāḷadevatā.meaning_2: deity of all ten thousand world-systems
sakaladasasahassacakkavāḷadevatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where sakala modifies dasasahassacakkavāḷa, indicating the deity associated with every one of the ten thousand world-systems in Buddhist cosmology.

sumedhatāpasa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from 'sumedha' (wise man, sage) and 'tāpasa' (ascetic, hermit), likely referring to a wise ascetic figure, possibly alluding to Sumedha, the ascetic who became Buddha Gotama, in a Buddhist context.

porāṇakabodhisattānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in genitive plural, referring to ancient or previous bodhisattas, likely in the context of past enlightened beings or aspirants to Buddhahood.

yassetāni.grammar: pron, nt nom pl of eta
yassetāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form yassetāni appears to be a scribal error or variant for etāni, possibly influenced by preceding ya or yassa in sandhi context. Without sentences provided, it is interpreted as the standard demonstrative pronoun 'these' in neuter nominative or accusative plural.

ukkuṭṭhisaddā.meaning_2: sound of exclamation; outcry; noise of outcry
ukkuṭṭhisaddā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun combining 'ukkuṭṭhi' (exclamation, outcry) with 'sadda' (sound, noise), likely in instrumental plural form 'ukkuṭṭhisaddā' meaning 'with sounds of outcry' or similar, based on the -ā ending typical for masculine or feminine instrumentals.

yadimassa.grammar: pron, masc gen sg of yad + ima
yadimassa.meaning_2: of whichever this; of whatever this
yadimassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form yadimassa appears to be a fused pronoun construction combining the indefinite 'yad' (from 'ya') and 'imassa' (genitive of 'ima'), likely resulting from sandhi or textual variant, expressing possession related to an indefinite 'this'.

paṭibhitthaṃ.meaning_2: comes to mind; occurs (to); inspires (someone to)
paṭibhitthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word paṭibhitthaṃ appears to be a scribal error or variant for paṭibhāti in its adverbial accusative form itthaṃ, but based on the provided entries, it is analyzed as the present verb paṭibhāti with the adverbial element itthaṃ implied in context. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

virajjhiya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Absolutive form indicating action of avoiding or shunning, often used in contexts of moral or disciplinary avoidance in Vinaya texts.

heṭṭhātitthe.meaning_2: unsuitable ford below; unsuitable crossing place underneath
heṭṭhātitthe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form heṭṭhātitthe is the locative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound heṭṭhātittha, combining the preposition heṭṭhā ('below') with atittha ('unsuitable ford'), indicating a crossing place that is unsuitable and located underneath or below.

muñcāmimaṃ.meaning_2: releases; lets go; frees; gets angry (with); emits; lets loose
muñcāmimaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form muñcāmimaṃ appears to be a scribal error or sandhi variant for muñca imaṃ ('release this'), a common imperative construction in Pāḷi texts. Without the sentence context, the precise usage (e.g., literal release or metaphorical emission) cannot be determined, but it likely functions as an imperative exhortation to let go of something specified as 'this'.

pādamuddhari.meaning_2: having raised the foot; having lifted the foot
pādamuddhari.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form of 'pādaṃ uddhari' functioning as an aorist, likely used in a narrative or descriptive context to indicate an action of lifting or raising the foot, common in descriptions of movement or gestures in Pāḷi texts.

tatthāsuṃ.meaning_2: they were there; there were in that place
tatthāsuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form combines the adverb 'tattha' (there) with the aorist 'āsuṃ' (they were), functioning adverbially to indicate location in the past; the lack of explicit sentences limits precise contextual nuance, but it likely denotes existence or presence in a specific place.

padakkhiṇamakaṃsu.meaning_2: they performed circumambulation to the right; they reverentially circumambulated
padakkhiṇamakaṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form combines the adverbial 'padakkhiṇam' (accusative of padakkhiṇā, 'to the right') with the aorist 'akaṃsu' ('they did'), indicating the action of performing a rightward circumambulation, a respectful ritual gesture.

abhivādetvāna.meaning_2: to greet; to salute; to pay respect
abhivādetvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form abhivādetvāna is an absolutive (gerund) derived from the verb abhivādeti, indicating the action of having greeted or paid respects, typically used in narrative sequences to denote a completed action prior to the main verb.

sahassiyamhi.meaning_2: in which there are a thousand; in the one containing a thousand
sahassiyamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a relative pronoun formed from the adjective sahassiya ('containing a thousand'), used in locative case to indicate location or relation in something consisting of a thousand parts or items.

iddhidhammesu.meaning_2: in psychic powers as qualities; in supernormal abilities as phenomena
iddhidhammesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative plural form of the tatpuruṣa compound iddhidhammo, where iddhi (psychic power) qualifies dhamma (here likely meaning 'qualities' or 'phenomena'). In Buddhist contexts, it often refers to supernormal powers as mental or doctrinal phenomena.

pallaṅkābhujane.meaning_2: crouching in cross-legged position; soiling on the couch
pallaṅkābhujane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a locative singular form of a compound noun derived from 'pallaṅka' (cross-legged posture or couch) and 'ābhujana' (crouching or soiling). In Pāḷi Vinaya contexts, it likely refers to a case involving soiling while sitting cross-legged, possibly in meditation or on a seat.

dasasahassādhivāsino.meaning_2: residents of ten thousand (worlds); those dwelling in ten thousand worlds
dasasahassādhivāsino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is nominative plural of a tatpuruṣa compound, with adhi indicating 'over' or 'in' the dasasahassa (ten thousand worlds), and vāsī meaning 'residents'. In Buddhist context, dasasahassa often refers to a cakkavāḷa of ten thousand worlds.

mahānādaṃ.meaning_2: great sound; loud roar; mighty bellow
mahānādaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'mahānāda', where 'mahā' means great and 'nāda' means sound or roar. In context, it likely refers to a loud or significant sound, such as a lion's roar or thunder, common in Pāḷi literature for emphasis.

pallaṅkavaramābhuje.meaning_2: bending or coiling excellently in the cross-legged posture; contracting in a princely meditation pose
pallaṅkavaramābhuje.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a present participle in locative singular masculine/neuter, modifying a subject in a meditative or seated context; 'pallaṅkavara' functions as a descriptive compound qualifying the manner of bending or coiling.

byapagataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Past participle of byāpajjati, indicating something that has approached or arrived, often used in contexts of reaching a state or place.

dakajā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] dakajā is the instrumental singular form of dakā, used to indicate agency or relation in the context of the sentence. The exact usage depends on the surrounding text, but it typically denotes 'by a maid' or 'related to a maid'.

tepajja.meaning_2: crime of heat; offence involving fire
tepajja.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a compound in Vinaya context referring to a specific case of misconduct related to heat or fire; no direct dictionary entry provided, based on standard Pāḷi morphology.

phalabhārā.meaning_2: burden of fruit; load of results; weight of consequences
phalabhārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'phala' (fruit, consequence) is the burden or load ('bhārā', instrumental singular of 'bhāra'). Likely used in a context describing a heavy load of fruits or metaphorical weight of outcomes.

tepajjubho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a descriptive compound referring to something with evident or clear heat, possibly in a metaphorical sense in Vinaya context; no sentences provided for exact usage.

vicittapupphā.meaning_2: variegated flowers; decorated flowers; multi-coloured flowers
vicittapupphā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in the feminine locative singular form, likely indicating 'in variegated flowers' or 'among decorated flowers', based on the ending -ā typical for nt stems in loc.sg. The primary sense aligns with floral decoration rather than the secondary meaning of menstrual flux.

anovaṭṭhena.meaning_1: in a manner not rained on; without being soaked by rain
anovaṭṭhena.meaning_2: in a manner not rained on; without being soaked by rain
anovaṭṭhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an ablative of the compound 'anovaṭṭha', meaning 'not rained on', used adverbially to indicate manner. The base 'ovaṭṭha' is the past participle of ovassati (to rain down), negated by 'na'. No contextual sentences provided, but in Pāḷi texts, such terms often describe states of dryness or protection from rain, e.g., in similes for purity or detachment.

tampajjubbhijjate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a present tense verb form, likely 3rd singular middle or passive, meaning 'it is split' or 'it is broken'. The prefix 'tam-' may refer to 'that', 'pañca' suggests 'five', and 'ju' could relate to a base like 'yuj' or 'ju', combined with the root 'bhijj' (to break). Without context sentences, the exact usage is inferred from morphology.

gaganamaṇḍale.meaning_2: circle of the sky; celestial sphere
gaganamaṇḍale.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'gagana' (sky) qualifies 'maṇḍala' (circle), likely referring to the spherical or circular expanse of the sky in a cosmological or astronomical context.

candimāyuttā.meaning_2: connected with the moon; endowed with brightness
candimāyuttā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form candimāyuttā appears to be a feminine nominative singular adjective, likely a compound of candimā ('lunar' or 'of the moon') and yuttā ('endowed with' or 'connected to'). This suggests a meaning like 'endowed with moonlight' or 'linked to the moon deity,' fitting contexts involving lunar brightness or association.

darīsayā.meaning_2: lying in a cleft; residing in a cavern
darīsayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound darīsaya combines 'darī' (cleft or cavern) with 'saya' (lying or residing), indicating something situated or resting within a cleavage or cavern, likely in a descriptive or locative context.

sakāsayā.meaning_2: with one's own disposition; with one's own inclination
sakāsayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sakāsayā is instrumental singular feminine of the tatpuruṣa compound sakāsaya, meaning 'one's own disposition'. The base āsaya is analyzed as ā + √sī > say + *a, but in compounding it follows a pattern allowing feminine inflection in -ā, likely by analogy with similar compounds.

tadūpasammanti.meaning_2: they are calmed; they are cooled; they are settled
tadūpasammanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi combination of 'tadā' (then) and 'upasammanti' (they are calmed), functioning adverbially to indicate timing of the calming action in the sentence.

tānipajja.meaning_2: those things on the path; those matters concerning the way
tānipajja.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound combining the neuter nominative/accusative plural pronoun 'tāni' (those things) with the neuter noun 'pajja' (path, way). The form 'tānipajja' suggests assimilation or poetic contraction, possibly in a context referring to 'those things on the path' or doctrinal matters related to the path.

ajjapetaṃ.meaning_2: muttered thing; that which was recited
ajjapetaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word ajjapetaṃ appears to be a sandhi form where 'a-' (likely from 'etaṃ' 'this') combines with 'japetaṃ' (past participle of japati 'to mutter, recite'). It functions as a neuter noun referring to 'that which was muttered' or 'the recited thing', possibly in a context of ritual or prayer recitation.

nuddhaṃsati.meaning_2: remembers up; recalls; brings to mind
nuddhaṃsati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nuddhaṃsati is a present tense verb with prefix nu- (intensifying or interrogative particle, here fused as nu-) and ud- (up), derived from √dhaṃs 'to fall, perish'. In Buddhist contexts, it idiomatically means 'remembers' or 'recollects', as in recalling teachings or events, often with a sense of elevation or recovery from forgetfulness.

aniṭṭhagandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun formed from the past participle 'aniṭṭha' (unpleasant, lit. not wished for, from na + √is + ta) and 'gandha' (smell, from √ghā + a). The word describes a scent that is disliked or disagreeable, likely in a sensory or metaphorical context in Pāḷi texts.

diṭṭhagandho.meaning_2: visible smell; perceptible odour; scent that is seen
diṭṭhagandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining the past participle 'diṭṭha' (seen, visible) with 'gandha' (smell, odour), likely referring to a smell that is perceptible or evident to the senses, possibly in a metaphorical sense in Pāli texts.

sopajja.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Adverbial form indicating sequence in time, often used in narrative contexts to denote what follows an event.

hontāvaraṇā.meaning_2: obstacles to becoming; impediments to existence
hontāvaraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound hontāvaraṇā combines the present participle honta ('becoming' or 'existing') with āvaraṇā ('obstruction'), forming a neuter noun in the instrumental singular, indicating 'by obstacles to becoming.' This likely refers to hindrances preventing spiritual progress or existence in a desired state, common in Buddhist contexts.

ākāsabhūtā.meaning_2: having become space; existing as space; space-like
ākāsabhūtā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ākāsa 'space' qualifies bhūta 'become/existing', likely referring to an elemental or metaphysical state of space in a cosmological or doctrinal context, such as in Buddhist descriptions of elements (dhātu).

dasasahassacakkavāḷadevatānañca.meaning_2: and of the deities of ten thousand world-systems
dasasahassacakkavāḷadevatānañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as a genitive plural phrase connected by 'ca', referring to deities associated with ten thousand world-systems, likely in a cosmological or enumerative context typical of Pāli texts.

sañjātussāho.meaning_2: born of energy; arisen from effort; possessed of perseverance
sañjātussāho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sañjāta' (produced, arisen) modifies 'ussāha' (effort, energy), indicating energy that has arisen or is produced; likely in nominative singular based on typical usage in Pāli texts, though case not specified in query.

amoghavacanā.meaning_2: fruitful word; efficacious utterance; statement not in vain
amoghavacanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form amoghavacanā appears to be an instrumental singular of the compound amoghavacana, used to indicate 'by a fruitful word' or similar in context.

khittaleḍḍussa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a compound where khitta (past participle of khipati, 'thrown') modifies leḍḍu ('clod' or 'stone'), likely referring to a stone or clod that has been thrown, possibly in a context of disturbance or an act of throwing.

sūriyassuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: place of the sun; position of the sun; solar station
sūriyassuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive compound indicating possession or relation, with 'sūriyassa' (gen. sg. of sūriya 'sun') combined with 'uṭṭhānaṃ' (acc. sg. of uṭṭhāna 'rising; origin'), likely referring to the rising place or position of the sun in an astronomical or metaphorical context.

nikkhantasīhassa.meaning_2: departed lion; lion that has gone out
nikkhantasīhassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nikkhantasīhassa is genitive singular of the tatpuruṣa compound nikkhantasīha, likely referring to a lion that has departed or escaped, combining the past participle nikkhanta (from nikkhamati, 'to go out') with sīha ('lion'). In context, it may describe a specific lion in a narrative, such as one that has left or passed away.

sīhanādanadanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sīhanāda' (lion's roar) is qualified by 'nadana' (roaring), likely functioning as a descriptive genitive in neuter accusative singular form. The absence of sentences limits contextual nuance, but it evokes a sense of bold, resonant proclamation.

bhāramoropanaṃ.meaning_2: imposition of a burden; laying on of a load
bhāramoropanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where bhāra (burden) is the object of oropana (causing to descend, laying down). In a Vinaya context, it likely refers to the act of imposing a disciplinary burden or penalty on a monk.

avassaṃbhāvī.meaning_2: inevitably going to be; certainly fated; without doubt predestined
avassaṃbhāvī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'avassaṃ' (acc. sg. of avassa, 'inevitably') with 'bhāvī' ('going to be'), conveying something fated to happen without fail. The accusative form integrates into the compound as the object of bhāvī.

dasasahassīna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of a compound adjective dasasahassīna 'tenthousandth', derived from dasa + sahas + sīna (past participle of sīdati 'to sit down, settle'), likely meaning 'settled by ten thousand' or 'of the tenthousandth' in context, though no sentences provided to confirm usage.

bhavāmahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word 'bhavāmahaṃ' appears to be a sandhi combination of 'bhavāma ahaṃ' ('we are I'), likely a scribal error or emphatic construction in a text, but analyzed as the verb form 'bhavāma' with the pronoun 'ahaṃ' fused; the primary lemma focuses on the verbal element as per instructions.

dhuvasassataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound adjective in accusative singular neuter, likely used to describe something enduring and eternal, such as a state or quality in philosophical context. The form -aṃ indicates neuter accusative, agreeing with a neuter noun.

nikkhantasayanassa.meaning_2: of the bed that has been left; of the abandoned sleeping place
nikkhantasayanassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound nikkhantasayana, where nikkhanta (past participle 'departed, left') modifies sayana ('bed, sleeping place'). The construction implies a place of rest that has been vacated or abandoned, likely referring to a monk's empty sleeping spot in a monastic context.

dhuvasassatanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound where 'dhuvasassata' describes something as both stable (dhuva) and eternal (sassata), followed by the quotative particle 'iti' meaning 'thus'. Likely used in doctrinal contexts to affirm permanence, such as an epithet for Nibbāna.

dhuvāhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dhuvāhaṃ appears to be a sandhi variant or compound of dhuva (permanent, eternal) and ahaṃ (day), likely in accusative singular. It may denote 'eternal day' or a metaphorical expression for permanence, possibly an epithet related to Nibbāna as everlasting. Without context sentences, the exact usage is inferred from dictionary entries.

katasanniṭṭhāno.meaning_2: place of what is done; site of accomplishment
katasanniṭṭhāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'place of the done' or 'site of accomplishment'; sanniṭṭhāna is a rare form related to niṭṭhāna (ending, attainment) with san- prefix suggesting 'complete' or 'thorough'.

buddhakārake.meaning_2: maker of the Buddha; one who creates or causes the Awakened One
buddhakārake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound buddhakāraka combines 'buddha' (Awakened One) as the object with 'kāraka' (agent/doer), forming a bahuvrīhi or tatpuruṣa indicating the agent responsible for producing or causing the Buddha. In Buddhist contexts, this might refer metaphorically to factors or conditions leading to enlightenment.

upadhāretuṃ.meaning_2: to hold near; to support; to sustain
upadhāretuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upadhāretuṃ is an infinitive derived from the causative stem of upa √dhā, indicating purpose or result, often used in contexts of maintaining or upholding something close by, such as precepts or objects.

porāṇakabodhisattehi.meaning_2: with ancient bodhisattas; with former awakening beings
porāṇakabodhisattehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound adjective-noun, indicating association with ancient or former bodhisattas in a narrative or doctrinal context.

āsevitanisevitaṃ.meaning_1: unfrequented and unfrequented; unpractised and unpractised
āsevitanisevitaṃ.meaning_2: unfrequented places; unpractised paths; lit. not associated with and not resorted to
āsevitanisevitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adjective agreeing with an understood neuter plural noun such as 'ṭhānāni' or 'magge'. The double negative construction with 'a-' on both parts emphasises complete avoidance or desolation in context, likely describing remote or neglected locations not resorted to by people.

sumedhapaṇḍita.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Bahuvrīhi-like compound denoting a person who is both sumedha (wise) and paṇḍita (learned), likely a title for a scholar or monk.

sampattayācakānaṃ.meaning_2: of beggars who have arrived; of mendicants who are here
sampattayācakānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sampatta (reached, arrived) modifies yācaka (beggar), likely in genitive plural form in the text, referring to beggars who have reached or arrived at a place.

buddhakare.meaning_2: Buddha-maker; one who makes the Buddha; one who causes awakening
buddhakare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound buddhakara likely functions as a bahuvrīhi or karmadhāraya, interpreting as 'that which does buddha' or 'Buddha-doing', in the sense of causing or effecting awakening, possibly in a doctrinal context referring to factors or conditions leading to Buddhahood.

tadādakkhiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tadādakkhiṃ is a sandhied combination of the adverb tadā ('then') and the 1st person singular aorist of dakkhati ('I saw'), resulting in 'then I saw'. The sandhi change from tadā + adakkhiṃ to tadādakkhiṃ involves the assimilation of 'a + a' to 'ā' followed by 'dakkhiṃ'.

dānapāramitaṃ.meaning_2: highest state of generosity; perfection of giving
dānapāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dānapāramitaṃ is the accusative singular of the feminine compound noun dānapāramitā, indicating the object of giving or offering in context.

pattumicchasi.meaning_2: wish to attain; desire to reach
pattumicchasi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pattumicchasi is a fused present indicative 2nd singular of an irregular verb pattumicchati 'wishes to attain', combining the infinitive pattuṃ (to attain) with icchasi (you wish). The related entries show icchati derived irregularly from √is, and pattuṃ from pa + √ap. This construction expresses a desire to reach or achieve something, common in Pāli for expressing intentions.

vamatevudakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vamatevudakaṃ appears to be a sandhi-affected or corrupted rendering of 'vamati eva udakaṃ', where 'vamati' describes the action of water spilling or pouring out, as in a metaphorical 'vomiting' of liquid. The lemma is based on the verbal root √vam in its present tense, with 'eva' as an emphatic particle and 'udakaṃ' as the direct object (accusative neuter singular). No contextual sentences provided, so meaning inferred from dictionary entries.

hīnamukkaṭṭhamajjhime.meaning_2: low, high, or middle; inferior, elevated, or middling
hīnamukkaṭṭhamajjhime.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears in locative singular, likely modifying a masculine or neuter noun referring to a quality or state that can be low, high, or middle in degree or status. The compound lists three possibilities in a distributive sense, common in Pāli for enumerating categories.

upadhārayato.meaning_2: holds in memory; keeps in mind
upadhārayato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upadhārayato appears to be a scribal error or variant for upadhārayati, the 3rd sg. present indicative of upadhārayati, commonly used in Pāli texts for 'to hold in mind' or 'to remember'. No sentences provided for further context.

camarīmigo.meaning_2: yak and deer; both yak and deer
camarīmigo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a dvanda compound connecting 'camarī' (yak) and 'miga' (deer), likely used in a context enumerating animals or beasts, with 'ca' (and) implied in the compounding process.

bodhipācanā.meaning_2: goad of awakening; prod for enlightenment
bodhipācanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'bodhi' (awakening) with 'pācana' (goad), likely metaphorical in a Buddhist context for a stimulus or tool leading to enlightenment. No specific sentence context provided, so meaning is inferred from components.

sīlapāramitaṃ.meaning_1: perfection of ethical conduct; perfection of virtue
sīlapāramitaṃ.meaning_2: perfection of morality; ultimate state of moral integrity
sīlapāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter accusative singular form of the compound sīlapāramitā, one of the ten perfections (pāramī or pāramitā) in Buddhist doctrine, referring to the consummate development of ethical conduct (sīla). The form pāramitā is common in later Pāḷi texts influenced by Sanskrit, contrasting with the earlier pāramī.

paṭilaggitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Past passive participle in accusative singular neuter, indicating something that has been attached or clung to, often used in contexts of mental or physical adhesion.

avasitukāmo.grammar: adj, in comps, from avasituṃ kāmeti
avasitukāmo.meaning_2: desiring to stay; wishing to remain
avasitukāmo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form avasitukāmo is a compound adjective where avasituṃ (infinitive 'to stay') functions as the object of desire, combined with kāma ('desiring'). It describes someone who wishes to remain or settle in a place, often in contexts of reluctance to leave.

bandhanāgārasadise.meaning_2: like a prison; resembling a jail
bandhanāgārasadise.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where the locative form sadise ('like') follows bandhanāgāra ('prison'), resulting in the fused form bandhanāgārasadise, likely due to vowel sandhi (ā + a > ā).

nekkhammābhimukhova.meaning_2: as if facing renunciation; directed towards renunciation like
nekkhammābhimukhova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi compound combining 'nekkhamma' (neuter noun, renunciation), 'abhimukha' (adjective, facing towards), and 'iva' (indeclinable, like/as). The long 'ā' in nekkhammā results from sandhi with the following vowel-initial word. 'Eva' is not present; the ending 'ova' reflects sandhi of 'abhimukh' + 'a' (from iva). Used adverbially to describe a state or attitude resembling being oriented towards renunciation.

nekkhammapāramitaṃ.meaning_2: perfection of renunciation; ultimate state of renunciation
nekkhammapāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nekkhammapāramitaṃ is the neuter accusative singular, likely used as an object in the sentence, referring to the concept of renunciation as a perfected virtue in Buddhist doctrine.

ciravuttho.meaning_2: having dwelt for a long time
ciravuttho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a descriptive compound where 'cira' modifies the past participle 'vuttho' from vi√vas, indicating duration of stay. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is general.

dukhaṭṭito.meaning_2: troubled with pain; afflicted by discomfort
dukhaṭṭito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound past participle where 'dukha' (pain) functions as the object of affliction, indicating being overwhelmed or distressed by pain. The form 'dukhaṭṭito' appears to be an instrumental singular, expressing the means or cause of the state.

nekkhammābhimukho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where nekkhamma ('renunciation') is the object of abhimukha ('facing, directed towards'), functioning as an adjective likely modifying a masculine or neuter noun in the context of spiritual aspiration or orientation towards renunciation.

hīnamajjhimukkaṭṭhesu.meaning_2: in the low, middle, and high senses; in the inferior, medium, and superior meanings
hīnamajjhimukkaṭṭhesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative plural form of a compound adjective describing 'senses' or 'meanings' (artha), likely in a doctrinal or interpretive context, categorizing concepts into three levels: deficient/inferior (hīna), medium/middling (majjhima), and elevated/superior (ukkaṭṭha).

avajjetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The prefix 'ava' indicates 'down' or 'away', enhancing the sense of avoidance. The form is an absolutive, used to denote an action completed prior to the main verb in the sentence.

hīnādikesu.meaning_2: beginning with the inferior; and so forth, the deficient etc.
hīnādikesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound form where 'hīna' (inferior, deficient) is combined with 'ādika' (beginning with, etc.), typically used to indicate a series starting from something inferior or lower in a list or category.

sabbapaṇḍite.meaning_2: all wise men; every sage; all learned persons
sabbapaṇḍite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a masculine noun in the locative singular, likely used in a context addressing or referring to all wise individuals collectively.

vīriyapāramiṃ.meaning_2: perfection of energy; perfection of effort; transcendental virtue of willpower
vīriyapāramiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vīriya (effort, energy) qualifies pāramī (perfection), common in Buddhist contexts for denoting the ten perfections (pāramī). The form vīriyapāramiṃ is accusative singular, likely the object in the sentence.

vīriyapāramimpi.meaning_2: even the perfection of energy; even the virtue of effort
vīriyapāramimpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an emphatic adverbial form of the compound 'vīriyapāramī' (perfection of energy, one of the ten Buddhist perfections) with 'api' added for emphasis, meaning 'even the perfection of energy' or 'even vīriyapāramī itself'. In Buddhist contexts, it refers to the transcendental virtue of effort or willpower.

sabbairiyāpathesu.meaning_2: in all postures; in every mode of deportment (walking, standing, sitting, lying down)
sabbairiyāpathesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative plural form of the tatpuruṣa compound sabbairiyāpatha, meaning 'all postures' or 'every way of movement,' commonly referring to the four standard postures in Buddhist contexts.

anolīnavīriyo.meaning_2: not sluggish with energy; active and energetic
anolīnavīriyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining the past participle anolīna (not absorbed or sluggish) with the adjective vīriyo (energetic, masculine nominative singular), likely used to describe someone actively engaged without mental torpor.

vīriyapāramitaṃ.meaning_2: perfection of energy; perfection of effort
vīriyapāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound common in Buddhist texts, denoting the third of the ten perfections (pāramī) in the Theravāda tradition, emphasizing diligent effort in spiritual practice.

alīnavīriyo.meaning_2: energetic; alert with effort; not sluggish and vigorous
alīnavīriyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'alīna' (active, not sluggish) with 'vīriyo' (possessing energy or effort), likely in vocative singular addressing someone as 'O energetic one' or similar; without sentences, context is inferred from dictionary entries emphasizing alertness and vigor.

paggahitamano.meaning_2: having a mind that is held up; sustained-minded
paggahitamano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'paggahita' (past participle meaning 'held up; sustained') modifies 'mana' (mind), indicating a mind that is sustained or kept up. The form 'paggahitamano' suggests nominative singular, likely from a context where the subject has such a mentality.

sammānanāvamānanakkhamova.meaning_2: only intolerance of honouring and disrespecting; only inability to endure honouring and belittling
sammānanāvamānanakkhamova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a dvanda compound linking two abstract feminine nouns (honouring and disrespecting) with the adjective 'intolerant of' intensified by 'only', possibly in a context discussing impartiality or equanimity towards respect and contempt.

advejjhamānaso.meaning_2: with a mind free from ambiguity; certain-minded; without doubt in intention
advejjhamānaso.construction: na > a + dvi + dhā + ya; √man > mān + as + *a
advejjhamānaso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'advejjha-' (non-ambiguous, certain) qualifies 'mānasa-' (of the mind), used adjectivally to describe a state of mental certainty or lack of doubt.

sammānāvamānakkhamo.meaning_2: intolerant of contempt for honour; unable to endure disrespect towards respect
sammānāvamānakkhamo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where akkhama modifies sammānāvamāna, indicating inability to tolerate contempt for honour. The form appears to be nominative singular masculine, likely describing a quality of patience or endurance in a religious or ethical context.

khantipāramitaṃ.grammar: nt nom acc sg of khantipāramitā
khantipāramitaṃ.meaning_2: perfection of patience; highest state of endurance
khantipāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form khantipāramitaṃ is the neuter nominative or accusative singular of the feminine abstract noun khantipāramitā, a compound denoting one of the Buddhist perfections (pāramī). In texts like the Jātaka or Pāramī stories, it refers to the ultimate development of patience as a virtue leading to enlightenment.

dhanādīnaṃ.meaning_1: wealth etc.; riches and the like
dhanādīnaṃ.meaning_2: wealth and so on; things beginning with wealth
dhanādīnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the genitive plural form of the tatpuruṣa compound 'dhanādi', where 'dhana' (wealth) is the first member and 'ādi' (beginning with, etc.) indicates a series starting with wealth. In Pāḷi compounds, 'ādi' is commonly used to denote 'and the like' or 'etc.'

chandādivasena.meaning_2: by means of desire etc.; concerning days etc.
chandādivasena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental adverbial form of the compound chandādi + divasa, indicating manner or reference to 'desire and the like' in relation to 'day'. The ending -ena forms the adverb from the instrumental singular of the neuter noun divasa.

sabbautūsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sabbautūsu is the locative plural of the compound sabbantu, meaning 'in all seasons' or 'in every season'. The stem utu is adjusted to utū- before su to avoid vowel hiatus, a common sandhi in Pāli compounds.

gamanavīthiṃ.meaning_2: path of going; way of proceeding; mental process of journeying
gamanavīthiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun where 'gaman' (going, journeying) modifies 'vīthi' (path, mental process), likely referring to a cognitive or procedural sequence involving movement or progression in a Pāḷi text context, possibly related to mental processes or the path to enlightenment.

sakavīthiyāva.meaning_2: as long as along one's own path; up to one's own way
sakavīthiyāva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sakavīthiyāva appears to be a sandhi compound where saka (one's own) modifies vīthi (path), with vīthiyā as the instrumental singular of vīthi, combined with eva (only, just). This suggests an adverbial phrase meaning 'just by one's own path' or 'as far as one's own path,' potentially referring to a mental or spiritual path in Buddhist context.

tulābhūtā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound adjective where 'tulābhūtā' describes something that has become or is like a balance (tulā), implying fairness, equality, or measurability in context. The form is feminine nominative singular, agreeing with an implied or contextually feminine noun.

utuvasse.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form utuvasse is the genitive singular of the tatpuruṣa compound utuvassa, combining utu 'season' and vassa 'rainy season'. It refers to the monsoon period in a possessive sense, as in 'of the rains retreat'.

saccapāramitaṃ.meaning_2: perfection of truthfulness; highest state of honesty
saccapāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form saccapāramitaṃ represents the neuter accusative singular of the compound noun saccapāramitā, derived from the feminine base saccapāramī with the -tā suffix forming an abstract neuter noun denoting the 'perfection' or 'state' of truthfulness. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is based on dictionary entries.

bhusavātehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural of the compound 'bhusavāta', likely meaning 'with strong winds' or 'with mighty airs', combining 'bhusa' (strong, powerful) and 'vāta' (wind).

adhiṭṭhānapāramitaṃ.meaning_2: highest state of resolution; perfection of determination
adhiṭṭhānapāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form adhiṭṭhānapāramitaṃ appears to be a neuter accusative singular, referring to 'the perfection of determination' in a specific context, likely as an object in a sentence discussing Buddhist perfections (pāramī).

ekacitto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound ekacitto combines 'eka' (one, single) with 'citta' (mind, thought), indicating unity or focus of mind, often denoting determination or lack of doubt in Buddhist contexts.

kalyāṇajanassāpi.meaning_2: good person; virtuous man; beneficial individual
kalyāṇajanassāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound where kalyāṇa qualifies jana, indicating a person of good or virtuous nature. The enclitic api suggests emphasis or concession, as in 'even for a good person'. Without the full sentence, the exact contextual nuance is inferred from dictionary meanings.

ekasadisaṃ.meaning_1: one-like; similar to one; uniform; identical
ekasadisaṃ.meaning_2: uniform; having one likeness; like one thing
ekasadisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ekasadisaṃ is the accusative singular masculine or neuter of the compound adjective ekasadisa, likely used here to describe something as 'uniform' or 'of one kind' in a specific context, though no sentences are provided for precise usage.

ekacittova.meaning_2: just like one mind; as if singly minded
ekacittova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ekacittova results from sandhi of eka citta iva, where the final -a of citta contracts with the initial i- of iva to -o. It functions as an adverbial phrase emphasizing undivided attention or singular focus, common in Pāli descriptions of meditative concentration.

rajomalaṃ.meaning_2: dust and dirt; impurity from dust
rajomalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from 'rajas' (dust) and 'mala' (dirt), indicating a combination of physical impurities, likely in the accusative singular form based on the ending -ṃ.

ahitahite.meaning_2: in benefit and harm; in good and bad
ahitahite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] dvandva compound expressing both aspects, typically used in contexts of discernment between beneficial and harmful actions or states

mettāpāramitaṃ.meaning_1: highest state of benevolence; perfection of friendliness
mettāpāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form mettāpāramitaṃ is the accusative singular of the feminine abstract noun, likely functioning as the object in a sentence discussing the Buddhist perfections (pāramī). It combines mettā (benevolence) with pāramī (perfection), extended to pāramitā as in related Indic traditions.

pakkhippamānā.meaning_2: placed in measure; measured out; proportioned
pakkhippamānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pakkhippamānā appears to be an inflected adjective combining the aorist stem pakkhip (from pakkhipati 'to place, enclose') with appa ('little, few'), likely functioning as an instrumental singular feminine or similar, meaning 'with a little that has been placed' or 'in measured small quantity'. Without the full sentence, the exact inflection is inferred from common Pāḷi patterns.

tulābhūto.meaning_2: become like a balance; balanced; even; comparable
tulābhūto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound tulābhūto combines 'tulā' (balance, scale) with 'bhūto' (past participle of √bhū, meaning 'become'), indicating something that has become like a balance, often used metaphorically for fairness or equilibrium in Pāḷi texts.

kopānunayavajjitā.meaning_2: devoid of anger and affection; free from rage and inclination
kopānunayavajjitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'vajjitā' (feminine past participle agreeing with an implied feminine noun like 'cittaṃ') qualifies the combined 'kopānunaya' (anger and affection), indicating a mind or state free from these defilements, common in descriptions of enlightenment or meditative purity.

upekkhāpāramitaṃ.meaning_2: perfection of equanimity; ultimate state of mental balance
upekkhāpāramitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upekkhāpāramitaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the compound noun upekkhāpāramī, used here as an object referring to the 'perfection of equanimity' in a Buddhist context of transcendental virtues.

bodhiparipācanā.meaning_2: maturation of awakening; ripening of enlightenment; development of bodhi
bodhiparipācanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bodhi' (enlightenment) is qualified by 'paripācana' (maturation), referring to the process of spiritual ripening or full development of awakening in a Buddhist context.

puratthimādīsu.meaning_2: beginning with the east; in the east and so on
puratthimādīsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun used in the locative plural to indicate 'in the directions beginning with the east' or similar, common in Pāli texts for listing cardinal directions and the like.

hadayamaṃsabbhantare.meaning_2: in the flesh of the heart
hadayamaṃsabbhantare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a locative singular form of a compound 'hadayamaṃsabbhantara', combining 'hadayamaṃsa' (flesh of the heart) with 'abbhantara' (internal, inside), likely meaning 'in the interior of the heart's flesh' or similar, possibly in a metaphorical or anatomical context. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

patiṭṭhitabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of being firmly grounded; state of being well established
patiṭṭhitabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines the past participle patiṭṭhita ('firmly grounded, established') with bhāva ('state, condition') to denote the abstract state of establishment or firm grounding, commonly used in doctrinal contexts to describe a stable condition of mind or practice.

hetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] 'hetvā' is the gerund form of 'hanati', often used in the sense of 'having struck' or 'having killed' in narrative contexts, indicating a completed action prior to the main verb.

bāhirakabhaṇḍapariccāgo.meaning_2: giving up of external goods; renunciation of worldly possessions
bāhirakabhaṇḍapariccāgo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound indicating the act of abandoning external merchandise or goods, likely in a monastic context of renunciation. The form appears in the nominative singular, functioning as the subject of the sentence.

aṅgapariccāgo.meaning_2: giving up of the body; bodily sacrifice; self-sacrifice
aṅgapariccāgo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'aṅga' (body/limb) is the object of 'pariccāga' (giving up). It denotes the act of renouncing or sacrificing one's body, often in the context of extreme ascetic practices or self-mortification in Pāḷi texts.

dānaupapāramī.meaning_2: perfection of giving; generosity as a higher perfection
dānaupapāramī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'dāna' (giving, charity) with 'upapāramī' (higher or secondary perfection in the Buddhist sense of pāramī). It refers to the specific virtue of generosity as one of the ten perfections in Theravāda tradition.

jīvitapariccāgo.meaning_2: giving up of life; self-sacrifice; suicide
jīvitapariccāgo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'jīvitapariccāgo' functions as the subject in the sentence, referring to the act of sacrificing one's life.

dānaparamatthapāramī.meaning_2: perfection of giving as the ultimate goal; transcendental virtue of generosity towards the highest truth
dānaparamatthapāramī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'dāna' (giving) specifies the type of 'paramatthapāramī' (ultimate perfection), referring to the virtue of generosity directed towards the highest spiritual goal in Buddhist contexts, one of the ten perfections (pāramī).

yantatelaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'yanta' (machine, mechanism) and 'tela' (oil), indicating oil used for machines or mechanisms. The form is accusative singular neuter, as indicated by the -aṃ ending.

cakkavāḷamahāsamuddaṃ.meaning_2: great ocean encompassing the world system; vast sea surrounding the solar system
cakkavāḷamahāsamuddaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely used in a cosmological context to describe the encircling ocean of the world system in Buddhist literature.

āluḷento.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Past participle form indicating a state of being firmly attached or immersed, often used metaphorically for mental clinging in Pāḷi texts.

catunahutādhikadviyojanasatasahassabahal.meaning_2: thick by more than four hundred thousand two-yojanas (units)
catunahutādhikadviyojanasatasahassabahal.family_compound: catu nahuta adhika dvi yojana sata sahassa bahala
catunahutādhikadviyojanasatasahassabahal.construction: catu + nahuta + adhika + dviyojana + satasahassa + bahala
catunahutādhikadviyojanasatasahassabahal.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex descriptive compound indicating a vast, thick measurement, likely referring to the breadth or density of a cosmic or geographical expanse in the text, where 'two-yojana' denotes a standard unit of distance (approx. 40 km), and the numerals quantify an immense scale exceeding 400,000 such units.

akkantanaḷakalāpo.meaning_2: bundle of reeds trodden on; trampled reed sheaf
akkantanaḷakalāpo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun where 'akkanta' (past participle of akkamati, meaning 'trodden on') modifies 'naḷakalāpa' (bundle of reeds). The form appears to be nominative singular, possibly in a narrative context describing something stepped upon, such as in a simile or descriptive passage.

telayantacakkaṃ.meaning_2: oil machine wheel; wheel of an oil-press contraption
telayantacakkaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound referring to the wheel component of an oil-extraction machine, likely an ancient press mechanism using sesame oil.

tatuddhaṃ.meaning_2: from there upwards; thereupon above; thereafter up
tatuddhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a two-word adverbial phrase functioning as an indeclinable, combining 'tato' (ablative of demonstrative 'ta', meaning 'from that/there') with 'uddhaṃ' (adverbial accusative of 'uddha', meaning 'upwards/above'). It likely indicates motion or sequence 'from there up' or 'thereafter above', common in locative or directional contexts in Pāḷi texts.

sabhāvasarasalakkhaṇe.meaning_2: in that which has inherent nature, essential function, and characteristics
sabhāvasarasalakkhaṇe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex compound combining sabhāva (inherent nature) with sarasalakkhaṇa (essential function and characteristics), likely used in a philosophical or doctrinal context to describe something possessing intrinsic qualities and defining features. The locative case ending -e indicates 'in' or 'with' this quality.

telayante.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word 'telayante' appears to be a misspelling or erroneous form, likely intended as 'telāya' (instrumental singular of 'tela', meaning 'with (sesame) oil'). No contextual sentences are provided, but based on standard Pāḷi usage, it would refer to application or use of sesame oil in a ritual, medicinal, or descriptive context.

medanīti.construction: me + √mid > meda + ā + nī > medanī + ti
medanīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Medanīti refers to a medical condition involving painful urination or urinary issues, often in Vinaya contexts related to monastic hygiene or health exemptions.

yugantavātabbhāhatā.meaning_2: afflicted with the atmosphere of the end of an age; buffeted by the wind of a yuga's end
yugantavātabbhāhatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex tatpuruṣa compound formed from 'yuganta' (end of an age), 'vāta' (atmosphere or wind), and 'abbhāhata' (struck or afflicted), with the suffix -tā indicating an abstract feminine noun denoting the state of being afflicted. The term evokes a sense of being overwhelmed by the ominous, turbulent air associated with the close of an era.

mucchitamucchitāva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form mucchitāva appears to be a fused adverbial expression, likely from mucchitā (feminine nominative singular past participle 'unconscious') + eva ('just'), functioning as an indeclinable emphasizing the state of being merely or just unconscious, possibly in a poetic or elliptical context addressing or describing a feminine subject.

ghaṭādīni.meaning_2: water pots etc.; jars and the like
ghaṭādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a neuter plural form of the compound 'ghaṭādi', where 'ghaṭa' means 'water pot' and 'ādi' indicates 'beginning with' or 'etc.', used to denote a class including water pots and similar items.

kulālabhājanāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'vessels obtained from a potter' or 'potter's ware'. The neuter plural form indicates multiple items, likely in a context referring to pottery or household vessels produced by a potter. The middle element labha functions as a relational morpheme linking 'potter' to 'vessel' in the sense of acquisition or production.

pavaṭṭantāni.meaning_2: arising; occurring; coming into being; manifesting
pavaṭṭantāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pavaṭṭantāni is the neuter nominative plural of the present participle pavattanta from pavattati ('to arise, continue, proceed'), prefixed with pa- indicating forth or out. It refers to things or phenomena that are arising or in the process of manifesting, likely in a doctrinal context such as dependent origination.

nāgāvaṭṭo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'nāga' (elephant) with 'vaṭṭa' (round, referring to the trunk), forming an adjective describing something round or cylindrical like an elephant's trunk. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is derived from components.

bhūtayakkhadevatāsu.meaning_2: among spirits, demons, and deities; among supernatural beings and gods
bhūtayakkhadevatāsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the locative plural, indicating 'in/among bhūtas (spirits or beings), yakkhas (supernatural daemons), and devatās (deities)'. The form reflects sandhi between bhūta + yakkha, with final -ā of devatā unchanged in the compound stem.

aññatarāvaṭṭoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aññatarāvaṭṭoti appears to be a sandhi-affected or corrupted version of aññatarāvaṭṭoti, likely meaning 'a certain whirlpool thus' or 'one eddy like this', where -oti is a scribal error for -oti (iti). Without context, it may refer to a specific or certain circular eddy or transformation.

viloḷentassa.meaning_2: of the one who stirs; of the one who shakes about
viloḷentassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the genitive singular of the present tense of viloḷeti, a causative verb derived from vi + √luḷ, indicating 'of the one who stirs or shakes about'. The form fits standard Pāḷi present genitive for aeti-class verbs.

sakaladasasahassilokadhātu.meaning_2: whole ten-thousand-fold world system; entire system of ten thousand worlds
sakaladasasahassilokadhātu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'sakala' (whole) with 'dasasahassilokadhātu' (ten thousand-fold world system), emphasizing the entirety of the cosmological structure in Buddhist contexts.

ghaṭānekasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the neuter nominative/accusative plural of the compound adjective 'ghaṭānekasahassa', meaning 'numbering thousands of water pots'. It refers to a large quantity of water jars, likely in a descriptive context of abundance.

sañcuṇṇamathitā.meaning_2: having been ground to powder; having been pulverized
sañcuṇṇamathitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an absolutive derived from a causative present stem sañcuṇṇamathati ('grinds to powder'), indicating an action completed before the main verb. It likely describes a process of thorough crushing or pulverizing, common in contexts like preparing ingredients or destroying something completely.

paghaṭṭitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a feminine nominative singular form of the past participle, derived from paghaṭṭeti (to touch or strike). The prefix 'pa-' indicates direction or intensity. No sentences provided for contextual meaning.

byadhitamānasā.meaning_2: sick-minded; afflicted in mind; mentally disturbed
byadhitamānasā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound meaning 'having a sick mind', used as an adjective to describe someone whose mind is afflicted, possibly by sorrow or illness.

dīpaṅkaramupāgamuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi compound where the accusative singular of the masculine proper name dīpaṅkara (name of the 24th previous Buddha) combines with the first person singular aorist of upāgacchati, indicating the speaker's approach to Dīpaṅkara Buddha; the final ~ṃ is the accusative marker adjusted in sandhi.

kalyāṇamatha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi combination of the adverb kalyāṇaṃ 'well' and the conjunction atha 'then', likely resulting from vowel sandhi where final -ṃ of kalyāṇaṃ elides before initial a- of atha. It is not a standard dictionary entry but a contextual fusion in the text.

pathavikampane.meaning_2: trembling of the path; shaking of the road
pathavikampane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative case singular, likely used in a context describing an event where the path trembles, such as during an earthquake or divine manifestation.

jinasevitaṃ.meaning_2: associated with the Jina; followed by the conqueror; practiced in the tradition of the victor
jinasevitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a compound where 'jina' (conqueror, epithet of the Buddha) modifies the past participle 'sevitaṃ' (associated with, followed), in neuter accusative singular, likely functioning as an adjective or substantival phrase referring to the doctrine, path, or practice associated with the Jina.

rammanagarā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form rammanagarā appears to be an instrumental singular of the compound rammanagara, meaning 'by the charming town' or 'with the delightful city', based on typical Pāḷi declension patterns for neuter compounds.

rammanagarameva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed by sandhi between the adjective 'ramm' (charming), the noun 'nagar' (city), and the indeclinable 'eva' (only); likely locative case in context, expressing exclusivity of location.

mālāgandhehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the tatpuruṣa compound mālāgandha 'garland-scent' or 'fragrant garland', referring to scented garlands. The neuter gender follows the second member gandha (nt). Used in contexts of offerings or adornments.

anantarāyena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The instrumental form indicates 'by means of obstacle' or 'without obstacle' in contexts implying prevention or obstruction, often used adverbially to mean 'unhindered' or 'without interruption'.

pupphūpagaphalūpagā.meaning_2: having flowers and fruits approaching; approaching with flowers and fruits
pupphūpagaphalūpagā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa sandhi compound formed from four members: puppha (flower), upaga (approaching), phala (fruit), and upagā (approaching, feminine nominative singular of upagacchati). It describes something or someone approaching while possessing or accompanied by flowers and fruits, possibly a metaphorical expression for a blooming and fruitful state or entity in approach.

phusassūtiādīni.meaning_1: things beginning with touching, birth, etc.
phusassūtiādīni.meaning_2: beginning with contact, birth, and so forth
phusassūtiādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in neuter plural accusative form, listing categories starting with 'phusa' (touching/contact) and 'sūti' (birth), followed by 'ādi' (etc.), likely referring to various contacts or experiences including physical touch and rebirth in a doctrinal context.

thutimaṅgalāni.meaning_2: auspicious praises; commendatory blessings; adulatory ceremonies
