dvānavutikappamatthake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning adverbially in locative sense, likely from the locative singular form, indicating a temporal endpoint after ninety-two aeons; 'matthake' provides the locative ending for the entire compound.

mahiddhikabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of great supernormal power; condition of magical power
mahiddhikabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound noun, likely used to denote the quality or state of possessing great magical or supernormal powers, common in Buddhist contexts referring to meditative attainments.

dibbamandāravapadumapāricchattakapupphān.meaning_2: divine flowers of coral tree and lotus and coral tree
dibbamandāravapadumapāricchattakapupphān.construction: dibba + mandārav + a + padum + a + pāricchattak + a + pupph + a
dibbamandāravapadumapāricchattakapupphān.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun listing types of heavenly flowers: divine coral tree flowers, lotus flowers, and coral flowers. The plural form indicates multiple such flowers in context.

catuparisamajjhe.meaning_1: in the midst of the fourfold assembly
catuparisamajjhe.meaning_2: in the midst of the fourfold assembly, viz. monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen
catuparisamajjhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form catuparisamajjhe is a sandhi compound where the locative singular catuparisāya (in the fourfold assembly) undergoes sandhi with majjhe (in the midst), resulting in -ā + majjhe > -amajjhe. This locative construction indicates location within the community of monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

pupphavitānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive plural form of the tatpuruṣa compound pupphavitāna, denoting 'of the flower canopies' or 'of the floral awnings', likely referring to decorative coverings made of flowers in a ceremonial or architectural context.

dvānavutikappe.meaning_2: kappa of ninety-two; period of ninety-two (aeons)
dvānavutikappe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines the cardinal number 'dvānavuti' (92) with 'kappa' in its sense of aeon or world-period, likely denoting a specific cosmological duration of ninety-two aeons, common in Buddhist texts for describing vast time scales.

janasandho.meaning_2: connected with people; united with people
janasandho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'jana' (people) is the upapada and 'sandha' (connected with) is the adjective base, resulting in a masculine adjective form. No contextual sentences are provided to specify usage.

asanarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from 'asana' (food or eating) and 'rukkha' (tree), likely referring to a tree that provides food or fruit. No contextual sentences provided, so meaning inferred from dictionary entries.

anantasīlo.meaning_2: having endless conduct; of boundless behaviour
anantasīlo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound adjective formed by ananta 'endless' and sīla 'having conduct', used in compounds to describe character or habit without limit.

lokagganāyakoti.meaning_2: chief of the world; world leader
lokagganāyakoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'world-chief', with lokagga (chief of the world) as the prior member and nāyaka (leader) as the subsequent member. The -ti ending indicates nominative singular.

āmalakarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is the nominative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound 'āmalaka-rukkha', referring to the tree bearing the āmalaka fruit (Phyllanthus emblica).

ekasatasahassaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound cardinal numeral formed by combining 'eka' (one), 'sata' (hundred), and 'sahassa' (thousand), literally 'one hundred thousand'. The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the object of a verb in the context, such as counting or quantifying entities like beings or worlds.

sattaratanakhacitaṃ.meaning_2: adorned with seven treasures; studded with seven gems
sattaratanakhacitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound adjective used as a neuter noun in accusative singular, describing something adorned or inlaid with the traditional seven jewels (e.g., gold, silver, lapis lazuli, etc.)

mahāpīṭhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun in neuter accusative singular, combining 'mahā' (great) and 'pīṭha' (seat). In Pāḷi texts, it often refers to a supreme or divine seat, such as a throne or a significant location.

candamittā.meaning_2: name of an arahant nun; lit. moon-friend
candamittā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Formed as a feminine derivative of the compound 'candamitta' (moon-friend), analogous to personal names like candā and mittā for arahant nuns.

pāṭalirukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pāṭalirukkho is nominative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound, with sandhi between -ī and r- resulting in -ir-. It denotes a tree known as the trumpet-flower tree (Bignonia suaveolens or similar), possibly used in a descriptive or locative context.

ekatiṃsakappe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound ekatiṃsakappe is the locative singular form, indicating location in time, specifically the 31st aeon or world-cycle. This usage is common in cosmological or biographical contexts describing events over vast periods.

sattattisahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral expressing seventy thousand, likely in neuter plural form as in the text, used to denote a large quantity, such as in cosmological contexts common in Pāḷi literature.

sattaratanapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.meaning_2: adorned with seven treasures; decorated with seven gems
sattaratanapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular neuter, likely describing an object (e.g., a statue or image) adorned with the seven Buddhist treasures (gold, silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, etc.). The compound combines the numeral 'satta' (seven) with 'ratana' (treasure/gem) and the past participle 'paṭimaṇḍita' (adorned).

hatthippamāṇaṃ.meaning_2: boundless like an elephant; elephant-like immeasurability
hatthippamāṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in accusative singular, likely describing something immeasurable in the manner of an elephant's strength or size; the form suggests use as an object in the sentence.

katiṃsakappe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] 'Katiṃsakappe' appears to be an inflected form (likely locative singular) of 'katiṃsaka', a compound denoting 100,000, used in numerical contexts in Pāli texts, especially in Vinaya for counting.

puṇḍarīkarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun in nominative singular, likely referring to a tree associated with the lotus or the fragrant mango tree (Mangifera indica) based on the components. Without the sentence context, the precise usage cannot be determined, but it denotes a type of tree.

sattatihatthubbedhaṃ.meaning_2: seventy-cubit height; seventy cubits in height
sattatihatthubbedhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound indicating a measurement of height equivalent to seventy cubits, likely referring to the stature or reach of a being in a narrative context, such as in cosmological or hagiographical descriptions where extraordinary proportions are mentioned.

yojanattayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound yojanattaya 'triad of yojanas', likely referring to a distance of approximately sixty kilometres in a geographical or travel context.

sikhivhayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sikhivhayo is the vocative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound sikhivhayo, meaning 'O one named Sikhī', referring to the Buddha named Sikhī. The sandhi combines sikhī (stem sikhī-) with avhayo (stem avhay-, voc. sg. of avhaya 'name').

ācāraguṇasampanno.meaning_2: endowed with the qualities of good conduct; possessing virtues of proper behavior
ācāraguṇasampanno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective describing someone accomplished in the virtues of conduct, typically used in Buddhist texts to praise moral excellence.

cittīkārapītibahulo.meaning_2: full of mental consideration and joy
cittīkārapītibahulo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where bahula qualifies the combined cittīkārapīti, indicating abundance of heedful joy or devotion.

samālā.meaning_2: with a pavilion; together with the tent
samālā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form samālā appears to be a sandhi combination of the prefix 'sa' (meaning 'with') and 'mālā' (garland), but given the dictionary entries, it likely intends 'sa + māla' (with pavilion), with vowel assimilation from ā to ā. However, the stem and pattern suggest a masculine form in -ā, possibly an error or dialectal variant for 'samāla'. Without context sentences, interpretation is based on common compounds in Pāli texts.

sapattacīvaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Accusative singular form of the compound 'pattacīvara', referring to the bowl and robe together, common in monastic contexts.

mahādānañceva.meaning_2: great gift and; great offering as well
mahādānañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi form resulting from the combination of the neuter noun mahādāna (great gift/offering) with the conjunction ca (and) and the emphatic particle eva (indeed/just). The 'ñ' represents sandhi assimilation of 'n' from dāna with the following 'c' of ca. Likely used in a context enumerating virtues or practices, such as in Buddhist texts emphasizing generosity.

añjanādibhesajjāni.meaning_2: ointments and the like medicines; medicinal substances beginning with ointments
añjanādibhesajjāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'añjana' (eye ointment or collyrium) is qualified by 'ādi' (beginning with, etc.) and combined with 'bhesajja' (medicines), indicating a category of remedies starting with ointments. The form is neuter nominative plural, likely listing types of medicines in a Vinaya or medical context.

mahāsirīsarukkho.meaning_2: great tree of good fortune; venerable sirīsa tree
mahāsirīsarukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sirīsa' is qualified by 'mahā' (great sirīsa) and the whole specifies the type of 'rukkha' (tree). 'Sirī' in sirīsa likely relates to the tree's name rather than the goddess of fortune, but the compound evokes auspiciousness.

cattālīsahatthubbedhaṃ.meaning_2: a height of forty cubits; measurement of forty hand-spans in height
cattālīsahatthubbedhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound indicating a specific measurement, likely referring to the height of a structure or object in a narrative context, such as a building or statue in Pāḷi literature.

amaccagaṇaparivuto.meaning_2: surrounded by a group of ministers; accompanied by royal advisors
amaccagaṇaparivuto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a nominative singular masculine of a compound past participle, describing someone surrounded by a ministerial group, likely in a royal or advisory context.

paṭṭuṇṇacīnapaṭṭakoseyyakambaladukūlāni.meaning_2: silk cloths, woollen cloths, Chinese cloths, cocoon-silk cloths, and fine cloths
paṭṭuṇṇacīnapaṭṭakoseyyakambaladukūlāni.family_compound: paṭṭa uṇṇā cīnapaṭṭa koseyya kambala dukūla
paṭṭuṇṇacīnapaṭṭakoseyyakambaladukūlāni.construction: paṭṭa + uṇṇā + cīnapaṭṭa + koseyya + kambala + dukūla
paṭṭuṇṇacīnapaṭṭakoseyyakambaladukūlāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a long dvanda compound listing various types of fine fabrics, appearing in nominative plural neuter as the object of a verb like 'dānaṃ deti' in a Vinaya context of monastic offerings or prohibitions on luxurious robes.

bhiyyaso.meaning_2: more; to a greater degree; further
bhiyyaso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a variant or scribal error for standard Pāli 'bhiyyo' (comparative adverb from 'bhūri'), used to indicate increase or repetition in context.

udumbararukkho.meaning_2: cluster fig tree; Ficus racemosa tree
udumbararukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is the nominative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'udumbara' (cluster fig) and 'rukkha' (tree), denoting the tree species Ficus racemosa. No contextual sentences provided, so meaning inferred from dictionary entries.

tiṃsahatthubbedhaṃ.meaning_2: height of thirty cubits; lit. thirty hand-piercings-up
tiṃsahatthubbedhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an indeclinable measure of height in context, likely accusative singular in a descriptive phrase; 'ubbedha' derives from ud + √vidh, indicating upward piercing or extent.

vattāvattasampattiyā.meaning_2: accomplishment in proper and improper conduct; attainment of right and wrong practices
vattāvattasampattiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'vatta' (proper duty or conduct, from √vatt) and 'āvatta' (improper or reverted conduct, from ā + √vatt), suffixed with 'sampatti' (accomplishment, from saṃ + √pad), indicating possession or means of attainment in matters of correct and incorrect behavior.

jātanagaraṃ.meaning_2: town of a particular type; city belonging to a class; kind of town
jātanagaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'jāta' (type, class) qualifies 'nagara' (town, city), indicating a town of a specific kind or category. The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the object in the sentence.

anuḷā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form anuḷā appears to be a variant or dialectal spelling of anu, possibly influenced by regional pronunciation or scribal variation in Pāḷi texts. It functions as a preposition indicating spatial or temporal following, similar to the related entries for anu. Without provided sentences, the exact contextual usage cannot be specified further.

nigrodharukkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'nigrodha' (banyan tree) and 'rukkha' (tree), used as a specific designation for the banyan tree. The form 'nigrodharukkho' indicates it is likely the subject or a descriptive term in the sentence.

vīsatihatthubbedhaṃ.meaning_1: twenty-cubit height; twenty cubits in height
vīsatihatthubbedhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular neuter form of a tatpuruṣa compound describing a measurement of height equivalent to twenty cubits, likely referring to the stature or reach of an object or being in the context.

mahātamavinodanā.meaning_2: by dispelling the great darkness; by removing gross ignorance
mahātamavinodanā.construction: mahā + tamas + vi + node + ana + ā
mahātamavinodanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is an instrumental singular form of the compound noun mahātamavinodana, where vinodana acts as an abstract noun from the causative of vi√nud, indicating the action of dispelling. The compound likely denotes 'the dispelling of the great darkness' in a spiritual context, such as enlightenment removing ignorance.

dīpaṅkarādīnaṃ.meaning_2: Dīpaṅkara and so forth; beginning with Dīpaṅkara
dīpaṅkarādīnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive plural form of the compound dīpaṅkarādi, indicating 'of Dīpaṅkara and others', commonly used in Buddhist texts to refer to Dīpaṅkara Buddha and subsequent previous Buddhas in lists.

orabhāge.meaning_2: lower part; inferior portion; this side's share
orabhāge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from 'ora' (abbrev of avara, meaning lower or this side) and 'bhāga' (part or portion); likely denotes a spatial or hierarchical division, such as the lower section or near-bank area, depending on context.

laddhabyākaraṇo.meaning_2: acquisition of explanation; getting of exposition
laddhabyākaraṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a technical term in Vinaya or Abhidhamma contexts referring to the process or instance of obtaining doctrinal explanation or commentary. The form suggests a neuter noun used as a compound in doctrinal discussions.

yenena.meaning_2: by which; whereby; on account of which
yenena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the relative pronoun 'ya', used to indicate means or cause in context.

dīpaṅkarapādamūle.meaning_2: at the base of the feet of Dīpaṅkara
dīpaṅkarapādamūle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of the compound dīpaṅkarapādamūla, referring to the base of the feet of the Buddha Dīpaṅkara, often used in contexts of prostration or reverence in Buddhist texts.

dānapāramitādayo.meaning_2: beginning with the perfection of giving, etc.; and so on starting from the perfection of generosity
dānapāramitādayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dānapāramitādayo is a compound where dānapāramī (perfection of giving) combines with ādi (beginning with, etc.), inflected in the nominative plural masculine to denote a class or series starting with that item. The -tā- appears to be an extended stem form of pāramī in this context, possibly influenced by sandhi or dialectal variation in compounds.

kappakoṭisatehipi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form with api, indicating 'even with billions of aeons', likely referring to vast cosmic time periods in a Buddhist context.

nijjhāmataṇhā.meaning_2: burnt craving; desire that has been burned out
nijjhāmataṇhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound where 'nijjhāmata' (from the past participle nijjhām(a), 'burnt') modifies 'taṇhā' ('craving'), indicating craving that has been extinguished or overcome, a concept often used in Buddhist contexts to describe liberation from desire.

kālakañjakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A compound noun referring to a type of vegetable, likely Cucurbita pepo or similar gourd plant, used in Pāli texts for culinary or medicinal contexts.

sotavekallatā.meaning_2: deformity of the ear; ear defect
sotavekallatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sota' (ear) specifies the type of 'vekallatā' (deformity). In Vinaya context, it likely refers to physical defects disqualifying ordination, such as an ear malformation.

mūgapakkhikā.meaning_2: mute-sided; associated with muteness; non-verbal factional
mūgapakkhikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form suggests a feminine adjective, possibly 'mute-sided' or 'belonging to the mute faction', combining 'mūga' (mute) with 'pakkhika' (sided with, fortnightly). Without sentences, the primary sense is likely 'associated with muteness' in a factional or side-related context.

ubhatobyañjanapaṇḍakā.meaning_2: hermaphroditic eunuch; person with dual sexual characteristics who is asexual or effeminate
ubhatobyañjanapaṇḍakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound combines 'ubhatobyañjana' (hermaphrodite) with 'paṇḍaka' (eunuch or effeminate), referring to a specific category in Vinaya texts for individuals ineligible for ordination due to ambiguous or non-normative gender/sexual traits.

suddhagocarā.meaning_2: pure domain; suitable sphere; proper range of activity
suddhagocarā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'suddha' (pure, clean) with 'gocara' (domain, sphere), indicating a purified or appropriate field of activity, often in a doctrinal or meditative context.

kammakiriyadassanā.meaning_2: by insight into action; through seeing of deeds
kammakiriyadassanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of the compound noun kammakiriyadassana, meaning 'seeing of action/deed'. The compound combines kamma (action), kiriya (doing, action), and dassana (seeing, insight), likely denoting spiritual insight into the nature of volitional actions in Buddhist context.

nūpapajjare.meaning_2: does not approach; does not go near
nūpapajjare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is 3rd sg. present indicative of the negative prefixed verb nūpapajjati, likely a denominative from a base related to 'pajja' (approach, go near), with nū- intensifying and na- negating. In context, it indicates refraining from approaching.

lokatthacariyāyo.meaning_2: conduct beneficial to the world; behavior that serves the welfare of people
lokatthacariyāyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is feminine genitive plural, indicating 'of those who have conduct beneficial to the world' or similar, depending on context; combines 'loka' (people or world) with 'atthacariyā' (beneficial conduct).

sabbapāramīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'sabba' (all) with 'pāramī' (perfection), referring to the complete set of ten perfections in Buddhist doctrine.

akittibrāhmaṇakāle.meaning_2: at the time of infamy among priests
akittibrāhmaṇakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular sandhi compound used adverbially to indicate a specific occasion or time period involving disrepute among Brahmins; the form akittibrāhmaṇakāle results from the combination of akitti (fem nt stem) + brāhmaṇa (masc) + kāle (loc sg of kāla), with sandhi resolution of i + b → ib and no further change before kāle.

saṅkhabrāhmaṇakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the conch and the Brahman; at the time of the priest and the conch shell
saṅkhabrāhmaṇakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative singular form, likely referring to a specific ritual or mythological time involving the conch shell (saṅkha) and the Brahman priest (brāhmaṇa). The exact context from the sentences is not provided, but it evokes ceremonial or auspicious timing in Pāḷi literature.

dhanañcayarājakāle.meaning_2: in the time of king Dhanañcaya
dhanañcayarājakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Locative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound dhanañcayarājakāla, meaning 'in the time of king Dhanañcaya', where Dhanañcaya is a Kuru king (lit. 'heap of wealth')

mahāsudassanakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the great King Sudassana
mahāsudassanakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This locative form indicates the time or occasion associated with the ancient king Mahāsudassana, a previous incarnation of the Buddha, as referenced in DN17 Mahāsudassanasutta.

mahāgovindakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the great Govinda; at the appropriate time of Jotipāla
mahāgovindakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form used adverbially to indicate 'at the time of the great Govinda', referring to Jotipāla, likely in a narrative context of a specific occasion or event involving this figure.

nimimahārājakāle.meaning_2: in the time of King Nimi
nimimahārājakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a temporal adverb, indicating 'in the time of King Nimi', where Nimi is a legendary king and previous birth of the Buddha.

candakumārakāle.grammar: ind, adv, loc sg of candakumārakāla
candakumārakāle.meaning_2: in the time of Prince Canda; during the period of Prince Canda
candakumārakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the locative singular adverb of the tatpuruṣa compound candakumārakāla ('the time of Prince Canda'), indicating temporal location. Prince Canda is a previous incarnation of Sāriputta, often referenced in Jātaka tales.

visayhaseṭṭhikāle.meaning_2: at the time of the merchant in the province; at the occasion of the provincial businessman
visayhaseṭṭhikāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative adverbial phrase used as a sandhi compound, functioning as a temporal adverb indicating 'at the time of the provincial merchant.' The form kāle is locative singular of kāla, combined with the attributive visayha and seṭṭhi. Likely from a context describing a specific event or occasion involving a merchant in a province.

sivirājakāle.meaning_2: in the time of king Sivi
sivirājakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to the era or reign of King Sivi, a legendary figure in ancient Indian lore known for his generosity.

vessantarakāleti.meaning_2: at the time of Vessantara; in the Vessantara story
vessantarakāleti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a sandhi combination of 'Vessantara' (proper name) in accusative with 'kāle' (locative singular of kāla meaning 'at the time'). This is likely an adverbial phrase indicating the context or occasion related to the Vessantara Jātaka, a famous birth story of the Buddha's previous life.

dānapāramitāya.meaning_2: by the perfection of giving; through the highest state of generosity
dānapāramitāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the instrumental singular form of the feminine compound noun 'dānapāramitā', referring to the Buddhist virtue of perfect generosity, used here likely in a context of dedication or attainment.

pūritattabhāvānaṃ.meaning_2: being filled; filled state; creature that is filled
pūritattabhāvānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where pūrita (past participle of pūreti, 'to fill') modifies attabhāva ('self-state' or 'being'). It likely refers to a being or entity characterized by fullness, possibly in a metaphysical or existential sense in Pāli texts.

sakattānaṃ.meaning_2: of one's own; belonging to oneself
sakattānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sakattānaṃ is the genitive plural of saka, used to indicate possession ('of one's own') in contexts describing personal or reflexive belongings, such as one's own actions or possessions.

attapariccāgaṃ.meaning_2: self-sacrifice; abandonment of self; giving up the self
attapariccāgaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form attapariccāgaṃ is accusative singular, indicating the object of a verb in a context likely involving an act of self-renunciation or sacrifice, common in Buddhist texts.

dānapāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of giving; perfection of generosity
dānapāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term is a compound combining 'dāna' (giving, generosity) with 'pāramitā' (perfection), a key concept in Buddhist doctrine referring to the transcendent virtues or perfections cultivated on the path to enlightenment. The suffix 'tā' forms the abstract feminine noun indicating the state or quality of perfection.

sīlavarājakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the virtuous king; during the era of the ethical ruler
sīlavarājakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound noun sīlavarājakālo, denoting 'at the time of Sīlava the king' or 'during the reign of the virtuous king Sīlava'. It likely refers to a specific historical or narrative period involving the arahant monk Sīlava acting in a royal or sovereign capacity.

campeyyanāgarājakāle.meaning_2: in the time of the Nāga king of Campā
campeyyanāgarājakāle.construction: campeyy + an + nāga + rāja + kāl + e
campeyyanāgarājakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'campeyyanāgarājakāla', meaning 'the time of the Nāga king of Campā'. The adjective 'campeyya' qualifies 'nāgarāja', and the whole is governed by 'kāla'. Used adverbially to indicate 'at that time' in narrative contexts, such as in Jātaka stories involving the city of Campā.

bhūridattanāgarājakāle.meaning_2: in the time of King Bhūridatta, the nāga king
bhūridattanāgarājakāle.construction: bhūri + datta + nāga + rāja + kāla + e
bhūridattanāgarājakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a temporal adverbial phrase, likely referring to a legendary serpent king from Buddhist Jātaka tales, where Bhūridatta is a nāga prince transformed into a human.

chaddantanāgarājakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the six-tusked elephant king; at the time of the royal tusker
chaddantanāgarājakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of the compound noun chaddantanāgarājakāla, used adverbially to indicate 'at the time of'. The compound refers to the legendary six-tusked elephant king from the Jātaka tales, symbolizing a specific era or occasion.

jayaddisarājaputtakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the son of the non-ruling conqueror; in the era of the victorious prince without royal authority
jayaddisarājaputtakāle.construction: jaya + addi + arāja + putta + kāla + e
jayaddisarājaputtakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound used adverbially, likely indicating a specific historical or narrative period involving a victorious figure who is a son but not a reigning king.

alīnasattukumārakāleti.meaning_2: alert young enemy prince; active non-sluggish adversary boy
alīnasattukumārakāleti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a vocative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound alīnasattukumārakāla followed by iti, likely used in direct address or citation, such as 'O alert young enemy prince!' or similar. The compound combines 'alīna' (active), 'sattu' (enemy), 'kumāra' (prince/youngster), and 'kāla' (time), possibly implying a timely or opportune adversary figure. Without context, the exact nuance is interpretive, but it evokes a narrative or poetic reference to a vigilant youthful opponent.

sīlapāramitāya.meaning_2: perfection of morality; perfection of ethical conduct
sīlapāramitāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sīlapāramitāya is the feminine instrumental singular of the compound sīlapāramitā, used to indicate the means or dative of cause in the context of Buddhist perfections (pāramī).

vijjhiyantopi.meaning_2: even while they are shooting; even if they are shooting
vijjhiyantopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an adverbial construction combining the present participle 'vijjhiyant-' (shooting), the 3rd plural ending '-i', and the emphatic particle 'api' (even, also), functioning as an indeclinable adverb indicating manner or concession, e.g., 'even while shooting'. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

koṭṭiyantopi.meaning_2: even up to the end; even at the tip
koṭṭiyantopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form or compound adverb meaning 'even up to the end' or 'even at the tip,' likely from 'koṭṭiya' (tip, end) + 'anta' (end) + 'api' (even, also). Without the sentence context, the exact usage is inferred from common Pāḷi adverbial constructions.

sattihi.meaning_2: with a spear; with power; with strength
sattihi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sattihi is the instrumental singular of satti, which can mean either 'spear' or 'power/strength' depending on context. Without the specific sentence provided, both senses are possible; in martial contexts, it likely refers to a weapon, while in descriptive contexts, it denotes ability.

sīlapāramitā.meaning_1: perfection of morality; perfection of conduct
sīlapāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of ethical conduct; ultimate state of moral integrity
sīlapāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sīlapāramitā extends sīlapāramī by adding the suffix -tā, indicating abstraction or the state of perfection, common in Buddhist terminology for the pāramī or pāramitā series.

somanassakumārakāle.meaning_2: at the time of a joyful young prince; at the occasion of the happy youngster
somanassakumārakāle.construction: somanassa + kumār + a + kāl + a + e
somanassakumārakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative case, likely functioning adverbially as 'at the time when he was a joyful young prince', indicating a temporal context of youth and happiness.

hatthipālakumārakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the elephant-keeper prince
hatthipālakumārakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'hatthipālakumārakāla', meaning 'the time of Hatthipāla the prince' or 'the time when Hatthipāla was a prince'. Hatthipāla is a proper name referring to a young prince who was an elephant keeper.

ayogharapaṇḍitakāleti.grammar: sandhi, masc + adj + masc + masc + ind
ayogharapaṇḍitakāleti.meaning_2: the house-wise man time thus; the learned householder at the right time thus
ayogharapaṇḍitakāleti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound likely used in a quotative or illustrative sense, such as naming or describing 'the house-wise man at the right time, thus.' aya may mean 'coming' or 'way,' ghara 'house,' paṇḍita 'learned,' kāla 'time,' iti 'thus.' Without the full sentence, the exact contextual meaning is inferred as a proverbial or definitional phrase.

nekkhammapāramitāya.meaning_2: by the perfection of renunciation; through the ultimate state of giving up
nekkhammapāramitāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the feminine instrumental singular of the compound nekkhammapāramī, used to indicate the means or instrument of the perfection of renunciation in Buddhist contexts.

nissaṅgatāya.meaning_2: on account of being unattached; because of detachment
nissaṅgatāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nissaṅgatāya is the feminine instrumental singular of the abstract noun nissaṅgatā, derived from the adjective nissaṅga 'unattached, free'. It denotes the state or quality of being unattached, used adverbially to indicate the reason or manner.

nekkhammapāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of renunciation; highest state of giving up
nekkhammapāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nekkhammapāramitā is the nominative singular of the compound noun, with pāramī extended to pāramitā, a common nominalization in Pāli for abstract concepts, emphasizing the 'state' or 'perfection' aspect.

vidhurapaṇḍitakāle.grammar: ind, adv, sandhi, masc + adj + masc
vidhurapaṇḍitakāle.meaning_2: in the time of the wise Vidhura
vidhurapaṇḍitakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative adverbial form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'vidhurapaṇḍitakāla' (time of Vidhura the wise man), used to indicate the period or era associated with the wise disciple Vidhura.

mahāgovindapaṇḍitakāle.meaning_2: in the time of the great Govinda Pandit
mahāgovindapaṇḍitakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound used adverbially to denote 'in the time of'. The epithet 'mahāgovinda' refers to Jotipāla, and 'paṇḍita' specifies his role as a learned sage. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is derived from component analysis.

kuddālapaṇḍitakāle.grammar: sandhi, masc + adj + masc + loc sg
kuddālapaṇḍitakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the foolish spade; at the time of the spade-like fool
kuddālapaṇḍitakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a bahuvrīhi-like compound where 'kuddāla' (spade) modifies 'paṇḍita' (learned person), but with 'a-' privative implied, yielding 'apaṇḍita' (unlearned, foolish). The locative 'kāle' indicates 'at the time of'. Likely idiomatic for a time of folly or incompetence, perhaps in a proverbial or narrative context.

arakapaṇḍitakāle.meaning_2: at the time of Araka, the wise (teacher)
arakapaṇḍitakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'arakapaṇḍitakāla', meaning 'the time of Araka the paṇḍita', used adverbially to indicate 'at the time of'. Araka is a legendary wise teacher in Pāli tradition, often referenced in similes for ancient wisdom.

bodhiparibbājakakāle.meaning_2: at the time of the wandering ascetic Bodhi; at the time of the Bodhi wanderer
bodhiparibbājakakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'bodhiparibbājakakāla', meaning 'the time of Bodhi the wandering ascetic'. 'Bodhi' refers to a private Buddha (paccekabuddha) by that name, and 'paribbājaka' indicates his role as a wandering ascetic.

mahosadhapaṇḍitakāleti.grammar: sandhi, masc + masc + adj + masc + ind
mahosadhapaṇḍitakāleti.meaning_2: great mockery of the wise man, thus; 'the great derision of the scholar', thus
mahosadhapaṇḍitakāleti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a sandhi compound likely representing 'maho-sadha-paṇḍita-kāle ti' (great mockery of the wise man, thus), with 'osadha' as a potential variant or scribal error for 'sadha' (mockery); used quotatively to denote a proverbial or cited expression about deriding a scholar at an inopportune time.

senakapaṇḍitakāle.meaning_2: in the time of the wise Senaka
senakapaṇḍitakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative singular, likely referring to the era or period associated with the arahant monk Senaka, described as wise. The ending -e indicates locative case of the entire compound.

vicinantohaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vicinantohaṃ appears to be a sandhi combination of the present participle vicinant- (instrumental singular) and the pronoun ahaṃ ('I'), likely resolving as vicinant + o + ahaṃ, common in Pāli for 'I [being] investigating'. The lemma is thus the base participle stem in nominative form.

antobhastagataṃ.meaning_2: gone into the body; embodied; entered within the body
antobhastagataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'gataṃ' (past participle of √gam, 'gone') is modified by 'antobhastā' meaning 'within the body' (anto 'inside' + bhastā 'body'). The neuter accusative singular form suggests it functions as an object or predicate nominative, likely describing a state of being embodied or having entered the body in a philosophical or doctrinal context.

vīriyapāramitādīnampi.meaning_2: even the perfections beginning with energy; and so forth including the perfection of energy
vīriyapāramitādīnampi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in instrumental plural with api, listing the Buddhist perfections (pāramī) starting with vīriya (energy or effort), a key virtue in the pāramī tradition. The ādi indicates 'and so on' or 'etc.', and api adds an inclusive or emphatic sense like 'even' or 'also'.

jalamajjhe.meaning_2: in the midst of the water
jalamajjhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound where 'jala' (nt, water) combines with 'majjhe' (loc sg of majjha, in the middle), functioning adverbially to indicate location in the midst of water. The form 'jalamajjhe' likely results from elision or fusion in context, common in Pāḷi for such adverbial phrases.

vīriyapāramīti.meaning_2: perfection of energy; perfection of effort; one of the ten perfections
vīriyapāramīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound denoting the 'perfection consisting of vīriya' (energy or effort), one of the pāramīs in Buddhist doctrine. The ending -īti reflects the feminine nominative singular form of the abstract noun.

vīriyapāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of energy; perfection of effort
vīriyapāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'vīriyapāramitā' denotes the 'perfection' (pāramitā) characterized by 'energy' or 'effort' (vīriya), a key concept in Buddhist doctrine representing one of the six or ten perfections (pāramī) essential for spiritual progress.

khantivādijātake.meaning_2: in the birth story of the patience-preacher; in the story of the one who speaks with patience
khantivādijātake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the locative singular of a neuter noun, referring to a specific Jātaka tale where the protagonist is characterized by patience in speech or doctrine. The structure indicates 'in the Jātaka of the patience-speaking one'.

mahādukkhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a compound adjective 'mahādukkha', used nominally to indicate great or intense suffering, a common Buddhist term for profound dukkha.

khantipāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of patience; highest state of endurance
khantipāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun formed by adding the suffix -tā to khantipāramī, indicating the abstract state or fact of the perfection of patience. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is based on dictionary entries.

saccapāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of truth; highest state of truthfulness
saccapāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form saccapāramitā is the nominative singular of the feminine abstract noun, extending the base compound saccapāramī with the -tā suffix to denote the state or realization of the perfection.

vatamadhiṭṭhahinti.meaning_2: thus having resolved upon a vow; thus determined to undertake a spiritual practice
vatamadhiṭṭhahinti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi-resolved form of a compound expression where 'vata' (vow or exclamation) combines with the aorist 'adhiṭṭhahiṃ' (having resolved or fixed attention) and quotative 'iti' (thus). In context, it likely functions as an adverbial phrase indicating a firm resolution or determination regarding a religious duty, common in doctrinal statements.

adhiṭṭhānapāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of determination; perfection of resolution; highest state of resolution
adhiṭṭhānapāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the feminine nominative singular form of the compound noun denoting one of the ten perfections (pāramī) in Buddhist doctrine, specifically emphasizing steadfast determination of mind.

mettābalenupatthaddho.meaning_2: supported by the strength of loving-kindness; upheld by the power of benevolence
mettābalenupatthaddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning as an indeclinable adjective phrase in the nominative singular masculine, describing a state of being supported or strengthened by loving-kindness. The instrumental form 'baleṇa' is embedded within the compound, indicating the means of support.

mettāpāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of loving-kindness; perfection of benevolence
mettāpāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form mettāpāramitā appears to be a variant or scribal adjustment of mettāpāramī, with the addition of -tā suffix indicating abstract state, common in Mahāyāna-influenced Pāli texts where pāramitā denotes the 'perfections' of the bodhisattva path. Without sentence context, the usage is inferred from standard Buddhist terminology.

upadhāyahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upadhāyahaṃ appears to be a sandhi variant or scribal error for upadhā + ya + haṃ, combining 'upadhā' (from upa + √dhā, lit. 'placing near', here adverbial 'nearby') with 'ya' (relative 'where') and 'haṃ' (emphatic 'indeed'). It functions as an adverbial phrase meaning 'wherever indeed' or 'at whatever place nearby', possibly in a locative sense emphasizing proximity in context.

upāgantvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Gerund form indicating anterior action, commonly used in Vinaya texts to describe sequential events like approaching a monk or assembly.

dassentinappakanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word dassentinappakanti appears to be a sandhi combination of dassenti (3pl pres caus 'they show') + anappaka (adj 'considerable') + iti (quotative 'thus'). In context, it likely means 'they show [it to be] considerable thus', emphasizing that something is presented as not insignificant.

niṭṭhubhanādīhi.meaning_2: with (matters) such as spitting out, expectoration, etc.
niṭṭhubhanādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound niṭṭhubhana-ādi, indicating 'with things beginning with (niṭṭhubhana)'. Used in contexts listing prohibited or impure acts starting with expectoration, typical in Vinaya or monastic rules.

mālāgandhūpahārādīhi.meaning_2: beginning with garlands and offerings of fragrance, etc.
mālāgandhūpahārādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'beginning with garlands, fragrance offerings, etc.', used to list items in a series, typical in Pāḷi for enumeration in vinaya contexts.

anativattantassa.meaning_2: of the one not conforming; of the one not behaving accordingly
anativattantassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a tatpuruṣa compound 'anati-vatta-nta' with anati (non-inclination, from √nam) modifying vatta (custom, behavior), functioning as a present participle agreeing with a masculine or neuter subject in genitive singular. The prefix ana- likely intensifies the negation.

upekkhāpāramitā.meaning_2: perfection of equanimity; highest state of equanimity
upekkhāpāramitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun formed by adding the suffix -tā to the base upekkhāpāramī, indicating the abstract state or perfection. It appears in the accusative singular form in the text.

vessantarattabhāve.meaning_2: in the state of being Vessantara; in the incarnation as Vessantara
vessantarattabhāve.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in locative singular case, referring to the personal state or incarnation of Vessantara, the famous prince from the Jātaka tale who is a previous birth of the Buddha. The form indicates a specific context, likely narrative or doctrinal, emphasizing his existence or condition as Vessantara.

aviññāya.meaning_2: not knowing; not understanding; not being conscious (of)
aviññāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The negative gerund formed with 'a-' prefix, indicating absence of knowledge or consciousness, commonly used in Buddhist contexts to describe states of ignorance or unconsciousness.

dānabalā.meaning_2: woman of giving strength; generous woman; woman endowed with the power of charity
dānabalā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a compound noun analogous to abalā ('woman', lit. 'not-strong'), where dāna ('giving, charity') modifies balā ('strength'), forming a descriptive feminine term for a woman characterized by generous or charitable strength. Without specific sentences, the interpretation is based on compositional analysis and common Pāḷi patterns for gendered compounds.

mahāpathavikampanādīni.meaning_2: great highway tremors and so forth
mahāpathavikampanādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex compound where 'mahāpatha' (highway) is qualified by 'kampanādīni' (tremors etc.), likely describing earthquake-like shaking of the earth or paths as an example of omens or signs in Pāli texts.

dīpaṅkarapādamūlato.meaning_2: from the base of the feet of Dīpaṅkara
dīpaṅkarapādamūlato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an ablative form of the tatpuruṣa compound dīpaṅkarapādamūla, meaning 'the base of Dīpaṅkara's feet', used in Buddhist texts to indicate prostration or reverence at the feet of the Buddha Dīpaṅkara.

avidūrenidānakathā.meaning_2: introduction not far (removed); proximate introductory narrative
avidūrenidānakathā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound avidūrenidānakathā combines the locative adverb avidūre ('near') with nidānakathā ('introduction' or 'background story'), suggesting an introductory narrative that is proximate or not far removed, possibly in a textual or narrative context where the story is closely connected to the main events.

lokasmiñhi.meaning_2: in the world; indeed in this world
lokasmiñhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form lokasmiñhi results from sandhi between the locative singular of loka (lokasmiṃ) and the enclitic particle hi, where final ṃ assimilates to ñ before h. It functions adverbially, emphasizing 'in this world indeed' or 'for in this world'.

kappakolāhalaṃ.meaning_2: uproar of the rabble; noisy disturbance of the crowd
kappakolāhalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'kappa' (suitable, allowable) with 'kolāhala' (rabble, uproar), likely denoting a permissible or fitting tumult of the crowd in a vinaya context.

cakkavattikolāhalanti.meaning_2: uproar of the emperor; din of the wheel-turning monarch
cakkavattikolāhalanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'cakkavattī' (emperor, wheel-turner) with 'kolāhala' (neuter sense of uproar or noisy crowd), likely functioning as an appositive or explanatory term in a quotative construction ending in 'anti' (instrumental plural of 'iti'), meaning 'the uproar called that of the emperor' or similar, indicating a specific type of commotion associated with imperial presence.

kappuṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: proper effort; suitable exertion; appropriate initiative
kappuṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'kappa' (suitable, fitting) modifies 'uṭṭhāna' (effort, rising). In the absence of context sentences, the meaning is inferred as 'suitable effort' or 'proper exertion', common in Buddhist texts for diligent practice aligned with doctrine.

lokabyūhā.meaning_2: array of the world; worldly formation; cosmic arrangement
lokabyūhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] As a compound, lokabyūhā likely refers to a structured or manifested aspect of the world, possibly in a military, cosmological, or experiential sense, combining 'world' with 'array/formation'.

kāmāvacaradevā.meaning_2: deities of the sense-desire realm; gods belonging to the kāma world
kāmāvacaradevā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where kāmāvacara (adj, 'belonging to the realm of sense desire') qualifies deva ('deity'). The form kāmāvacaradevā is nominative plural, referring to gods in the sensuous heavens in Buddhist cosmology.

muttasirā.meaning_2: one freed from the head; beheaded
muttasirā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form muttasirā appears to be a compound of the past participle muttā ('released, freed') and sirā ('head'), likely in the sense of decapitation or being freed from the head, common in Pāḷi texts for describing execution or ascetic practices involving self-harm. The long ā ending suggests feminine nominative singular.

rudamukhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound rudamukha combines the present participle rudanta ('crying, weeping') with mukha ('face'), indicating a face marked by tears, often in contexts of sorrow or lamentation.

rattavatthanivatthā.meaning_2: clothed in a red garment; dressed in crimson cloth
rattavatthanivatthā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound functioning as a feminine adjective or noun, likely referring to a female figure dressed in a red robe, common in Pāḷi descriptions of divine or royal attire. The form suggests nominative singular feminine, with sandhi resolving between components.

virūpavesadhārino.meaning_2: wearing deformed or ugly disguises or appearances
virūpavesadhārino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective in the nominative masculine plural form, likely referring to beings or figures adopting unsightly or monstrous disguises, common in narrative contexts involving deception or supernatural elements in Pāḷi literature.

lokavināso.meaning_2: destruction of the world; ruin of the universe
lokavināso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound lokavināso combines 'loka' (world, universe) with 'vināsa' (destruction), indicating the catastrophic end or ruin of the world, a concept often discussed in Buddhist cosmology regarding the periodic dissolution of the cosmos.

sabbaññubuddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound epithet in vocative singular form, commonly used to address the Buddha as the all-knowing enlightened one. The first member sabbaññū is an adjective used substantively, combined with buddha, resulting in a masculine noun.

lokapāladevatā.meaning_2: deity who is a guardian of the world
lokapāladevatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where devatā is qualified by lokapāla, indicating a deity that serves as a world-protector. The form appears to be nominative singular, though no contextual sentence is provided to confirm usage.

ugghosentā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ugghosentā is the feminine nominative singular present participle of the causative verb ugghoseti, indicating a female subject who is shouting or proclaiming something.

ugghosentiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ugghosentiyo appears to be a 3rd person plural present indicative of ugghoseti, with -iyo likely a scribal or dialectal variant of the standard -anti ending. The -ti at the end may be an erroneous addition or sandhi influence.

cakkavattikolāhalaṃ.meaning_2: uproar of the emperor; noise of the sovereign; pandemonium caused by the wheel-turner
cakkavattikolāhalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'cakkavattī' (emperor) with 'kolāhala' (uproar or noisy crowd), likely in accusative singular form to denote the object of the uproar or the uproar associated with the emperor. Without the full sentence context, the exact usage is inferred from the components.

buddhakolāhalasaddaṃ.meaning_1: announcement about coming of a Buddha
buddhakolāhalasaddaṃ.meaning_2: sound of the announcement about the coming of a Buddha; noise proclaiming the Buddha's arrival
buddhakolāhalasaddaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular, likely functioning as the object of a verb implying hearing or producing the sound in the context of Buddhist narrative.

ekekacakkavāḷe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound 'ekekacakkavāḷa', meaning 'in each and every world system'. The first member 'ekeka' denotes individuality or each one, and 'cakkavāḷa' refers to a world system or universe. Used contextually to indicate separation across multiple cosmological realms.

catumahārājasakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmit.meaning_2: by the four great kings, Sakka, Suyāma, Santusita, Sunimmita, Vasavatti and Mahābrahmā
catumahārājasakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmit.family_compound: catu mahārāja sakka suyāma santusita sunimmita vasavattī mahābrahma
catumahārājasakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmit.construction: catu + mahā + rāja + sakka + su + yāma + santusita + su + nimmita + vasa + vattī + mahā + brahma + hi
catumahārājasakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmit.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a dvanda compound listing six deities: the four great kings (cātumahārājāno), Sakka (king of the devas), Suyāma (Yāma heaven lord), Santusita (Tusita heaven lord), Sunimmita (Nimmānarati heaven lord), Vasavatti (Paranimmitavasavatti heaven lord), and Mahābrahmā (great Brahma). This sequence reflects the cosmological order of Buddhist heavens, from the sensuous realm to the form realm.

ekacakkavāḷe.meaning_2: a single world system; one universe
ekacakkavāḷe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of the compound 'ekacakkavāḷa', meaning 'in one world system'. The compound combines 'eka' (one, single) with 'cakkavāḷa' (world system, universe), indicating a singular cosmological unit in Buddhist context.

sakkasampattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the accusative singular of the compound sakkasampatti, where sakka functions as a noun derived from the root √sak (referring to ability or proficiency) combined with sampatti (prosperity, achievement). In context, it likely denotes 'capability' or 'proficiency' as an object of a verb.

mārasampattiṃ.meaning_2: prosperity of death; welfare of Death; good fortune pertaining to Māra
mārasampattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound 'mārasampatti', meaning 'the prosperity or success associated with death or Māra (the personified tempter in Buddhism). Without a specific sentence context, the interpretation aligns with the core senses of the components: māra as 'death' or 'Māra', and sampatti as 'prosperity' or 'attainment'.

brahmasampattiṃ.meaning_2: attainment of Brahman; prosperity of the divine; spiritual success
brahmasampattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'brahma' (Brahman or divine) with 'sampatti' (attainment or prosperity), likely referring to spiritual or divine achievement in a Buddhist or Brahmanical context.

cakkavattisampattiṃ.meaning_2: prosperity of the wheel-turning monarch; welfare of the universal emperor
cakkavattisampattiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, used as the object in the sentence. The first member 'cakkavattī' specifies the type of prosperity associated with an ideal sovereign ruler in Buddhist cosmology.

lokanittharaṇatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of crossing the world; for the purpose of getting across the world
lokanittharaṇatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial compound indicates purpose, likely in a soteriological context referring to liberation from the cycle of rebirth in the world.

kāladīpadesakulajanettiāyuparicchedavase.meaning_2: according to the determination of lifespan of the mother of the family belonging to the foot-place of the lamp of time
kāladīpadesakulajanettiāyuparicchedavase.family_compound: kāla dīpa desa kula janettī āyu pariccheda vasa
kāladīpadesakulajanettiāyuparicchedavase.construction: kāla + dīpa + desa + sa + kula + janettī + āyu + pariccheda + vasa + ena
kāladīpadesakulajanettiāyuparicchedavase.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex bahuvrīhi compound serving as an instrumental adverb indicating the basis or criterion ('according to') for some determination or classification. The core structure builds on 'āyuparicchedavasena' ('by the determination of lifespan'), qualified by 'kāladīpadesakulajanetti' ('of the mother of the family belonging to the foot-place of the lamp of time'). 'Kāladīpadesa' likely refers to a specific doctrinal or cosmological location or context where time is illuminated like a lamp's base, possibly alluding to temporal or karmic factors in lifespan determination in Buddhist texts.

vaḍḍhitaāyukālo.meaning_2: time of increased life; period of prolonged lifespan
vaḍḍhitaāyukālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely refers to a time or period characterized by an extended or increased lifespan, possibly in a cosmological or soteriological context where virtuous actions lead to longer life.

tilakkhaṇamuttā.meaning_2: freed from the three characteristics (of impermanence, suffering, and non-self)
tilakkhaṇamuttā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound tilakkhaṇamuttā describes a state of liberation from the three marks of existence (anicca, dukkha, anattā), common in Buddhist texts to denote enlightenment or nirvana. The form is feminine nominative singular, likely referring to a nun or abstract feminine concept.

ūnaāyukālopi.meaning_2: even at a time deficient in life; even in a period of shortened lifespan
ūnaāyukālopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound combining 'ūna' (deficient), 'āyu' (life), 'kāla' (time), and 'api' (even). The form suggests a descriptive phrase meaning 'even at a time when life is deficient,' possibly referring to old age or a shortened lifespan in a contextual sentence about life's duration or mortality.

ussannakilesā.meaning_2: one with abundant defilements; one afflicted by copious impurities
ussannakilesā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a masculine noun, likely in instrumental singular form in the text, describing someone overwhelmed by excessive unwholesome mental states.

ussannakilesānañca.meaning_2: abundant defilements; plentiful impurities; copious unwholesome mental states
ussannakilesānañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective used as a substantive, describing defilements that are excessive or abundant, likely in the context of overcoming or being burdened by plentiful impurities in a doctrinal or soteriological sentence.

ovādaṭṭhāne.meaning_1: place of advice; place of instruction
ovādaṭṭhāne.meaning_2: place for giving advice; instructional setting; exhortation context
ovādaṭṭhāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ovādaṭṭhāne is the locative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound ovāḍaṭṭhāna, indicating 'in the place of advice'. The gemination of ṭṭ arises from sandhi between ovāda and ṭhāna. This term likely refers to a physical or situational context suitable for providing moral or doctrinal instruction in Buddhist texts.

āyukālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from āyu 'life' and kāla 'time', indicating the duration or period of one's life. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning inferred from components.

vassasatakālo.meaning_2: century-time; time of a century; period of one hundred years
vassasatakālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound vassasatakālo combines 'vassasata' (century) with 'kālo' (time), indicating a duration of one hundred years. Likely appears in contexts discussing long-term periods, such as in historical or cosmological texts.

nibbattitabbakāloti.meaning_2: time when birth should take place; appropriate time for arising or production
nibbattitabbakāloti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'nibbattitabba' (gerundive 'that which should be produced or born') modifies 'kālo' (time), indicating the suitable moment for birth or becoming in a doctrinal context, likely related to rebirth or origination in Buddhist texts.

dasayojanasahassaparimāṇo.meaning_2: measuring ten thousand yojanas; comprising a distance of ten thousand yojanas
dasayojanasahassaparimāṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective quantifying an extent or size as ten thousand yojanas (approximately 160,000 km), likely used in a cosmological or geographical context in Pāli texts to denote a vast measurement.

pubbadakkhiṇāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed by 'pubba' (eastern) + 'dakkhiṇā' (southern direction), indicating the southeast direction; the instrumental case suggests 'towards the southeast' or 'in the southeast' depending on context.

khattiyabrāhmaṇagahapatimahāsālā.meaning_2: nobleman; priest; wealthy householder; rich businessman
khattiyabrāhmaṇagahapatimahāsālā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound enumerating the four classes of people: nobles, priests, householders, and those with great halls (wealthy merchants). It likely appears in a context listing or addressing these social groups, such as in a sutta discussing duties or assemblies.

idañcettha.meaning_2: here and now; in this case and this place
idañcettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a fused adverbial expression combining 'idaṃ' (here, in this case), 'ce' (if, but), and 'ettha' (here, in this place), likely used in conditional or locative contexts to emphasize immediacy or specificity in the present situation.

nibbattitabbanti.meaning_2: to be produced; to be brought into being; to be originated
nibbattitabbanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nibbattitabbanti appears to be a locative or adverbial extension of nibbattitabba, possibly with -nti as an indeclinable ending indicating manner or purpose ('in the manner of being produced'), though no sentences are provided for full contextual analysis. It expresses something that ought or is destined to arise or come into existence, often in philosophical contexts like dependent origination.

lokasammate.meaning_1: considered (as) the world; deemed (to be) the world; regarded as the world; agreed to be the world
lokasammate.meaning_2: world that is thought together; world agreed upon
lokasammate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'loka' (world) is qualified by the past participle 'sammata' (considered, agreed upon). The locative singular ending *-e indicates 'in the world that is considered/agreed upon'. In Buddhist contexts, it often refers to the conventional world or the world as commonly accepted by people.

brāhmaṇakulevāti.meaning_2: only in a Brahman family, thus
brāhmaṇakulevāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This form appears to be a sandhi-affected indeclinable adverbial phrase combining the locative singular of 'brāhmaṇakula' (in a Brahman family) with 'eva' (only, indeed) and 'iti' (thus), likely used to quote or emphasize a specific statement like 'only in a Brahman family, thus'.

lokasammataṃ.meaning_2: regarded by the world; approved by people
lokasammataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective agreeing with a neuter noun in accusative singular, indicating something considered or approved by the world or people.

buddhamātā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'buddha' (genitive sense) qualifies 'mātā' (mother), indicating the mother of the Buddha. In Pāḷi texts, it often refers to Mahāmāyā, the mother of Gotama Buddha.

pūritapāramī.meaning_2: perfection of fulfilment; completed transcendental virtue
pūritapāramī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pūrita' (fulfilled, pp of pūreti) modifies 'pāramī' (perfection). It likely refers to the Buddhist concept of a pāramī (perfection) that has been fulfilled or completed, as in the ten perfections in Theravāda tradition. No specific sentence provided, but contextually it denotes an ultimate state of spiritual completion.

tusitadevatāhi.meaning_2: name of a group of deities; from Tusita heaven; lit. contented
tusitadevatāhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tusitadevatāhi appears to be a sandhi compound of tusitā (masc pl 'Tusita deities') and devatāhi (fem instr pl 'with the deities'), resulting in an instrumental plural form meaning 'with the Tusita deities'. The exact sandhi resolution may involve elision or vowel adjustment typical in Pāli compounds.

sabbadevalokesu.meaning_2: in all heavenly realms; in every world of gods
sabbadevalokesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative plural form of a compound pronoun 'sabba-devaloka', meaning 'all heavenly worlds', used to indicate location in all divine realms. The form -esu is the locative plural ending for masculine/neuter pronouns derived from ka-stems.

katakusalakammokāsaṃ.meaning_2: opportunity for wholesome action; space for meritorious deed
katakusalakammokāsaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an inflected accusative singular form of a compound noun, likely in a context referring to an opportunity or permission to perform wholesome or meritorious actions, as in legal or monastic procedures.

ayamanupubbikathā.meaning_2: talk on this [topic] that develops progressively; systematic discourse on this
ayamanupubbikathā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'aya' (this) modifies 'anupubbikathā' (graduated talk), specifying the topic of the progressive discourse. In Buddhist contexts, it often refers to the preliminary, sequential teaching before deeper doctrines like the four noble truths.

kapilavatthunagare.meaning_1: name of the capital city of the Sakyans
kapilavatthunagare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is the locative singular form of the compound 'kapilavatthu-nagara', meaning 'in the city of Kapilavatthu', referring to the location of an event involving the Buddha's return to his hometown.

āsāḷhinakkhattaṃ.meaning_1: full-moon day in the month āsāḷha
āsāḷhinakkhattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form āsāḷhinakkhattaṃ is the accusative singular of the compound noun, referring to the full-moon constellation or lunar mansion associated with the āsāḷha month in the Pāḷi calendar. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning based on dictionary entries.

sattamadivasato.grammar: ind, adv, masc abl sg of sattamadīvasa
sattamadivasato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sattamadīvasato is a sandhi compound where 'dī' is a contracted form of 'diva' (day) before 'vasa'. It functions adverbially to indicate 'from the seventh day', likely in a temporal sense referring to the start of a period or event.

vigatasurāpānaṃ.meaning_2: free from drinking liquor; devoid of strong drink
vigatasurāpānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vigata (pp of vigacchati, 'free from') modifies surāpāna ('drinking liquor'). The accusative singular form suggests use as an object or postposition, e.g., 'free from the drinking of liquor' in a monastic context prohibiting alcohol.

mālāgandhavibhūtisampannaṃ.meaning_2: endowed with garlands, fragrance, and splendour; adorned with wreaths, scents, and magnificence
mālāgandhavibhūtisampannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound describing something (likely neuter singular accusative) fully equipped or adorned with three qualities: garlands (mālā), fragrance (gandha), and splendour (vibhūti), as per the past participle sampanna meaning 'endowed with'.

sattayojanikassa.meaning_2: of seven yojanas (in length); of about 140 kilometres
sattayojanikassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the genitive singular masculine of the compound adjective sattayojanika, meaning 'of seven yojanas'. A yojana is approximately 20 km, so it denotes a distance of about 140 km. Used to describe something extending or measuring that length.

manussamalaharaṇatthaṃ.meaning_2: for the purpose of removing the impurity of humans; for the sake of cleansing human defilement
manussamalaharaṇatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound used adverbially to indicate purpose, common in Pāḷi for expressing 'for the sake of'. The final atthaṃ governs the overall meaning of intent for removal of human impurities, likely in a soteriological or ethical context such as purification from moral stains.

dibbavatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dibbavatthaṃ is the accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound dibbavattha, combining the adjective dibba (divine) with the noun vattha (cloth, robe). In Pāli texts, especially the Vinaya, it refers to a celestial or divine garment, often in contexts of heavenly attire or miraculous robes.

dibbapupphāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in accusative plural form, likely referring to divine or heavenly flowers in a context of celestial beauty or offerings.

rajatapabbato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'rajata' (silver) qualifies 'pabbata' (mountain), likely a proper name referring to a specific silvery or silver-associated mountain in the context of Pāḷi literature.

pācīnasīsakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an accusative singular neuter form of a compound adjective used nominally, likely referring to a headless entity or object in the eastern direction. The exact contextual meaning depends on the missing sentence, but it fits descriptive compounds in Pāḷi texts, possibly in geographical or symbolic descriptions.

dibbasayanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound noun 'dibbasayana', likely referring to a celestial or divine resting place in a religious or narrative context.

nipajjāpesuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nipajjāpesuṃ is a 3rd plural aorist of the causative verb nipajjāpeti ('caused to lie down'), indicating that they caused others to lie down or rest. The āpe- element shows the causative formation from nipajjati. No contextual sentences provided to specify exact usage.

setavaravāraṇo.meaning_2: elephant that is the best among white ones
setavaravāraṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely descriptive of a white elephant with excellent qualities; 'vara' as 'best' modifies the type of elephant, with 'seta' specifying color and 'vāraṇa' the base noun meaning elephant.

rajatapabbataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'rajata' (silver) qualifies 'pabbata' (mountain), in accusative singular neuter, likely referring to a proper name of a place or mythical mountain in Pāḷi literature.

rajatadāmavaṇṇāya.meaning_2: having the colour of a silver garland; silvery garland-like in appearance
rajatadāmavaṇṇāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular masculine or neuter form used as adjective, likely describing something with a lustrous, silver-wreath-like hue, possibly in a poetic or descriptive context.

setapadumaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound of 'seta' (white, from √sit) and 'paduma' (lotus); accusative singular form indicates object usage in context, likely referring to a pure or white lotus flower.

mātusayanaṃ.meaning_2: mother's bed; bed of the mother
mātusayanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where mātu (genitive of mātar 'mother') qualifies sayana ('bed, couch'), indicating the bed belonging to the mother. The form mātusayanaṃ is the accusative singular neuter.

dakkhiṇapassaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'dakkhiṇa' (southern or right) qualifies 'passa' (side), commonly used in directional contexts to denote the southern direction or the right-hand side.

paviṭṭhasadiso.meaning_2: similar to one who has entered; resembling an entrant
paviṭṭhasadiso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective formed from the past participle paviṭṭha ('entered') and sadisa ('similar to'), functioning as a descriptive term for something like an entered or immersed state, possibly in a meditative or narrative context.

uttarāsāḷhanakkhattena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound referring to a specific northern asterism or zodiacal constellation associated with the lunar month Āsāḷha (June-July), likely in an astrological or calendrical context.

catusaṭṭhimatte.meaning_2: consisting of sixty-four; amounting to sixty-four
catusaṭṭhimatte.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective used substantively as a feminine noun, likely referring to a group or collection of sixty-four items, such as the sixty-four arts (catusaṭṭhi-kala) in traditional contexts. The locative form 'catusaṭṭhimatte' suggests 'in the sixty-four' or 'among the sixty-four'.

brāhmaṇapāmokkhe.meaning_2: Brahman chief; foremost Brahman; eminent priest
brāhmaṇapāmokkhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'brāhmaṇa' (Brahman or priest) with 'pāmokkha' (chief, foremost). The form 'brāhmaṇapāmokkhe' is locative singular, likely indicating 'in the case of the Brahman chief' or 'among the foremost Brahmans', possibly referring to a specific context or title in Pāḷi texts.

gomayaharitūpalittāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a complex feminine ablative singular compound: 'to that which is smeared with green cowdung' or similar, likely describing a surface or object coated with fresh cowdung paste, common in traditional contexts for purification or marking.

lājādīhi.meaning_2: with things beginning with fried grain; with parched corn etc.
lājādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound lājādī, used to indicate 'with fried grain and the like' in lists of items, common in Pāḷi for denoting categories starting with a specified item.

katamaṅgalasakkārāya.meaning_2: honour for which auspicious occasion; respect for festive event
katamaṅgalasakkārāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound appears to refer to honour or respect associated with a particular auspicious or festive occasion, likely in a ceremonial context. The dative ending -āya indicates 'for' or 'to' such an honour.

sappimadhusakkharābhisaṅkhatassa.meaning_2: of that which is made of ghee, honey and sugar
sappimadhusakkharābhisaṅkhatassa.construction: sappi + madhu + sakkharā + abhi saṃ √kar > khar + ta + assa
sappimadhusakkharābhisaṅkhatassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where the final member 'abhisaṅkhatassa' (genitive singular masculine or neuter of abhisaṅkhata) qualifies the preceding items, indicating something prepared or fabricated from ghee, honey, and sugar. Likely from a Vinaya context describing a type of confection or offering.

varapāyāsassa.meaning_2: of the excellent milk rice pudding
