bodhipallaṅkaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound. In Buddhist context, it specifically denotes the throne or seat of enlightenment at Bodhgaya, symbolizing the Buddha's awakening.

ugghosayuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Appears to be an aorist form of udghaṃsati 'to announce, proclaim', with sandhi resolution of ug + ghosayuṃ. The -yuṃ ending indicates 3rd plural aorist, common in early Pāli texts for past actions.

nāgagaṇā.meaning_2: group of nāgas; assembly of serpents; multitude of dragons
nāgagaṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nāgagaṇā is the feminine instrumental singular of the compound nāgagaṇa, likely referring to 'by the group of nāgas' in a context involving mythical serpents or a collective of noble beings, depending on the specific sense of nāga employed.

supaṇṇasaṅghāpi.meaning_2: community of supaṇṇas; fellowship of supernatural birds
supaṇṇasaṅghāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be an inflected form (likely nominative singular) of the compound supaṇṇasaṅgha, referring to the collective or community of supaṇṇas, mythical bird-like beings. The 'api' suggests emphasis or inclusion, such as 'even the supaṇṇas' community' in a broader context.

brahmagaṇāpi.meaning_2: even the brahmin group; even the religious order of brahmins
brahmagaṇāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form where 'brahmagaṇa' (brahma + gaṇa, masculine, meaning a group or order of brahmins) is combined with 'api' (indeclinable, here emphatic 'even'). The form suggests an instrumental singular of 'brahmagaṇa' sandhied with 'api', implying 'even by/with the brahmin group' or similar, depending on sentence context.

cīvarūpari.meaning_2: on the robe; upon the robe-cloth
cīvarūpari.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an indeclinable preposition, indicating location 'on the robe'. The first member 'cīvara' is the locative object, combined with the preposition 'upari' meaning 'above' or 'on top of'.

bodhirukkhaṅkurehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form bodhirukkhaṅkurehi indicates 'with sprouts of the Bodhi tree'; the compound combines the Bodhi tree with its sprouts, common in contexts describing sacred or natural elements in Buddhist texts.

rattapavāḷapallavehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of a descriptive compound where 'ratta' (red) modifies 'pavāḷa' (coral), and the whole qualifies 'pallava' (sprouts), likely referring to red coral-like shoots or buds in a poetic or metaphorical context.

paṭhamayāme.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound refers to the initial three-hour period of the night, commonly used in Buddhist texts to describe times for meditation or events.

pacchimayāme.meaning_2: in the last watch of the night
pacchimayāme.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative form of the compound pacchimayāma, referring to the final watch of the night (approximately 2-5 AM), commonly used in Pāḷi texts for the time when the Buddha would arise and contemplate.

dvādasapadikaṃ.meaning_2: twelve-versed; consisting of twelve lines of verse
dvādasapadikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective formed from the cardinal number 'dvādasa' (twelve) and 'padika' (having lines of verse), likely describing a text or hymn with twelve verses. The form is accusative singular neuter, agreeing with a neuter noun in context.

vaṭṭavivaṭṭavasena.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, instr sg of vaṭṭavivaṭṭavasa
vaṭṭavivaṭṭavasena.meaning_2: according to the round of existence and its cessation; by means of the cycle and its stopping
vaṭṭavivaṭṭavasena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial instrumental form of a compound noun vaṭṭavivaṭṭavasa, likely meaning 'the power or mode of the cycle and its cessation'. In Buddhist contexts, it may refer to the dynamic of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa, used adverbially to indicate manner or according to that principle.

anulomapaṭilomato.meaning_2: in conformity and reverse; forward and backward
anulomapaṭilomato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound of anuloma ('conforming, forward') and paṭiloma ('reverse, contrary'), with the instrumental plural ending -hi sandhied to -o, meaning 'in forward and reverse directions' or 'both ways', often used in contexts like breath or recitation.

dvādasakkhattuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound noun dvādasakkhattu, denoting the number of times an action is performed, commonly used in enumerative contexts in Pāḷi texts.

aruṇuggamanavelāya.meaning_1: at the time of dawn; at the time of sunrise
aruṇuggamanavelāya.meaning_2: at the time of the arising of red light
aruṇuggamanavelāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound is a locative singular form used to indicate the time of dawn, combining the concept of the rising of red light (dawn) with 'time' or 'point in time'. In context, it denotes the period at sunrise.

pācīnacakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ.meaning_2: rim of the eastern side of the world-system
pācīnacakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an inflected form in accusative singular of a complex compound describing a cosmological or architectural feature, likely the 'eastern rim' of the universe in Buddhist texts.

pacchimacakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound referring to the outer edge or boundary on the western side of the cakkavāḷa (world-system), likely in a cosmological context; the ending -yaṃ indicates accusative singular, possibly as the object of a verb in the missing sentence.

dakkhiṇacakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ.meaning_2: southern rim of the world system
dakkhiṇacakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an inflected form (accusative singular neuter) of a tatpuruṣa compound referring to the southern edge or lip of the cosmological world-system, likely in a directional or geographical context.

uttaracakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ.meaning_2: rim of the northern face of the world-system
uttaracakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound referring to the northern rim or edge of a cakkavāḷa (world-system), possibly in a cosmological context; the ending -yaṃ indicates accusative singular, likely the object of a verb like 'reaches' or 'touches' in the original sentence.

pathavitale.meaning_2: on the surface of the earth; on the ground
pathavitale.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'in/on the flat surface of the earth', combining pathavī (earth) with tala (flat surface, ground). The -e ending indicates locative case, suggesting position 'on the ground' or 'on the earth's surface' in context.

dasasahassacakkavāḷesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'dasasahassacakkavāḷa' meaning 'world system of ten thousand', denoting location in multiple such systems, common in Buddhist cosmology for describing the extent of a Buddha's influence or enlightenment.

pupphūpagarukkhā.meaning_2: tree approaching flowers; tree going towards flowers
pupphūpagarukkhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'upaga' functions as an adjective 'approaching' modifying 'puppha' (flowers), and the whole 'pupphūpaga' then compounds with 'rukkha' (tree), likely describing a tree that approaches or grows towards flowers. The form 'pupphūpagarukkhā' appears to be a feminine instrumental singular, possibly agreeing with an unprovided noun in the original sentence.

phalūpagarukkhā.meaning_2: tree that has approached its fruit; tree that is fruit-bearing; tree that is nearing fruition
phalūpagarukkhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'phalūpaga' (fruit-approaching or fruit-bearing) qualifies 'rukkha' (tree). The form 'phalūpagarukkhā' appears to be an instrumental singular, likely used in a context describing a tree in relation to its fruit or a metaphorical sense of consequence-bearing entity.

phalapiṇḍībhārabharitā.meaning_2: filled with the weight of fruit clusters
phalapiṇḍībhārabharitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective, likely modifying a feminine noun such as a tree or branch, indicating it is laden with heavy fruit bunches. The final element bharita functions adjectivally within the compound.

daṇḍakapadumāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is nominative plural of a neuter compound noun, combining 'daṇḍaka' (small stick, stalk) and 'paduma' (lotus), likely referring to lotus stalks or stems in a descriptive context.

vissaṭṭhamālāguḷā.meaning_2: garland that has been let loose; released wreath of flowers
vissaṭṭhamālāguḷā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines the past participle vissaṭṭha ('let loose, released') with mālāguḷa ('garland, wreath'), likely describing a garland that has been removed or set free, perhaps in a ritual or narrative context involving release of adornments.

susanthatapupphasanthāro.meaning_2: a welcome or reception with a well-spread flower-carpet; a hospitable spreading of flowers on a coverlet
susanthatapupphasanthāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (karmadhāraya) where 'susanthata' modifies 'puppha', describing a well-spread flower arrangement, and the whole serves as the object or manner of 'santhāra' (spreading/welcome). In context, it likely refers to a luxurious or hospitable floral bedding or carpet spread.

cakkavāḷantaresu.meaning_2: in other world systems; in other solar systems
cakkavāḷantaresu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative plural form of the compound adjective cakkavāḷantara, meaning 'other world systems'. It refers to world systems beyond one's own, commonly used in cosmological contexts to denote multiple universes or solar systems in Buddhist literature.

aṭṭhayojanasahassalokantarikā.meaning_2: eight-thousand-yojana world-interval; situated between worlds at a distance of eight thousand yojanas; approximately 160,000 kilometres
aṭṭhayojanasahassalokantarikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound used as a feminine adjective or noun, likely referring to a vast spatial interval between worlds in cosmological contexts, such as in Buddhist texts describing the distance between world-systems.

sattasūriyappabhāyapi.meaning_2: even by the light of the seven suns
sattasūriyappabhāyapi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form where 'sattasūriyappabhāya' (instrumental singular of the compound sattasūriyappabhā, 'of the light of the seven suns') combines with the indeclinable api ('even'). The compound sattasūriyappabhā means 'the light of seven suns', likely metaphorical for intense brightness. Without the full sentence, the contextual usage is inferred from the dictionary entries as an adverbial phrase indicating comparison or emphasis on luminosity.

anobhāsitapubbā.meaning_2: not previously illuminated; not formerly radiated upon
anobhāsitapubbā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in feminine form, likely agreeing with a feminine noun in the sentence. The prefix 'a-' negates 'obhāsita' (shone upon, pp of obhāseti), and 'pubbā' indicates 'previously.' Thus, it describes something not illuminated or revealed before, common in doctrinal contexts for novel teachings.

ekobhāsā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'eka' (one) modifies 'bhāsā' (language), likely referring to a unique or singular form of speech or dialect in context.

caturāsītiyojanasahassagambhīro.meaning_2: eighty-four-thousand-yojana-deep; profoundly deep, measuring eighty-four thousand yojanas in depth
caturāsītiyojanasahassagambhīro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective, likely modifying a noun such as 'samuddo' (ocean) in a cosmological context, emphasizing immense depth equivalent to 84,000 yojanas (approx. 1,008,000 km).

nappavattiṃsu.meaning_2: did not proceed; did not continue; did not occur; did not manifest
nappavattiṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the 3rd person plural aorist form of nappavattati, indicating a past action that did not happen or continue. The negative prefix 'na' combined with 'pavattati' (from pa + √vatt, 'to proceed') negates the progression or manifestation in the context of the sentence.

jātibadhirā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'jāti' (birth, kind) with 'badhira' (deaf), indicating deafness from birth or innate deafness, as a descriptive feminine noun.

jātipīṭhasappino.meaning_2: crippled by birth; born into a crippled condition
jātipīṭhasappino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in the nominative singular masculine, likely describing a person or being crippled due to their birth or caste status. The form -ino suggests nominative singular, agreeing with a masculine subject in the context.

andubandhanādīni.meaning_2: binding with chains etc.; bondage with manacles and so on
andubandhanādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is an inflected form (nominative/accusative plural) of a compound noun ending in 'ādi', indicating 'beginning with' and listing 'andubandhana' (binding with chains) as the starting example, followed by others in a series. Used to denote various forms of restraint or bondage in a collective sense.

sirivibhavena.meaning_2: by the loss of fortune; by the decline of glory; by the destruction of wealth
sirivibhavena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the tatpuruṣa compound sirivibhava, where sirī (fortune, glory) is qualified by vibhava (power, wealth, or decline). Without context, the positive sense 'by the power of fortune' or negative 'by the loss of fortune' is possible, but vibhava's abstract derivations suggest the latter in many contexts.

tusitapurato.meaning_2: from Tusita heaven; from the city of the satisfied
tusitapurato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tusitapurato is an ablative singular of the compound tusitapura, meaning 'from the Tusita heaven' or 'from the city of Tusita', referring to the heavenly realm where the future Buddha resides.

santikenidānakathā.meaning_2: introduction (to a book); origin story; background narrative
santikenidānakathā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound santikenidānakathā appears to be a sandhi form, likely 'santike nidānakathā', meaning 'introduction in the presence of' or 'nearby origin story', but as per instructions, the lemma is the uninflected compound without sandhi resolution.

udānetvā.meaning_2: having carried out; having taken upwards
udānetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form udānetvā is the absolutive of the causative verb udānayati (to cause to lead or carry up), combining the prefix uda- (upwards) with the root √nī (to lead). It indicates an action completed before the main verb, often implying elevation or removal to a higher place.

jayapallaṅke.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form jayapallaṅke is the locative singular of the compound jayapallaṅka, likely denoting a seat symbolizing victory, as in a king's throne or a position of conquest.

suañjitāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form suañjitāni is a neuter plural nominative or accusative of a compound adjective, with su- as an intensifying prefix meaning 'well' applied to the past participle añjitāni 'anointed things'. The sandhi combination of su + añjitāni results in suañjitāni. In context, it likely refers to objects or substances that have been thoroughly anointed.

jālīkumārasadisā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound adjective where 'sadisa' (resembling) is the final member, qualifying the combined 'jālīkumāra' (likely a proper name, 'Blazing Prince'). The feminine form 'sadisā' indicates agreement with a feminine noun in the original sentence.

kaṇhājinakumārisadisā.meaning_2: resembling Princess Kaṇhājinā; like the daughter of Vessantara
kaṇhājinakumārisadisā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi-like compound adjective meaning 'similar to Kaṇhājinā the princess,' used to describe someone resembling the princess in the Jātaka story of Vessantara.

maddīdevisadisā.meaning_2: unlike the princess goddess; dissimilar to the divine queen
maddīdevisadisā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes something incomparable or peerless in resemblance to the princess Maddī, who is also a divine queen (devī). The negative prefix 'a-' in asadisa emphasizes dissimilarity or matchlessness.

dāsatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of the slave; for the benefit of the servant
dāsatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where dāsa (slave, servant) is combined with atthāya (dative of attha, meaning 'for the sake/benefit/purpose'), indicating purpose or benefit related to a slave. The form dāsatthāya is the dative singular, used to express 'for the slave's sake' or similar instrumental purpose in context.

jayapallaṅko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound where 'jaya' (victory) modifies 'pallaṅka' (throne or seat), likely referring to a throne symbolizing conquest or victory in a royal or ceremonial context.

varapallaṅko.meaning_2: excellent couch; best seat; foremost sofa
varapallaṅko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'vara' (excellent, best) with 'pallaṅka' (couch, seat) to denote a superior or royal seating arrangement, likely in a context of luxury or meditation posture.

anekakoṭisatasahassā.meaning_2: one billion; one trillion (countless hundreds of millions)
anekakoṭisatasahassā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an inflected form (instrumental singular neuter) of a compound numeral indicating an extremely large number, literally 'hundreds of millions times many' or 'countless hundred-millions'. Used to denote vast quantities in Buddhist texts.

kattabbakiccaṃ.meaning_2: duty that should be done; obligation to be performed
kattabbakiccaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining two deverbal nouns from √kar, expressing a duty or obligation that must be carried out. The neuter accusative singular form indicates the object of an action in context.

pallaṅkasmiñhi.meaning_2: in the couch; in the seat; in the sofa; in the cross-legged sitting position; in the meditation posture
pallaṅkasmiñhi.construction: pari > pali > paly > pall + √añc > aṅk + a
pallaṅkasmiñhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pallaṅkasmiṃ is the locative singular of the masculine noun pallaṅka, inflected with the special locative ending -asmiṃ for stems ending in -a. The particle hi ('indeed' or 'because') is not part of the lemma but would appear separately in sentence analysis. Contextually, it likely refers to 'in this couch' or 'in this (meditation) seat,' emphasizing location for an action or state.

vitakkavūpasamanatthaṃ.meaning_2: that which serves the purpose of calming thoughts; that which is for the subsiding of reflections
vitakkavūpasamanatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular neuter form of a tatpuruṣa compound used as an indeclinable adverbial phrase, likely modifying a verb like 'kammaṃ karoti' in a context such as 'vitakkavūpasamanatthaṃ kammaṃ karoti' meaning 'he does an action for the calming of thought'. The final element 'anatthaṃ' is the accusative of 'attha' (purpose, aim), negated in form but here indicating purpose as per standard Pāḷi idiom. The compound breaks down as vitakka (thought) + vūpasama (calming) + attha (for the purpose of).

yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound form of 'yamaka' (pair, twin) and 'pāṭihāriya' (miracle), likely referring to a specific type of paired or twin miracle in Buddhist texts, such as the twin miracle (yamaka pāṭihāriya) performed by the Buddha. The accusative singular ending indicates its role as an object in the sentence.

mahābodhimaṇḍasmiñhi.meaning_2: in this great Bodhi seat; in this seat of great awakening
mahābodhimaṇḍasmiñhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi combination of the locative singular 'mahābodhimaṇḍasmiṃ' (in the great Bodhi seat) and the particle 'hi' (indeed, for). The base compound 'mahābodhimaṇḍa' modifies 'bodhimaṇḍa' (Buddha's seat under the bodhi tree) with 'mahā' (great), emphasizing the sacred site of the Buddha's enlightenment.

katapāṭihāriyañca.meaning_2: and the miracle done; and the performed wonder
katapāṭihāriyañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'kata' (past participle of √kar, 'done') modifies 'pāṭihāriya' (miracle), indicating a miracle that has been performed. The ending 'ñca' reflects sandhi with a preceding word ending in -ṃ, resulting in -ṃca → -ñca.

pāthikaputtasamāgame.meaning_2: in the assembly of the sons of travellers; in the gathering of the naked ascetics
pāthikaputtasamāgame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the compound noun pāthikaputtasamāga, referring to a meeting or assembly associated with the naked ascetics known as Pāthikaputtas. The term combines the name of the ascetic group with samāgama, indicating the context of their gathering.

kaṇḍambarukkhamūle.meaning_2: at the root of the excellent tree trunk
kaṇḍambarukkhamūle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular tatpuruṣa compound: kaṇḍa (stem/trunk) + bara (excellent) + rukkha (tree) + mūla (root). The form shows sandhi with -mūle. Likely from a vinaya or descriptive context referring to the base of a notable tree.

yamakapāṭihāriyasadisaṃ.meaning_2: resembling a twin miracle; like a paired wonder
yamakapāṭihāriyasadisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective in accusative singular neuter, likely modifying a preceding neuter noun in context. It combines 'yamaka' (pair/twin), 'pāṭihāriya' (miracle), and 'sadisa' (similar), suggesting something comparable to a miracle involving duality or pairing, such as the Twin Miracle (Yamakapāṭihāriya) in Buddhist tradition.

pācīnanissite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective used as a noun in the locative case, meaning 'in the eastern direction' or 'on the eastern side'. The first member 'pācīna' indicates 'eastern', and 'nissita' means 'situated in' or 'dependent on', conveying location in the east.

uttaradisābhāge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of the compound uttaradisābhāga, meaning 'in the northern direction', composed of uttara ('northern'), disā ('direction'), and bhāga ('part, quarter').

phalādhigamaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: place of attaining fruit; site of realizing result
phalādhigamaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound breaks down as phala (fruit/result) + adhi (upon/towards) + gama (village) + aṭṭhāna (place); likely denoting a ruined village where spiritual fruition or enlightenment is attained, though exact contextual sentence unavailable.

animisacetiyaṃ.meaning_2: shrine of the unblinking; shrine of the gods
animisacetiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'animisacetiyaṃ' is the accusative singular form of 'animisacetiya', likely referring to a shrine or stupa associated with gods (animisa as 'unblinking ones' metaphorically denoting deities). The context of sentences is empty, but in Pāḷi literature, such terms often denote sacred sites linked to divine or unblinking entities.

puratthimapacchimato.meaning_2: from east to west; from front to back
puratthimapacchimato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of a compound adjective puratthimapacchima, likely neuter to agree with an implied nt noun like disā (direction). It denotes spatial extent from the eastern/front side to the western/back side, common in Pāli for describing breadth or universality.

ratanacaṅkame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ratana (jewel) qualifies caṅkama (walking path), likely referring to a path paved with or adorned by jewels in a monastic or royal context.

ratanacaṅkamacetiyaṃ.meaning_2: Jewel Walk Stupa; shrine named after the jeweled walking meditation path
ratanacaṅkamacetiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a proper name for a specific stupa or shrine, likely associated with a path for walking meditation adorned with jewels or named 'Ratanacaṅkama'.

pacchimuttaradisābhāge.meaning_2: the part of the western and northern direction; the northwestern quarter
pacchimuttaradisābhāge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound describing a directional region, likely in a geographical or cosmological context such as a monastery layout or map division in Pāli texts.

ratanagharaṃ.meaning_2: jewel house; house of treasures; treasury
ratanagharaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ratanagharaṃ is the accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound ratanaghara, where ratana (nt, 'jewel; treasure') qualifies ghara (nt, 'house'), likely denoting a building housing jewels or treasures. Used in accusative case, it functions as the direct object in the sentence.

māpayiṃsu.meaning_2: makes; builds; constructs; lit. causes to measure
māpayiṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form māpayiṃsu is the 3rd person plural aorist of the causative verb māpayati, indicating 'they caused to measure/made/built'. Without the sentence context, the specific usage cannot be detailed further.

anantanayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound 'anantanaya', where 'ananta' (infinite) qualifies 'naya' (method). The form 'anantanayaṃ' suggests use as a direct object in a sentence, likely referring to an infinite or boundless mode of analysis or inference in a philosophical or grammatical context.

samantapaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'samanta' (all; surrounding) modifies 'paṭṭhāna' (foundation; establishing), likely referring to a comprehensive or universal basis in doctrinal contexts such as meditation or Abhidhamma analysis. The accusative singular form suggests it functions as a direct object in the original sentence.

sattaratanamayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is nominative singular neuter, agreeing with an implied neuter noun like 'vihāraṃ'. The compound combines 'sattaratana' (seven treasures) with 'maya' (made of), indicating material composition typical in descriptions of opulent structures or objects in Pāli texts.

sammasitaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun meaning 'the place or basis of right understanding' or 'the object of right view,' commonly used in Buddhist contexts to refer to the four foundations of mindfulness (satipaṭṭhāna) where 'sammasita' relates to correct perception.

ratanagharanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ratanagharanti is the nominative singular neuter of the tatpuruṣa compound ratanaghara, with the indeclinable iti appended, functioning adverbially as 'as the jewel-house' or 'in the manner of the house of jewels'. In Pāli, such constructions with iti often denote simile or manner.

ubhayampetaṃ.meaning_2: both this too; this as well
ubhayampetaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound formed by the adverbial accusative 'ubhayaṃ' (also, as well), the emphatic particle 'api' (too, also), and the accusative pronoun 'etaṃ' (this). In context, it likely functions as an adverbial phrase emphasizing 'this as well' or 'both this,' referring to two things inclusively.

ratanagharacetiyaṃ.meaning_2: shrine housing a jewel; jeweled-house pagoda
ratanagharacetiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'ghara' functions adjectivally as 'housing' or 'containing', describing a cetiya (shrine) that houses a ratana (jewel). The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the direct object in the sentence.

bodhisamīpeyeva.grammar: sandhi, fem + ind, prep + ind, emph
bodhisamīpeyeva.meaning_2: right near the place of awakening; just close to the Bodhi tree
bodhisamīpeyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by the locative singular of 'bodhi' (referring to the site of the Buddha's enlightenment, sense 2) + 'samīpe' (near to) + emphatic particle 'eva' (just, only). It likely describes a location immediately adjacent to the Bodhi tree or enlightenment site in the narrative context.

paṭisaṃvedento.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form paṭisaṃvedento is the present active participle nominative masculine singular of paṭisaṃvedeti, often used to describe one who is experiencing or feeling something directly, such as sensations or results in a Buddhist context.

atikkantodāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form atikkantodāni results from sandhi combining the past participle atikkanta ('having exceeded' or 'having surpassed') with the adverb dāni ('now'), likely in a locative or adverbial sense, though no sentences are provided for precise contextual usage.

domanassappatto.meaning_2: afflicted with distress; overcome by unhappiness; reached a state of dejection
domanassappatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form domanassappatto is a compound past participle where domanassa (neuter noun meaning 'distress') acts as the object of the prefixed verb pa-√ap ('to reach'), indicating a state of having attained or being affected by mental suffering. In context, it describes someone in a condition of emotional distress or depression.

kaḍḍhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a nominal derivative indicating a boundary or limit, common in technical contexts like Vinaya for delineating areas.

indriyaparopariyattañāṇassa.meaning_2: superior or inferior state of the faculties (of); good or bad mental condition
indriyaparopariyattañāṇassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form indicating 'of the knowledge of the superior or inferior state of the faculties'. The compound combines 'indriyaparopariyatta' (condition of faculties) with 'ñāṇa' (knowledge), denoting insight into mental faculties' states.

upanissayabhūtā.meaning_2: having become a supporting condition; being a decisive support
upanissayabhūtā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Feminine nominative singular form of the past participle in composition, indicating something that has become or exists as a supporting condition (upanissaya), a key term in Buddhist conditionality referring to a predominant or decisive supporting factor.

āsayānusayañāṇassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'knowledge of the underlying tendencies in dispositions' or 'insight into latent biases,' likely a technical term in Buddhist psychology referring to the understanding of how propensities reside in one's mental inclinations.

mahākaruṇāsamāpattiñāṇassa.meaning_2: knowledge of attainment of great compassion; insight into meditative attainment of great compassion
mahākaruṇāsamāpattiñāṇassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ñāṇa (knowledge/insight) is qualified by mahākaruṇāsamāpatti (attainment of great compassion), likely referring to the meditative or soteriological insight into boundless compassion in Buddhist contexts, such as the fourth brahmavihāra.

yamakapāṭihīrañāṇassa.meaning_2: knowledge of paired miracles; insight into twin wonders
yamakapāṭihīrañāṇassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'yamaka' (pair, twin) modifies 'pāṭihīra' (miracle), and the whole forms a bahuvrīhi with 'ñāṇa' (knowledge), indicating knowledge concerning paired or twin miracles, likely in a doctrinal context such as the Yamaka of Abhidhamma dealing with paired concepts.

anāvaraṇañāṇassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'anāvaraṇa' (not obstructing) qualifies 'ñāṇa' (knowledge), indicating knowledge free from obstructions, common in descriptions of enlightened insight in Buddhist texts.

kaḍḍhamāno.meaning_2: dragging conceit; pulling pride; conceit that drags down
kaḍḍhamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound where 'kaḍḍha' (from the present stem of √kaḍḍh, 'to drag') modifies 'māna' ('pride, conceit'). The form is the nominative singular of a masculine noun, likely used adjectivally to describe a type of conceit that 'drags' or 'pulls' one down, perhaps metaphorically in a doctrinal context about mental states.

domanassappattaṃ.meaning_2: affected by mental suffering; distressed; dejected; having attained a state of unhappiness
domanassappattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound where patta functions as a past participle meaning 'reached' or 'attained', describing a state of having reached or being subject to domanassa (mental distress). The neuter accusative singular form suggests it functions as an object or predicate in the sentence, likely describing a person or being in a state of emotional suffering.

vilekhamānaṃ.meaning_2: being perplexed; being confused; lit. being scratched
vilekhamānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular neuter form of the present participle, used adjectivally to modify a neuter noun in the accusative case, indicating a state of perplexity or confusion.

otāramassa.meaning_2: of the opportunity; of the chance; of the opening; of the gap; of the fault; of the shortcoming; of the imperfection; of the point of entry; of the space to go in
otāramassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form otārassa is the genitive singular of the masculine noun otāra, indicating possession or relation ('of the ...'). Without the full sentence context, the specific sense (e.g., opportunity vs. fault) cannot be precisely determined, but it likely relates to a 'crossing down' or transitional concept in Pāḷi literature.

rāgapāsādīhi.meaning_2: snare of sensual desire, etc.; trap of lust, and so on
rāgapāsādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form indicating 'with snares of sensual desire and the like,' used in contexts enumerating various bonds or defilements beginning with lust.

vivekasukhaññeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed as an adverbial phrase, where 'vivekasukha' (seclusion's happiness) is inflected to 'vivekasukhaṃ' (accusative singular neuter) and combined with the emphatic particle 'ññeva' (a sandhi variant of 'eva' meaning 'only'). It emphasizes that the true pleasure lies exclusively in solitude or detachment.

kumārivaṇṇādivasena.meaning_2: by means of a young girl, appearance, etc.; according to the type of a princess, colour, etc.
kumārivaṇṇādivasena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound used instrumentally to indicate manner or reason, likely in a classificatory sense such as 'in the manner of a young girl, her appearance, and so on' or 'by reason of princesses, colours, days, etc.' The exact context would clarify the enumeration starting from kumārī.

panācariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound of 'pana' (five) and 'ācariyā' (instrumental plural of ācariya, teacher). It refers to five teachers or preceptors in a Vinaya context, likely indicating a group or set of five religious instructors.

mahitthibhāvena.meaning_2: state of being an old woman; condition of senior femininity
mahitthibhāvena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of the abstract compound noun mahitthibhāva, denoting the state or nature associated with mahitthī (old woman). The meaning emphasizes the condition or characteristic of being an elderly female, likely in a grammatical or descriptive context given the abstract nature of bhāva.

avītarāgādīnaṃ.meaning_2: etc., beginning with those not free from desire; and so forth, starting with the non-arahants
avītarāgādīnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the genitive plural form of the indeclinable compound 'avītarāgādi', used to indicate 'and the like' or 'etc.' in lists, particularly referring to non-arahants and similar beings afflicted by desire and other defilements.

noyāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form noyāti is the 3rd person singular present indicative of the verb noyāti, a prefixed form of the root √yā (to go). It is commonly used in Pāli texts to denote leading, carrying, or removing something away from a place.

suvānayotiādīni.meaning_2: things such as those easily seduced; things beginning with the easily persuaded, etc.
suvānayotiādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound forming a neuter plural adjective used substantively, referring to a list or class of things starting with 'suvānaya' and similar, in the sense of 'such as the easily led or persuaded, etc.' The form suvānayotiādīni is the nominative/accusative plural, with sandhi between iti and ādi.

sītādipaṭibāhanatthaṃ.meaning_2: for the purpose of carrying cold and the like
sītādipaṭibāhanatthaṃ.construction: sīta + ādi + paṭi + vāhana + attha + aṃ
sītādipaṭibāhanatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound used as the object of an implied verb like 'kāranaṃ' or 'hetu'; it denotes the purpose of conveying cold items and similar things, likely in a Vinaya context regarding monastic rules on carrying.

paṭisaṃvediyamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a present participle in the masculine nominative singular, indicating someone who is experiencing or feeling a sensation, likely in a context of perceiving or being aware of a feeling.

paṭisaṃvediyamānoyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The provided word appears to be a sandhi form of paṭisaṃvediyamāneva, where 'm' from 'māna' elides before 'e' of 'eva'. This is a present participle in the locative singular (paṭisaṃvediyamāne) modified by the emphatic particle eva, meaning 'only in the experiencing' or 'just while feeling'. The lemma is given as the finite verb form for standardization, but the actual usage is participial, indicating a state of experiencing a sensation exclusively or merely.

jhānasukhaphalasukheneva.meaning_2: with the happiness of the fruit of meditative pleasure; by the bliss resulting from the fruit of jhāna
jhānasukhaphalasukheneva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound jhāna-sukha-phala-sukha, meaning 'the happiness of the fruit of jhāna-sukha'. It compares the pleasure of deep meditation to the bliss resulting from its fruition, emphasizing equivalence via 'iva'.

sattasattāhamatthake.meaning_2: at the end of seven weeks; after forty-nine days
sattasattāhamatthake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound forming an adverbial locative expression meaning 'at the top/conclusion of seven seven-day periods,' i.e., after seven weeks or forty-nine days, commonly referring to the period after the Buddha's enlightenment when he composed verses or reflected on the world.

ekūnapaññāsatime.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word ekūnapaññāsatime is the locative singular of the ordinal adjective ekūnapaññāsatima, indicating 'at the forty-ninth' or 'in the forty-ninth', likely referring to a specific time, section, or instance in a sequential context such as a text or list.

agadaharīṭakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A compound noun referring to a type of mineral used in traditional medicine, often identified as magnetite or a similar substance. The accusative singular form suggests it is the direct object in the sentence.

tenassa.grammar: pron, masc & nt gen sg of ima
tenassa.meaning_1: of him; his; of it; its
tenassa.meaning_2: of him; his; of it; its
tenassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi combination of tena (instr sg of ta) + assa (gen sg of ima), resolving euphonic changes in connected speech.

nāgalatādantakaṭṭhañceva.meaning_2: the betel creeper and the tooth stick as well
nāgalatādantakaṭṭhañceva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex sandhi compound formed by juxtaposing 'nāgalatā' (betel creeper) and 'dantakaṭṭha' (tooth stick), followed by the enclitic 'ñca' (a form of 'ca' meaning 'and') and 'eva' (emphasizing 'as well' or 'too'). The form 'ñca' likely results from sandhi with a preceding vowel, common in Pāli compounds. The entire expression lists these two items inclusively, possibly in a monastic context referring to everyday items.

mukhadhovanaudakañca.meaning_2: and the water for washing the face and rinsing the mouth
mukhadhovanaudakañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by juxtaposing 'mukhadhovana' (washing of the mouth/face), 'udaka' (water), and 'ca' (and), likely in a list of ritual items or ablutions in a Vinaya or similar context.

anotattadahodakena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of a compound noun denoting water from the Anotatta lake, one of the great Himalayan lakes; the form shows sandhi between 'daha' and 'udaka' resulting in 'dahodaka'.

ukkalājanapadā.meaning_2: inhabitants of the country Ukkala; people of the land Ukkala (modern day Orissa)
ukkalājanapadā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound noun in nominative plural form, referring to the people or inhabitants of the Ukkala region, likely used in a descriptive or locative context in the text.

āhārasampādane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where āhāra specifies the object of the action sampādana, indicating the act of procuring or providing food or nutriment, common in contexts of monastic provisions.

pāyāsapaṭiggahaṇadivaseyeva.meaning_2: on the very day of receiving the milk rice pudding
pāyāsapaṭiggahaṇadivaseyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning adverbially, indicating time: 'on the day itself of accepting the pudding'. In Vinaya contexts, pāyāsa often refers to a special alms offering, and paṭiggahaṇa to the formal acceptance by monks.

antarahitattā.meaning_2: disappearance; state of having vanished; state of being invisible
antarahitattā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form antarahitattā is the ablative singular neuter of the abstract noun antarahitatta, derived from the past participle antarahita ('disappeared' or 'invisible'). In context, it likely denotes 'from the state of disappearance' or 'due to having vanished,' emphasizing a causal or originative sense.

indanīlamaṇimaye.meaning_2: made of sapphire gems; consisting of sapphire jewels
indanīlamaṇimaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where indanīla (sapphire) specifies the type of maṇi (jewel) in maṇimaya (made of jewels), likely in locative or instrumental case in context, describing something adorned or constructed with sapphire gems.

muggavaṇṇaselamaye.meaning_2: made of stone resembling the color of mung beans
muggavaṇṇaselamaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective modifying a masculine noun, where 'mugga-vaṇṇa' specifies the greenish color like mung beans, and 'sela-maya' indicates composition from stone, likely referring to a statue or structure with a mung bean-like hue.

paññāyamānalekhā.meaning_2: inscription appearing in script; writing occurring in a known form
paññāyamānalekhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun where paññāyamāna (present participle, 'appearing' or 'being known') modifies lekhā ('writing' or 'inscription'), likely referring to a script or inscription that manifests or is recognized in a particular context, such as in texts or records.

paṭiggaṇhitvā.meaning_2: to take; to receive; to accept
paṭiggaṇhitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form paṭiggaṇhitvā is the absolutive (gerund) derived from the present stem paṭiggaṇh, indicating the action of 'having taken' or 'after receiving', commonly used in Pāli to express anteriority in sequence of events.

paricaritabbaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: place or basis for that which should be attended to; object or situation requiring service or care
paricaritabbaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines the potential participle paricaritabba ('that which should be attended to or served') with ṭhāna ('place, basis'), indicating a locus or context for dutiful service, likely in a monastic or ethical framework where such attendance is obligatory.

suvaṇṇasamuggassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective modifying an unstated noun, likely referring to a golden casket in a descriptive context.

nisinnamattasseva.grammar: ind, adv; comp of pp nisinn + pp matta + gen sg + iva + eva
nisinnamattasseva.meaning_2: just as much as seated; only to the extent of sitting
nisinnamattasseva.construction: ni + sīda + na + √mā + ta + assa + iva + eva
nisinnamattasseva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a fused adverbial expression where 'nisinnamattassa' (genitive singular of nisinnamatta, 'of the measure of seated' or 'of the amount of sitting') combines with 'eva' for emphasis, and 'iva' for similitude, yielding an indeclinable unit meaning 'just as much as one is seated' or 'only to the extent of sitting.' This construction is idiomatic in Pāḷi for expressing proportion or limitation in similes, often in meditative or descriptive contexts.

adesetukamyatākārapavatto.grammar: sandhi, masc + inf + fem + masc + pp
adesetukamyatākārapavatto.meaning_2: the action of desiring to go to an unsuitable place; lit. the deed of longing to arrive at an improper place, having proceeded forward
adesetukamyatākārapavatto.construction: ades + etuṃ + kamyat + ā + kāra + pavatta
adesetukamyatākārapavatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex tatpuruṣa compound likely used adjectivally or nominally in a Vinaya context to describe an improper action or case involving the desire to go to a forbidden or unsuitable place, such as an area off-limits to monks.

cakkavāḷasahassehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound 'cakkavāḷasahassa', referring to thousands of world systems or solar systems, commonly used in Buddhist cosmology to denote the domain ruled by a cakkavattirāja (universal monarch).

sakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmitavasavattima.meaning_2: Sakka, Suyāma, Santusita, Sunimmita, Vasavattī, Mahābrahmā
sakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmitavasavattima.family_compound: sakka suyāma santusita sunimmita vasavattī mahābrahma
sakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmitavasavattima.construction: sakka + suyāma + santusita + sunimmita + vasavattī + mahābrahmā + no
sakkasuyāmasantusitasunimmitavasavattima.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound listing six great deities or lords of the heavens in Pāli Buddhist cosmology, appearing in the nominative plural form as subjects. The sequence follows the standard order of heavenly rulers: Sakka (Trāyastriṃśa), Suyāma (Yāma), Santusita (Tuṣita), Sunimmita (Nirmāṇarati), Vasavattī (Paranirmitavaśavartin), and Mahābrahmā (Brahmā realm).

dhammantiādinā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound used in lists to indicate 'dhamma and the rest' or 'beginning with dhamma', common in Pāḷi for enumerations of teachings or principles.

sattāhakālakatabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of having died after a week
sattāhakālakatabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sattāha qualifies the time of death, and kālakatabhāva indicates the state of having passed away; the entire term describes the condition or occurrence of death happening after seven days.

abhidosakālakatabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of having died around dusk
abhidosakālakatabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where abhidosa (around dusk) modifies kāla (time), and kālakatabhāva (state of having died) forms the core, indicating the condition or occurrence of death at the time of evening. The accusative ending suggests it functions as the object in its sentence.

bodhimaṇḍasāmantāyeva.meaning_2: just in the vicinity of the bodhimanda; only around the seat of enlightenment
bodhimaṇḍasāmantāyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi compound functioning as an indeclinable adverbial phrase. 'Sāmantā' is the ablative singular adverb of 'sāmanta' meaning 'from all around' or 'in the vicinity of', combined with 'bodhimaṇḍa' to specify location, and 'eva' adds emphasis meaning 'only' or 'just'. It likely describes something happening exclusively near the Buddha's seat under the bodhi tree.

āsāḷhipuṇṇamāsiyaṃ.meaning_2: on the full-moon day in the month āsāḷha
āsāḷhipuṇṇamāsiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular, indicating location in time, 'on the full-moon day of āsāḷha'. This is a tatpuruṣa compound where āsāḷhi specifies the month for the full-moon night puṇṇamāsī. The optative siyaṃ appears to be a separate word in the original text, possibly forming a phrase like 'āsāḷhipuṇṇamāsiyaṃ siyaṃ' meaning 'there might be on the full-moon of āsāḷha'.

paccayabāhullāya.meaning_2: excess of supporting conditions; over-abundance of causes or requisites
paccayabāhullāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where paccaya (supporting condition, cause) is qualified by bāhulla (abundance, excess), indicating an excessive reliance on or proliferation of conditions, often in a doctrinal context warning against attachment to causal dependencies.

abhivādanādīni.meaning_2: bowing down etc.; paying respect etc.; honouring etc.
abhivādanādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter nominative/accusative plural form of the indeclinable 'ādi' used in compounds, indicating 'beginning with bowing down and so on', referring to rituals or acts of respect including and beyond bowing.

mahākulapasuto.meaning_2: tied to a great family; attached to a prominent family
mahākulapasuto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'mahākula' (great family) with 'pasuto' (past participle of pa√si, meaning 'tied' or 'attached'), indicating someone bound or devoted to a noble lineage, likely in a social or familial context.

āsanamattaṃ.meaning_2: measure of the seat; just the seat; only the seat
āsanamattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form āsanamattaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound āsanamattha, where matta (from √mā 'to measure') functions as an indeclinable meaning 'only' or 'just', qualifying āsana 'seat'. This is a common construction in Pāli for emphasizing limitation or sufficiency, often in contexts of minimalism or meditation posture.

jānanasamatthena.meaning_2: capable of knowing; skilled in understanding
jānanasamatthena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound, indicating 'by one capable of knowing' or 'with understanding skill'; used adjectivally in context.

sabbadevamanussesu.grammar: masc pl, loc of sabbadevamanussā, comp
sabbadevamanussesu.meaning_2: among all gods and human beings; among all deities and men
sabbadevamanussesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound in locative plural form, combining 'sabba' (all) with 'devamanussā' (gods and humans), indicating 'among all gods and humans'. The form 'sabbadevamanussesu' results from sandhi where 'sabbā' (loc pl of sabba) + 'devamanussesu' (loc pl of devamanussā) merge, with ā + e > e.

anodissakavasena.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, instr sg of anodissakavasa
anodissakavasena.meaning_2: by unrestricted power; by general authority; without personal bias
anodissakavasena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where anodissaka (unrestricted, general) modifies vasa (power, will), and the whole is put in the instrumental case with -ena to form an adverbial phrase indicating manner or means. It conveys action by impartial or general authority, fitting the 'without a personal hint' nuance of anodissaka.

pharaṇasamatthaṃ.meaning_2: capable of pervading; able to suffuse; skilled in infusing
pharaṇasamatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in accusative singular neuter, likely describing something capable of pervading or suffusing, such as a quality or substance in a doctrinal context.

odissakavasena.meaning_2: by special authority; by exceptional power; by particular will
odissakavasena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental adverbial form from the compound 'odissakavasena', combining 'odissaka' (special, exceptional) and 'vasa' (will, power), used to indicate manner or reason, as in 'by special desire' or 'through exceptional authority'. No sentences provided for further contextual nuance.

abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānādīni.meaning_2: bowing down, rising up, etc.; acts of respect and so on
abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a neuter plural form of a compound noun ending in 'ādi', indicating a list beginning with bowing down and rising in respect, typical in Vinaya contexts for enumerating courteous acts.

sammāsambuddhabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of being a perfectly awakened one; condition of full enlightenment
sammāsambuddhabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, likely used in contexts discussing the attainment or nature of Buddhahood in Pāḷi texts.

varabuddhāsane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of the compound 'varabuddhāsana', meaning 'in the excellent Buddha's seat'. The first member 'vara' qualifies 'buddhāsana' (Buddha's seat) as 'excellent' or 'foremost'.

uttarāsāḷhanakkhattayoge.meaning_2: conjunction with the northern Asāḷha constellation; astrological alignment involving the northern Asāḷha star
uttarāsāḷhanakkhattayoge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound describing an astrological conjunction (yoga) involving the northern (uttara) form of the Asāḷha nakṣatra, a lunar mansion associated with the months of June-July. In Pāḷi astrological contexts, such terms refer to specific celestial alignments, likely of significance in horoscopes or omens.

brahmakoṭīhi.meaning_2: divine totality; supreme point; highest limit
brahmakoṭīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a compound referring to a supreme or divine extent, possibly a cosmological or numerical magnitude in Buddhist texts, such as the number of worlds or beings. The 'hi' suffix in the original form suggests an emphatic particle attached, but the core lemma is the compound.

dhammacakkappavattanasuttantaṃ.meaning_2: Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta; the discourse on setting the wheel of Dhamma rolling; SN 56.11
dhammacakkappavattanasuttantaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of the compound noun naming the famous first discourse of the Buddha, where he expounds the Four Noble Truths to the five ascetics at the Deer Park in Sarnath. The text form indicates it as the object in a sentence, likely 'the Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta'.

aññāsikoṇḍaññatthero.meaning_2: the elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña; the venerable Koṇḍañña who understood
aññāsikoṇḍaññatthero.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in vocative singular, used as a proper name for the elder monk Koṇḍañña, the first to attain enlightenment after the Buddha's sermon, highlighting his understanding ('aññāsi') of the Dhamma.

desanānusārena.grammar: ind, adv, sandhi comp of desanā + anusārena
desanānusārena.meaning_2: in accordance with the teaching; following the discourse
desanānusārena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi compound functioning as an indeclinable, combining the feminine noun desanā ('teaching, discourse') with the instrumental adverb anusārena ('in accordance with'), commonly used in Pāḷi to express conformity or adherence to a doctrine or instruction.

suttapariyosāne.meaning_2: conclusion of the discourse; end of the sutta
suttapariyosāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound commonly used in Pāḷi texts to indicate the conclusion or ending of a sutta recitation or discourse.

vappattheraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in accusative singular, resolving to vappaṃ + ttheraṃ, referring to the senior monk named Vappa, a Sakyan disciple of the Buddha. The word appears as an object in the text, likely in a narrative context involving this figure.

vappatthero.meaning_2: elder Vappa; senior monk named Vappa
vappatthero.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a proper name compound referring to the elder monk Vappa, a Sakyan disciple, in vocative singular case, likely addressing him in the context of the text.

bhaddiyattheraṃ.meaning_2: the elder Bhaddiya; the senior monk named Bhaddiya
bhaddiyattheraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of the compound 'bhaddiyatthera', referring to the arahant monk Bhaddiya, one of the Buddha's disciples. Without the sentence context, the exact usage is inferred from the dictionary entries; it likely functions as the object of a verb like 'eti' (comes/goes) in a narrative about his arrival or movement.

mahānāmattheraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound 'mahānāmatthera', referring to the Sakyan layman Mahānāma addressed as an elder; the -ṃ ending indicates object of a verb in an unprovided sentence context.

assajittheranti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form assajittheranti appears to be a sandhi combination or scribal error for assājī ti, where assājī is the 1st person singular aorist 'I let go' and ti is the indeclinable 'thus'. Without the full sentence context, the exact usage in the text cannot be specified, but it likely conveys an action of releasing or rejecting in a narrative or doctrinal context.

anattalakkhaṇasuttantaṃ.meaning_2: the discourse on the characteristic of not-self
anattalakkhaṇasuttantaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of the compound noun referring to the Anattalakkhaṇa Sutta (SN 22.59), a key discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya explaining the impersonal nature of the five aggregates.

yasakulaputtassa.meaning_2: of the son of good family named Yasa; of the respectable young man Yasa
yasakulaputtassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of the compound 'Yasakulaputta', referring to the arahant monk Yasa as a son of a good family. The name 'Yasa' combines with 'kulaputta' to specify his identity and status in the context.

ehibhikkhupabbajjāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound likely used in a vocative or dative context in Vinaya texts, addressing a monk regarding novice ordination, e.g., 'O monk, come to renunciation!' The form ends in -āya, suggesting dative singular of the feminine pabbajjā, with ehi as an imperative call.

kappāsikavanasaṇḍe.meaning_2: cotton forest grove; thicket of cotton trees
kappāsikavanasaṇḍe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular, indicating location in a grove of cotton trees; the compound combines 'kappāsika' (cotton-related, here likely modifying 'vana') with 'vanasaṇḍa' (forest thicket).

bhaddavaggiyakumāre.meaning_2: youngster belonging to an excellent group; prince of a fine lineage
bhaddavaggiyakumāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'bhaddavaggiyakumāra', meaning a young prince or boy from an excellent or noble group, likely referring to a specific noble youth in the narrative context.

sabbapacchimako.meaning_2: completely final; altogether last; very last
sabbapacchimako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective formed by 'sabba' (all, every) intensifying 'pacchimaka' (very last, final), likely meaning 'the very last of all' or 'completely final' in a sequential or ordinal context.

sabbuttamo.meaning_1: most supreme of all; altogether supreme
sabbuttamo.meaning_2: best of all; highest among everything
sabbuttamo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sabba functions adjectivally to qualify uttama, indicating the supreme quality in relation to all things. The form sabbuttamo appears to be a sandhi variant or scribal adjustment of sabb-uttamo, with the double 'bb' preserved from sabba.

ehibhikkhubhāveneva.meaning_2: by the very monkhood that comes
ehibhikkhubhāveneva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form of ehibhikkhubhāvena + eva, likely in an instrumental case construction emphasizing the attainment of monkhood through the imperative call 'come!' in monastic contexts, such as ordination procedures in the Vinaya.

pāṭihāriyasahassāni.meaning_2: thousands of miracles; thousands of wonders
pāṭihāriyasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi-like compound in neuter plural, functioning as the object of 'thousands of miraculous displays' in the context of the text.

uruvelakassapādayo.meaning_2: Uruvelākassapa and others; lit. beginning with Uruvelākassapa
uruvelakassapādayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in the nominative plural form, referring to Uruvelākassapa (a prominent disciple) and other similar figures, common in lists of monks or disciples in Pāli texts.

sahassajaṭilaparivāre.meaning_2: with a thousand dreadlocked ascetics as retinue; accompanied by a thousand jaṭila ascetics
sahassajaṭilaparivāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a large entourage of dreadlocked ascetics (jaṭila), numbering one thousand, functioning as a retinue (parivāra) in a locative form indicating accompaniment.

tebhātikajaṭile.meaning_2: with the three matted-hair ascetics; with ascetics having matted hair
tebhātikajaṭile.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be an instrumental singular form of a compound describing a group of three ascetics characterized by matted hair (jaṭila), likely in a narrative context involving such figures.

ādittapariyāyadesanāya.meaning_2: teaching of the discourse on burning; explanation of the fire sermon
ādittapariyāyadesanāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun refers to the teaching or exposition of the Āditta Pariyāya Sutta (SN 35.235), known as the Fire Sermon, where the Buddha uses the metaphor of everything being 'on fire' with passion, hatred, and delusion.

arahantasahassena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound arahantasahassa, meaning 'a thousand arahants', used to indicate accompaniment or means in the context of the sentence.

bimbisārarañño.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'bimbisāra' (name of the Magadhan king) is combined with 'rañño' (genitive singular of 'rāja', meaning 'of the king'). The form indicates possession or relation to King Bimbisāra, likely used in a narrative context referring to the historical figure in Buddhist texts.

nagarūpacāre.meaning_2: neighbourhood of the town; area surrounding the city
nagarūpacāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'nagarūpacāra' means the vicinity or precincts of the town, combining 'nagara' (town) with 'upacāra' (vicinity, approach). The form 'nagarūpacāre' is locative singular, indicating location 'in the town neighbourhood'.

cakkavicittatalesu.meaning_2: flat surface decorated with diverse wheel designs; variegated wheel-patterned base
cakkavicittatalesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely describes a decorative architectural or artistic element, such as a floor or platform adorned with multicolored wheel motifs, common in Buddhist iconography where the wheel (cakka) symbolizes the Dharma.

suvaṇṇapaṭṭavitānaṃ.meaning_2: golden cloth canopy; golden silk awning
suvaṇṇapaṭṭavitānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of the compound noun, likely describing a luxurious covering made of golden silk cloth stretched out as a canopy.

pabhāsamudayaṃ.meaning_2: arising of light; origination of radiance
pabhāsamudayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pabhāsa' (light, radiance) is qualified by 'samudaya' (arising, origination), forming 'the arising of light'. The accusative singular form indicates an object in the sentence.

vissajjantesu.meaning_2: having dismounted; having disembarked; having left behind
vissajjantesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'vissajjantesu' is the locative plural of the present active participle vissajjant-, indicating 'in those who were dismounting/disembarking/leaving behind'. The -su ending applies to masculine/neuter locative plural, consistent with tesu from ta.

sāvakabhāvapakāsanatthaṃ.meaning_2: for the purpose of illuminating the state of a disciple; for the sake of explaining the nature of a pupil
sāvakabhāvapakāsanatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound used in accusative case to indicate purpose, common in Pāli for 'for the sake of'. The structure breaks down as disciple-state-illumination-purpose-accusative, denoting intent to clarify the disciple's condition or nature in a doctrinal context.

pādapiṭṭhe.meaning_2: at the foot of the tree; base of the tree
pādapiṭṭhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pādapiṭṭhe is locative singular, indicating position 'at the foot/base of the tree'. Here piṭṭha means 'back' or 'surface', but in this compound with pāda, it denotes the lower part or base of the tree trunk. The dictionary entry for piṭṭha is adapted to fit the compound structure, distinct from the flour meaning (piṭṭha 2).

ekatālaṃ.meaning_2: one palm tree (in height); a single palmyra
ekatālaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely an adverbial accusative indicating measure, 'to the height of one palm tree', based on tāla 1.2 usage; no contextual sentence provided, so meaning inferred from dictionary entries.

sattatālappamāṇaṃ.meaning_2: of the measure of seven palm trees; as deep as seven palm trees
sattatālappamāṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adjective, describing something with the height or depth equivalent to seven palm trees, likely in a descriptive context such as dimensions of a pit or structure.

thāmagatadiṭṭhiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective formed by thāmagata (entrenched; obstinate) + diṭṭhika (having views; holding opinions), likely denoting someone obstinately attached to views or entrenched in beliefs. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is inferred from components.

damitoyevāti.meaning_2: thus, 'tamed indeed'; thus, 'just tamed'; thus, 'merely tamed'
damitoyevāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a quotational adverbial phrase formed by combining the past participle 'damita' (tamed), the emphatic particle 'eva' (indeed, just), and the quotative 'iti' (thus). It functions to quote or exemplify the idea of something being 'tamed indeed' or 'just tamed', often used in explanatory or illustrative contexts in Pāḷi texts.

aṭṭhuppattiyā.meaning_2: for the sake of attaining the goal; for the purpose of achieving the aim
aṭṭhuppattiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the instrumental singular feminine form of the compound aṭṭhuppatti, denoting 'for the attainment of the goal/purpose'. The first member aṭṭha refers to 'goal; purpose', and the second uppatti to 'arising; origin', together indicating the realization or coming into being of the intended purpose. Used adverbially in contexts emphasizing motivation or instrumental purpose.

magadharājā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun referring to the sovereign of the ancient kingdom of Magadha (modern Bihar), commonly used in Pāḷi texts to denote rulers like Bimbisāra or Ajātasattu.

aṭṭhārasakoṭisaṅkhā.meaning_2: eighteen koṭi saṅkhā (a numerical unit representing 18 × 10^7 × 10^14 = 1.8 × 10^22)
aṭṭhārasakoṭisaṅkhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral used in Pāḷi texts to denote extremely large numbers, often in cosmological or enumerative contexts such as the number of worlds or beings. The term saṅkhā here refers to a vast numerical measure, with koṭi as the multiplier and aṭṭhārasa specifying eighteen.

sakalalaṭṭhivanuyyānaṃ.meaning_2: whole Laṭṭhivana pleasure grove; entire cane wood park to the southwest of Rājagaha
sakalalaṭṭhivanuyyānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a descriptive compound where 'sakala' modifies the proper name 'laṭṭhivanuyyānaṃ', indicating the entirety of the named park or grove near Rājagaha. No contextual sentence provided, but based on dictionary entries, it likely refers to a location in a narrative setting.

rūpasobhaggappattaṃ.meaning_2: endowed with beautiful form; possessed of splendorous appearance
rūpasobhaggappattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'rūpa' (form, appearance) with 'sobhaggappatta' (endowed with beauty or splendor), indicating something that has attained a state of beautiful or radiant form, likely in a descriptive context of physical or aesthetic quality.

vaṇṇabhūmi.meaning_2: region of color; land of beauty; realm of appearance
vaṇṇabhūmi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] As a compound, vaṇṇabhūmi combines 'vaṇṇa' (color, beauty, appearance) with 'bhūmi' (land, region, realm), likely denoting a specific area or domain characterized by color or beauty. Without contextual sentences, the primary sense is inferred as a colored or beautiful region; in Buddhist contexts, it may refer to a cosmological plane or aesthetic sphere.

nāmesā.meaning_2: namely this; that is to say, this
nāmesā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi combination of the indeclinable nāma ('namely') and the feminine nominative singular pronoun esā ('this'), likely resulting from vowel sandhi where the final -a of nāma merges with the initial e- of esā, though no explicit phonetic change is shown in the form; used to emphasize or specify 'this' in context.

lakkhaṇānubyañjanādippabhedā.meaning_2: divisions such as characteristics, secondary marks, etc.
lakkhaṇānubyañjanādippabhedā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive tatpuruṣa compound listing categories in a grammatical or doctrinal context, with 'ādi' indicating 'etc.' and 'pabhedā' in vocative singular to address or enumerate the divisions.

rūpakāyasirī.meaning_2: physical body of glory; material form of fortune
rūpakāyasirī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'rūpakāya' (physical body) with 'sirī' (glory, fortune), likely used in a poetic or honorific sense to describe a body endowed with splendor or auspicious fortune. Without specific sentences, the exact contextual usage is inferred from component meanings.

uṇhākāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound uṇhākāraṃ is the accusative singular form, likely referring to 'heat' as an abstract quality or 'the state of being hot' in context, combining the adjective 'uṇha' (hot) with 'kāra' (deed, action, or making).

buddhadhammasaṅghapaṭisaṃyuttā.meaning_2: connected with Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha
buddhadhammasaṅghapaṭisaṃyuttā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a feminine nominative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound where paṭisaṃyutta functions as the final member, indicating connection or relation. The form ā suggests agreement with a feminine noun such as dhātu (element) or a similar term in the original context, referring to faith or elements connected to the Three Jewels.

bhikkhusahassaparivuto.meaning_2: surrounded by one thousand monks; accompanied by a thousand monks
bhikkhusahassaparivuto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a descriptive compound where 'bhikkhusahassa' (instrumental sg of bhikkhusahassa, 'by one thousand monks') modifies 'parivuta' (pp 'surrounded'), indicating the Buddha or a similar figure surrounded by a thousand monks, a common motif in Pāli literature for describing large monastic assemblies.

buddhārahaṃ.meaning_2: worthy of the Buddha; one deserving the Buddha
buddhārahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in nominative singular, functioning as a bahuvrīhi adjective meaning 'worthy of the Buddha', often used as an epithet for the Buddha himself in Pāli texts.

pupphagandhavāsitaṃ.meaning_2: perfumed with floral scent; filled with flower perfume
pupphagandhavāsitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a past participle form used as an adjective in neuter accusative singular, likely describing something scented or suffused with the fragrance of flowers, such as air or a place in a poetic or descriptive context.

veḷuvanuyyānaṃ.meaning_2: bamboo park; pleasure grove in Veḷuvana
veḷuvanuyyānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining the proper name Veḷuvana (Bamboo Grove) with uyyāna (park), referring to the famous monastic park near Rājagaha. The form is accusative singular, likely the object in the sentence.

ārāmapaṭiggahaṇe.meaning_2: acceptance of a monastery; receiving a parkland
ārāmapaṭiggahaṇe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound, used in Vinaya contexts to denote the procedure or case of accepting a monastery donation. ārāma here specifically means 'monastery' (Buddhist vihāra), and paṭiggahaṇa refers to the act of formal acceptance.

jambudīpasmiñhi.meaning_2: India; name of the central continent in Buddhist cosmology
jambudīpasmiñhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The locative singular form jambudīpasmiñhi indicates 'in Jambudīpa'. Jambudīpa is the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, encompassing the human realm including India, named after the rose-apple tree.

gahitasenāsanaṃ.meaning_2: provided with lodging; furnished with a living place; lit. grasped bed and chair
gahitasenāsanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'gahita' (provided, furnished) modifies 'senāsana' (lodging), indicating something equipped with sleeping and seating arrangements, common in monastic contexts for describing prepared accommodations.

veḷuvanārāmaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'veḷuvana' (bamboo forest) with 'ārāma' (park or monastery), referring to the famous Veḷuvana monastery near Rājagaha.

assajittheraṃ.meaning_2: released elder; elder who was released
assajittheraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'assajit' (past participle from assajati 'released') modifies 'thera' (elder), resulting in the accusative singular form due to sandhi with the following word. The form 'assajittheraṃ' shows elision of 'i' in 'assajiti' before 'theraṃ'.

moggallānaparibbājakassapi.meaning_2: even of the wandering ascetic Moggallāna
moggallānaparibbājakassapi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in genitive singular with 'api' postposition, likely referring to the monk Moggallāna in the role of or compared to a wandering ascetic (paribbājaka). The genitive form indicates possession or relation, and 'api' adds emphasis like 'even' or 'also' in context.

aggasāvakaṭṭhāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular of the compound aggasāvakaṭṭhāna, likely meaning 'in the place of the chief disciple' or 'in the position of the foremost disciple', referring to the role or station of Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

arahattappattadivaseyeva.meaning_1: on the very day of attaining arahantship
arahattappattadivaseyeva.meaning_2: on the very day he became awakened; on the very day of reaching the state of being worthy
arahattappattadivaseyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound forming an adverbial phrase meaning 'on the very day of becoming an arahant.'
