It likely appears in a narrative context describing an event occurring immediately upon enlightenment, such as in the story of a monk or the Buddha himself. The emphasis from 'eva' underscores the immediacy.

veḷuvanuyyāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a karmadhāraya compound where veḷuvana (bamboo forest) specifies the type of uyyāna (park); the locative form indicates location, as in 'in the Bamboo Grove park'.

purisasahassaparivāro.meaning_2: man with a thousand-man retinue; person accompanied by a thousand followers
purisasahassaparivāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'purisa' (man) is qualified by 'sahassa-parivāra' (with a thousand retinue), indicating a man leading or accompanied by a thousand-person entourage. Common in descriptions of kings or leaders in Pāḷi texts.

saṭṭhiyojanamaggaṃ.meaning_2: road of sixty yojanas; path measuring sixty yojanas
saṭṭhiyojanamaggaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'saṭṭhi' (sixty) quantifies 'yojana' (a measure of distance, approx. 20 km), and the whole modifies 'magga' (road/path), indicating a path of approximately 1200 km. The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the direct object in the sentence.

dhammadesanāvelāya.meaning_2: time for teaching the Dhamma; occasion of a Dhamma discourse
dhammadesanāvelāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound combining 'dhammadesanā' (Dhamma teaching) with 'velā' (time), indicating the appropriate or specified time for delivering a Dhamma talk, often in monastic contexts.

pahitasāsananti.meaning_2: dispatched message; sent instruction; letter that has been sent
pahitasāsananti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi compound 'pahita-sāsana' with 'iti' appended, functioning as an indeclinable adverbial phrase meaning 'the sent message thus' or similar, likely in a quotative sense. 'Pahita' is the past participle of pahiṇāti (to send), and 'sāsana' means message or instruction. Without the full sentence, the exact contextual usage is inferred as referring to a dispatched communication.

saṭṭhivassattherā.meaning_2: elder monk of sixty years standing; senior monk with sixty rain retreats completed
saṭṭhivassattherā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a monastic elder who has completed sixty vassa (rain retreats), indicating seniority in the monastic order. The form is nominative plural, referring to such elders in a group.

pattakālato.meaning_2: from the suitable time; from the right occasion
pattakālato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an ablative indeclinable formed from the compound pattakāla ('suitable time'), indicating origin or source from the appropriate occasion. The form -ato is a common ablative ending for masculine/neuter nouns in Pāli, functioning adverbially.

pahitasāsanaṃ.meaning_2: instruction sent; dispatched teaching; message of the doctrine
pahitasāsanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines the past participle 'pahita' (likely meaning 'sent' or 'dispatched' from pa + √hi) with 'sāsana' (teaching or instruction), suggesting a sent message or dispatched doctrinal instruction, common in contexts of Buddhist teachings or monastic communications.

purisasahassaparivāre.meaning_2: accompanied by a thousand men; with a retinue of a thousand men
purisasahassaparivāre.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'purisa' (man) modifies 'sahassa' (thousand), forming 'purisasahassa' (thousand men), which then modifies 'parivāra' (retinue), resulting in a retinue consisting of a thousand men. The form 'purisasahassaparivāre' is likely locative singular, indicating 'with' or 'in the company of' such a retinue, common in descriptive contexts for kings or figures with large entourages.

sāsanamattampi.meaning_2: even a little of the teaching; even the slightest instruction
sāsanamattampi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound meaning 'even a little of the teaching,' formed by sāsana (teaching) + matta (amount of, in compounds) + api (even). It emphasizes a minimal quantity of religious instruction or message.

sinehābhāvena.meaning_2: state of affection; loving disposition; emotional attachment
sinehābhāvena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form of the compound sinehābhāva, indicating 'with affection' or 'by loving nature' in context.

rājabalaṃ.meaning_2: king's power; royal strength; sovereign's might
rājabalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where rāja (king) qualifies bala (strength), indicating the power associated with royalty. In the absence of specific sentences, the meaning is inferred from standard usage in Pāli literature, often denoting royal authority or military might.

sabbatthasādhako.meaning_2: accomplishing all purposes; effecting all benefits
sabbatthasādhako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound functions as an adjective describing something that achieves or accomplishes every purpose or benefit, based on the senses of sabbattha ('everywhere; in every way') and sādhaka ('effecting, accomplishing').

ativissāsiko.meaning_2: overly intimate; excessively confidential; too trustworthy
ativissāsiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word combines the prefix 'ati' indicating excess with 'vissāsika', suggesting a sense of undue trust or intimacy beyond what is appropriate.

passitukāmo.meaning_2: wishing to see; wanting to see; would be delighted to see
passitukāmo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form passitukāmo is a compound adjective combining the infinitive passituṃ 'to see' with kāmo 'wishing (to)', functioning as a bahuvrīhi or karmadhāraya to denote someone desiring to see. Used in contexts expressing intent or eagerness to perceive.

purisasahassāni.meaning_2: one thousand men; one thousand persons
purisasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral noun in the neuter plural form, likely used to quantify a group of individuals in a distributive sense, such as 'groups of a thousand men' or 'a thousand men' collectively.

ekapurisopi.meaning_2: even one man; even a single person
ekapurisopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an emphatic adverbial compound combining 'eka' (one, single), 'purisa' (man, person), and 'api' (even, also), used to stress 'even one person' in context, likely in a Vinaya or doctrinal discussion about minimal requirements or solitary actions.

sāsanamattaṃ.meaning_2: measured by the teaching; to the extent of the instruction; as much as the doctrine
sāsanamattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sāsanamattaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound sāsanamattta, where matta functions as a postpositional modifier indicating extent or measure ('to the extent of' or 'as much as'). The base sāsana likely refers to 'teaching' or 'instruction' in a Buddhist context, with matta derived from the past participle of mināti, emphasizing quantity or degree. Without the sentence, the exact nuance (e.g., sufficiency or limitation) is inferred from common usage in Pāli texts.

ārocentopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ārocentopi combines the 3rd plural present indicative ārocanti ('they tell/inform') with the enclitic api ('even'), often used in concessive sense as 'even if they tell'. Without the sentence context, the exact nuance is inferred from standard usage.

apabbajitvā.meaning_2: having ordained (in); having renounced the household life; lit. having gone forth
apabbajitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form apabbajitvā likely results from sandhi with a preceding vowel (e.g., a + pabbajitvā), where 'a' assimilates or contracts, but the lemma remains pabbajitvā as the core absolutive form.

parisapariyante.meaning_2: in the assembly up to the end; at the gathering's limit
parisapariyante.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound of 'parisā' (assembly) and the locative singular of 'pariyanta' (limit, end), likely meaning 'in the assembly up to the end' or 'at the limit of the gathering'. Without provided sentences, the exact contextual usage is inferred from dictionary entries, suggesting a locative phrase indicating spatial or temporal extent within an assembly.

ehibhikkhubhāve.meaning_2: coming to monkhood; entering the state of monk
ehibhikkhubhāve.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Sandhi compound formed by the imperative 'ehi' (come!) and the locative singular 'bhikkhubhāve' (in the monkhood), likely used in Vinaya context to denote the act of entering monkhood, as in a formulaic expression for ordination.

bhikkhusahassaparivāro.meaning_2: accompanied by one thousand monks; with a retinue of one thousand monks
bhikkhusahassaparivāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (tatpuruṣa) where 'parivāro' functions adjectivally to indicate accompaniment by a retinue of one thousand bhikkhus, common in Pāli texts to describe a Buddha or elder surrounded by followers.

phussamāsapuṇṇamāyaṃ.meaning_2: the full moon night of the Phussa month
phussamāsapuṇṇamāyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound referring to the full moon of the lunar month Phussa (December-January). The form is instrumental singular, likely used in a context describing time or an event associated with this specific full moon night.

āgatadivasato.grammar: ind, adv, masc abl sg of divasa
āgatadivasato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form āgatadivasato appears to be a sandhi compound of āgata (past participle 'having come' or 'arrived') + divasato ('from the day'), likely meaning 'from the day of arrival' or 'since the day one arrived'. This interprets the word as a descriptive adverbial phrase indicating a temporal starting point.

sattaṭṭha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Numerical compound formed by adding the cardinal numbers satta (seven) and aṭṭha (eight) to denote eighteen; common in Pāḷi for compound numerals.

phagguṇīpuṇṇamāsiyaṃ.meaning_2: on the full moon night of the Phagguṇī constellation
phagguṇīpuṇṇamāsiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be an instrumental singular of a tatpuruṣa compound 'phagguṇīpuṇṇamāsī' (full moon night of Phagguṇī), with 'siyā' likely a scribal error or variant for 'sī' (stem of puṇṇamāsī). In context, it likely denotes a temporal location, 'on the night of the full moon in the Phagguṇī month/star period'.

vasantasamayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vasanta (spring) qualifies samaya (time), denoting the season of spring. In Pāḷi literature, such compounds often refer to specific seasons or times poetically.

sassādīni.meaning_1: beginning with one's own (things), etc.; one's own and so on
sassādīni.meaning_2: one's own possessions etc.; things beginning with self
sassādīni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a common idiomatic compound in Pāḷi texts, especially in Vinaya and Abhidhamma, denoting a list starting with 'one's own' (e.g., property, body) and extending to similar items via 'ādi' (etc.). The neuter plural form sassādīni indicates the objects or items in the list.

sammukhasammukhaṭṭhānehi.meaning_2: in places of face-to-face confrontation; in positions of direct opposition
sammukhasammukhaṭṭhānehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of a compound noun, likely denoting locations or situations involving mutual face-to-face confrontation, as the reduplication of 'sammukha' emphasizes direct opposition. The absence of sentences limits precise contextual nuance, but the structure suggests use in contexts of debate, encounter, or opposition.

haritatiṇasañchannā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective describing something enveloped or shaded by fresh green grass, likely in a natural or poetic context.

paṭipajjanakkhamā.meaning_2: capable of practice; suitable for observance
paṭipajjanakkhamā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where paṭipajjana (procedure, practice) is qualified by khamā (the feminine form of khama meaning 'fit for, capable of'), resulting in an adjective describing something suitable or capable for practice or observance.

nātiuṇhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular adverbial form of the adjective atiuṇha, used to describe an excessive degree of heat in context.

nātidubbhikkhachātakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound is a bahuvrīhi describing a state or period that is not excessively characterized by famine, combining negation, intensification, and two synonymous terms for famine.

kulanagaraṃ.meaning_1: family town; town of the household
kulanagaraṃ.meaning_2: town; city associated with a family or household
kulanagaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound likely denoting a town or city belonging to or associated with a family or household; accusative singular form suggests use as direct object in context.

gamanavaṇṇaṃ.meaning_2: praise of going; commendation of journeying
gamanavaṇṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'gamana' (going, journey) is qualified by 'vaṇṇa' (praise). The accusative singular form suggests it functions as the object in the sentence, likely referring to the act of praising or describing the journey in a positive light.

aṅgamagadhavāsīnaṃ.meaning_2: resident of Aṅga and Magadha; Aṅgan and Magadhan
aṅgamagadhavāsīnaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative plural form of the compound adjective aṅgamagadhavāsī, referring to the people living in the regions of Aṅga and Magadha, likely in a context describing inhabitants or a group from these eastern Indian territories.

vīsatisahassehi.meaning_2: by twenty thousands; by twenty thousand each
vīsatisahassehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound numeral 'twenty thousand', likely used to indicate quantity or multitude in a descriptive or enumerative context, such as counting items, beings, or measures.

khīṇāsavabhikkhūhi.meaning_2: by monks who have destroyed the effluents; by arahants
khīṇāsavabhikkhūhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental plural form of the compound noun denoting arahant monks, used in contexts praising or referring to enlightened monastics.

saṭṭhiyojanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a numeral compound indicating a distance measure of sixty yojanas, approximately 1200 kilometers.

nikkhantabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of departure; condition of having left; state of being gone out
nikkhantabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound nikkhanta-bhāva, where nikkhanta (past participle of nikkhamati) qualifies bhāva. The form nikkhantabhāvaṃ indicates the object of a verb, referring to the abstract state or condition of departure or having departed.

nānaggarasabhojanassa.meaning_2: of one not eating finest delicacies; of one abstaining from luxurious foods
nānaggarasabhojanassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in genitive singular, describing someone who does not partake in the choicest foods or luxurious meals, likely in the context of ascetic practice or restraint.

vīsatisahassabhikkhuparivāro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'vīsati sahassa' (twenty thousand) modifies 'bhikkhuparivāro' (monks' retinue), referring to a large group of twenty thousand monks in a monastic context.

dassanatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of seeing; for the purpose of vision; for the benefit of insight
dassanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in the dative singular, expressing purpose, commonly used in Buddhist texts to indicate intent related to spiritual seeing or insight, as in practices aimed at realization.

tāvassa.grammar: pron, gen dat sg of ta
tāvassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tāvassa is the genitive/dative singular of the demonstrative pronoun 'ta' (that), often used possessively as 'his' or 'of him'. Without the provided sentences, the exact contextual nuance cannot be specified further, but it typically indicates possession or relation to the aforementioned entity.

uttamabhojanassa.meaning_2: of the best food; of supreme nourishment
uttamabhojanassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in genitive singular, likely used in a context referring to possession or relation to the highest quality of food or eating.

buddhaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttāya.meaning_2: connected with the qualities of a Buddha; related to the virtues of the Awakened One
buddhaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound used as a feminine noun in the dative case, likely referring to a sutta or section in the canon connected with the Buddha's qualities, as in the title of a text or chapter.

sañjātappasādaṃ.meaning_2: arisen lack of confidence; produced distrust; resulting suspicion
sañjātappasādaṃ.construction: saṃ + √jan > jā + ta + a + pa + √sad > sād + *a
sañjātappasādaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sañjāta' (arisen) modifies 'appasāda' (lack of confidence), indicating a state of distrust that has arisen, often in a religious or doctrinal context in Pāḷi texts.

nigrodhasakkassa.meaning_2: capable banyan tree; proficient banyan tree
nigrodhasakkassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nigrodhasakka appears to be a compound in genitive singular, likely 'of the capable banyan tree' or similar, based on the dictionary entries for nigrodha (banyan tree) and sakka (capable). Without the full sentence context, the precise usage is inferred from the components.

paṭijagganavidhiṃ.meaning_2: method of attending to needs; method of nursing or caring for; method of repair
paṭijagganavidhiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where paṭijaggana (care, nursing) qualifies vidhi (method), indicating a prescribed procedure for looking after or maintaining something, likely in a monastic or ethical context given the Vinaya association.

gandhapupphahatthā.meaning_2: having hands or trunks full of fragrant flowers
gandhapupphahatthā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound used as an epithet, likely for an elephant, indicating it holds fragrant flowers in its trunk (hattha meaning trunk in this context).

sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍite.meaning_2: adorned with all ornaments; decorated with all jewellery
sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective used as a masculine locative singular form, describing something adorned or decorated with all kinds of ornaments or jewellery. The base form is derived from the compound 'sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍita', where 'paṭimaṇḍita' is the past participle of 'paṭimaṇḍeti'.

daharadahare.meaning_2: young boy; youth; small boy; short boy
daharadahare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form daharadahare appears to be a sandhi compound in the locative singular case, likely meaning 'in a young young' or emphatically 'in a very young boy/youth', combining two instances of 'dahara' for intensification. Without contextual sentences, the exact nuance is unclear, but it fits patterns of reduplicative compounds for emphasis in Pāḷi.

nāgaradārake.meaning_2: young boy from the city; urban boy
nāgaradārake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound where nāgara ('belonging to a town') modifies dāraka ('young boy'), indicating a boy from or associated with the city. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

nāgaradārikāyo.meaning_2: girl from the city; urban maiden
nāgaradārikāyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nāgaradārikāyo is the feminine nominative singular of the compound, used to refer to a specific urban girl in context.

rājakumārikāyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form rājakumārikāyo appears to be a nominative singular with an unusual -yo ending, possibly a scribal error for standard -ā or a dialectal variant; it refers to a princess or royal female figure in the context.

gandhapupphacuṇṇādīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'beginning with fragrant flowers and powders', listing items such as perfumes, flowers, powders, and similar substances, likely in a ritual or medicinal context.

vīsatisahassakhīṇāsavaparivuto.meaning_2: surrounded by twenty thousand who have destroyed the effluents
vīsatisahassakhīṇāsavaparivuto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective, likely referring to the Buddha or a similar figure accompanied by twenty thousand arahants. The form appears in instrumental plural context in texts like the Mahāparinibbāna Sutta, indicating those who have eradicated mental defilements.

mānajātikā.grammar: adj, in comps, from māna + jātika
mānajātikā.meaning_2: of the nature of pride; characterized by conceit
mānajātikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound mānajātika combines 'māna' (pride) with 'jātika' (of the nature of), indicating something inherently prideful or egotistical in character. Used adjectivally in compounds to describe qualities or types related to conceit.

daharataro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Comparative form of 'dahara' (young) using the suffix '-tara'; used to indicate a greater degree of youthfulness or junior status in comparison.

pādapaṃsuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pāda' (foot) qualifies 'paṃsu' (dust), indicating dust located on or associated with the foot. Common in Pāḷi for descriptive compounds.

okiramāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form okiramāno is the masculine nominative singular of the present participle, often used to describe an agent performing the action of scattering or sprinkling down.

kāḷadevalassa.meaning_2: of Kāḷadevala; of the dark ascetic
kāḷadevalassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'kāḷadevala' meaning 'the dark ascetic', likely referring to the ascetic named Devala with the epithet 'kāḷa' (dark or black). In context, it denotes possession or relation to this figure, possibly in a narrative involving ascetics.

vandanatthaṃ.meaning_2: purpose of paying respect; object of honouring
vandanatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vandanatthaṃ is the accusative singular, indicating the purpose or object of veneration, derived from vandana (act of worshipping) and attha (benefit/purpose); the negative anattha in dictionary entries suggests contrast but is not directly applicable here.

paṭhamavandanā.meaning_2: first homage; initial adoration; prime worship
paṭhamavandanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'paṭhama' (first) modifies 'vandanā' (homage), likely referring to the initial act of paying respects in a ritual or grammatical context within Vinaya texts.

vappamaṅgaladivase.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular of the compound 'vappamaṅgala-divasa', combining the ploughing festival with 'day'. 'Vappa' refers to the agricultural season or act of sowing, linked to the root √vap.

aparivattanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aparivattanaṃ is the accusative singular neuter of the action noun derived from the verb aparivattati ('does not turn around'), formed by prefixing apa- (indicating negation or away) to parivattati. This suggests a concept of immutability or non-transformation, common in doctrinal contexts like the unchanging nature of dhamma or self.

dutiyavandanā.meaning_2: second veneration; second act of homage
dutiyavandanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound likely refers to a secondary or repeated act of paying homage, possibly in a ritual or grammatical context given the ordinal 'dutiya'.

tatiyavandanāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a compound noun with iti appended, likely functioning as a quotative or emphatic marker indicating 'the third adoration' or a specific term in a list of venerations.

ekasākiyopi.meaning_2: even a single one of the Sakyan clan
ekasākiyopi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound used emphatically, likely meaning 'even one of the Sakyans' or 'even a single Sakyan,' common in Pāḷi to highlight uniqueness or minimal instance in a narrative context, such as referring to the Buddha or a clansman.

sikhāpatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a compound noun meaning 'begging bowl with a crest' or 'crested alms bowl', combining 'sikhā' (crest, top-knot) and 'patta' (alms bowl).

temitukāmova.meaning_2: desiring to measure; wishing to estimate
temitukāmova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi form resolving to 'te + imitukāmā + iva', where 'imitukāmā' is the feminine nominative singular of an adjective formed from the desiderative infinitive 'imituṃ' (to measure) with 'kāma' (desire), equivalent to 'desiring to measure'. Used as an indeclinable simile in context, comparing something to a woman who wishes to measure or estimate.

atemitukāmassa.meaning_2: desiring not to die; wishing for non-death
atemitukāmassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a genitive singular form of a compound adjective 'atemitukāma', meaning one who desires not to die. The prefix 'a-' negates, 'te' likely refers to 'you' (2nd person), and 'mitu' is the inf. stem of √mī (to die), with 'kāma' meaning desire. Used in contexts of reluctance to death or immortality wishes.

ekabindumattampi.meaning_2: even only a drop; just a single drop
ekabindumattampi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an emphatic adverbial compound formed by combining 'eka' (one, single), 'bindumatta' (as much as a drop), and 'api' (even, just), likely resulting from sandhi resolution of 'ekabindumattā + api' where the final 'ā' is elided before 'a'. It conveys a minimal quantity with emphasis, often in contexts denying or highlighting insignificance.

vīsatisahassabhikkhuparivuto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound functioning as an adjective, likely modifying a masculine noun such as 'buddho' in context, indicating accompaniment by a large monastic assembly.

aggahosi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a periphrastic aorist construction combining the aorist of gaṇhāti (to take) with hoti (is/becomes), indicating a past action completed before another past event. The form aggahosi means 'had taken' in narrative contexts.

kulanagare.meaning_2: town of the family; family town; city belonging to the clan
kulanagare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound kulanagara combines 'kula' (family, household) with 'nagara' (town, city), likely denoting a town associated with or belonging to a particular family or clan. Without the specific sentences provided, the exact contextual usage cannot be precisely determined, but it fits common Pāḷi compound patterns for relational nouns.

ekabuddhassapi.meaning_2: of even one Buddha; of the solitary Buddha
ekabuddhassapi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound form of 'eka-buddhassa api', where 'ekabuddhassa' is the genitive singular of 'ekabuddho' (a single or solitary Buddha), and 'api' adds an emphatic or concessive nuance like 'even'. The form 'ekabuddhassapi' results from sandhi resolution in compounds, common in Pāli for genitive constructions with indeclinables.

piṇḍacārikavattaṃ.meaning_2: custom of alms-collecting; practice of going for alms
piṇḍacārikavattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where piṇḍacārika (alms-collector) modifies vatta (custom, practice), referring to the monastic routine of begging for food, a key discipline in Buddhist Vinaya.

niviṭṭhagehato.meaning_2: from the house where one is settled; from the dwelling of the entrenched
niviṭṭhagehato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an ablative singular form of the compound niviṭṭhageha, likely meaning 'from the house in which one is established or settled.' The first member niviṭṭha functions as an adjective modifying geha, indicating a dwelling associated with being 'settled down' or 'entrenched.' Without the full sentence context, the precise usage (e.g., literal house or metaphorical craving) cannot be determined, but it often implies attachment in doctrinal contexts.

dvibhūmakatibhūmakādīsu.meaning_2: in (places) etc. beginning with (buildings) having two floors and (those) having how many floors
dvibhūmakatibhūmakādīsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a complex sandhi compound used in the locative case plural, likely referring to various types of multi-storied buildings or structures, starting with two-story ones and extending to those with any number of stories, and so on. The form suggests an indeclinable ending -su indicating location 'in/among'.

dassanabyāvaṭo.meaning_2: engaged in seeing; occupied with vision; busy with insight

pabbājetukāmo.grammar: masc, agent cp from pabbājeti + kāma
pabbājetukāmo.meaning_2: desiring ordination; wishing to be ordained
pabbājetukāmo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a compound agent noun where pabbājetar (one who ordains) is combined with kāma (desiring), indicating someone who wishes to receive ordination as a novice (sāmaṇera). In Vinaya contexts, this typically refers to a candidate eager to go forth into the monastic life.

avisahamāno.meaning_2: not being able (to); not being capable (of); not daring (to); not having the courage (to)
avisahamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form avisahamāno is the masculine nominative singular of the present participle avisahamāna, combining the negative prefix a- (from na) with visahamāna ('daring, venturing'), thus indicating inability or lack of daring. The -māno ending agrees with a masculine subject in the sentence context.

vīsatisahassasamaṇaparivutaṃ.grammar: sandhi, nt + card + card + masc + pp
vīsatisahassasamaṇaparivutaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular neuter form of a bahuvrīhi compound describing something (likely a place or event) surrounded by twenty thousand ascetics (monks). The numeral 'vīsati sahassa' means 20,000, with 'vīsati' as feminine stem agreeing with 'sahassa' (thousand). 'Parivutaṃ' is the past participle of parivāreti, indicating being surrounded or accompanied.

brahmarūpavaṇṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where brahma (divine/holy) modifies rūpavaṇṇa (form-appearance). In Buddhist contexts, it likely refers to the sublime or divine appearance of a holy figure or state, emphasizing materiality and beauty in a spiritual sense.

vaṭṭānugataṃ.meaning_2: gone in the cycle of existence; conformed to saṃsāra; subject to rebirth
vaṭṭānugataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'vaṭṭa' refers to the cycle of rebirths (saṃsāra), 'anu' indicates conformity or following, and 'gataṃ' is the past participle of √gam meaning 'gone'. In Buddhist contexts, it describes one who has entered or is bound by the wheel of existence, as opposed to one who has escaped it.

lokuttaradāyajjassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive singular form indicating 'of the transcendental inheritance'. In Buddhist contexts, this likely refers to the spiritual legacy or attainment beyond worldly existence, such as the supramundane path or enlightenment.

rāhulakumāraṃ.meaning_2: Prince Rāhula; son of the Buddha
rāhulakumāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound referring to Rāhula, the Buddha's son, often addressed as a prince or young monk in the texts.

dukkarakārikakāle.meaning_2: at the time of practicing austerities; at the occasion of extreme asceticism
dukkarakārikakāle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where the locative singular of dukkarakārikā ('practice of austerities') combines with the locative singular of kāla ('time'), indicating 'at the time of the practice of austerities'. The sandhi likely involves elision or vowel adjustment between the two words.

piyasahāyakassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form piyasahāyakassa is the genitive singular of piyasahāyaka, indicating possession or relation, e.g., 'of the dear friend'. The -ka suffix denotes an agent or attributive form, emphasizing companionship.

uppannabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of having arisen; condition of being born
uppannabhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'uppanna' (past participle of uppajjati, 'arisen') qualifies 'bhāva' (state, condition), denoting the state or condition of having arisen or been born. The form 'uppannabhāvaṃ' is accusative singular, likely used in a phrase like 'uppannabhāvaṃ akkhāsi' meaning 'declared the arisen state' or similar, in a doctrinal context such as rebirth or manifestation.

balavapaccūsasamaye.meaning_2: at the time of intense early morning
balavapaccūsasamaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a locative singular sandhi compound of 'balava' (intensified form of balavant, meaning 'intense' or 'powerful') and 'paccūsasamaye' (early morning time). The sandhi resolves the final -a of balava with the initial p of paccūsasamaye, resulting in the form seen. Likely used adverbially to indicate 'at the intense or powerful early morning time,' possibly referring to the potency of dawn practices in a religious or ritual context.

āgamanatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of coming; for the sake of arrival
āgamanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where āgamana ('coming, arrival') serves as the upapada to attha ('purpose'), forming 'purpose of coming', and the entire form is in dative singular to express purpose. Used adverbially to indicate intent or reason for approaching.

pañcacattālīsayojanaṭṭhāne.meaning_2: at the place of forty-five yojanas
pañcacattālīsayojanaṭṭhāne.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound indicating location. It denotes a distance of forty-five yojanas (approximately 900 km), likely referring to a geographical point in a narrative context such as a journey in Pāli texts.

koṭisanthārena.meaning_2: with a ten-millionfold spreading; with immeasurable hospitality
koṭisanthārena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form koṭisanthārena is an instrumental singular of a tatpuruṣa compound koṭisanthāra, where koṭi (ten million) modifies santhāra (spreading, hospitality). It likely denotes an immense or countless degree of reception or covering, used figuratively to emphasize abundance in context.

aṭṭhārasahiraññakoṭīhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a compound noun denoting a quantity of gold, likely used in a context of vast wealth or offering, such as in descriptions of donations or treasures in Buddhist texts.

asītimahātherānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Genitive plural form of the compound 'asītimahāthera', referring to a group of eighty senior monks or elders in a monastic context.

pāṭiyekkasannivesane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a state of individual immersion or secluded dwelling, likely in a meditative or isolated context, combining separateness with sinking/immersion.

ekakūṭāgāradvikūṭāgārahaṃsavaṭṭakadīghas.meaning_2: in the manner of a single-peaked building, a double-peaked building, a goose-circle, a long hall, a pavilion, etc.
ekakūṭāgāradvikūṭāgārahaṃsavaṭṭakadīghas.family_compound: eka kūṭāgāra dvi kūṭāgāra haṃsavaṭṭaka dīgha sālā maṇḍapa ādi divasa
ekakūṭāgāradvikūṭāgārahaṃsavaṭṭakadīghas.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial compound ending in -vasena, indicating manner or kind, listing types of structures or designs beginning with the examples provided.

sesasenāsanāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sesasenāsanāni appears to be a scribal error or sandhi variant for senāsanāni, the neuter accusative plural of senāsana, commonly used in Pāḷi texts to refer to monastic dwellings or accommodations in the context of Vinaya rules.

pokkharaṇīcaṅkamanarattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānā.meaning_2: ponds, walking meditation paths, sleeping places, daytime meditation places
pokkharaṇīcaṅkamanarattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound enumerating monastic facilities: water lily ponds, walking paths for meditation, places for night rest, and spots for daytime meditation practice. The ending -āni indicates nominative or accusative plural neuter, likely in a list of provisions or requisites in a Vinaya or monastic context.

aṭṭhārasakoṭipariccāgena.meaning_2: by the sacrifice of eighteen koṭis; by the renunciation of eighteen ten-millions
aṭṭhārasakoṭipariccāgena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound denoting the sacrifice or giving up of eighteen koṭis (i.e., 180,000,000), likely in a context of great renunciation or offering as in Buddhist narratives.

mahābhikkhusaṅghaparivuto.meaning_2: surrounded by a large community of monks
mahābhikkhusaṅghaparivuto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound adjective describes someone or something encircled by a vast monastic assembly, emphasizing grandeur and accompaniment in a religious context.

sāvatthinagaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sāvatthī' specifies the city named Sāvatthī. The form 'sāvatthinagaraṃ' is the accusative singular, likely used as the object in the sentence.

vihāramahaṃ.meaning_2: I (am the one who has gone to the monastery); I (am the one who resides in the monastery)
vihāramahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound formed by combining the accusative singular of vihāra ('monastery' or 'dwelling') with the pronoun ahaṃ ('I'), likely functioning as an accusative object in a sentence like 'I see the monastery' or 'I go to the monastery'. Without the full sentence, the exact contextual meaning is inferred from common usage.

jetavanappavisanadivase.meaning_2: on the day of entering Jeta's wood; on the day of arrival at Jetavana
jetavanappavisanadivase.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative form of a tatpuruṣa compound used adverbially to indicate the time of an event, likely the Buddha's arrival at the Jetavana monastery in Sāvatthī.

kumārasatehi.meaning_2: hundred young boys; group of one hundred youngsters
kumārasatehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a numeral, indicating a group of one hundred kumāras (young boys or princes). The form kumārasatehi shows instrumental plural, likely modifying a preceding or following noun in a sentence describing association with such a group.

pañcavaṇṇavatthasamujjalāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective used as a neuter noun in the accusative plural, likely referring to shining or resplendent garments or robes that are multicoloured with five hues, common in descriptions of luxurious or divine attire in Pāli texts.

dhajasatāni.meaning_2: having a hundred flags; consisting of a hundred banners
dhajasatāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as a neuter noun in the nominative or accusative plural, likely referring to multiple items or entities characterized by having one hundred flags or banners, such as standards or groups.

mahāsubhaddā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from mahā 'great' intensifying subhaddā 'very fortunate', likely a feminine proper name referring to a queen or auspicious figure in Pāḷi texts.

seṭṭhidhītaro.meaning_2: daughters of wealthy men; daughters of bankers
seṭṭhidhītaro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the tatpuruṣa compound 'seṭṭhidhītar' (wealthy man's daughter), with sandhi resolution of 'dhītaro' from 'dhītara + o'. Used likely to denote a group of daughters from wealthy families in a narrative context.

kumārikāsatehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the tatpuruṣa compound kumārikāsata 'a hundred young girls', used to indicate accompaniment or means.

mātugāmasatehi.meaning_2: with a hundred women; with women by the hundred
mātugāmasatehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound mātugāmasata meaning 'a hundred women'. The word mātugāma means 'women' collectively, and sata 'hundred', forming a numeral compound. The form satehi reflects the neuter plural instrumental ending, common for numbers in Pāli.

puṇṇapātiyo.meaning_2: full vessel; brimming cup; receptacle filled to capacity
puṇṇapātiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound noun in nominative plural form, likely referring to vessels or cups that are full, possibly in a metaphorical or literal sense of abundance or completeness in a textual context.

ahatavatthanivattho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound adjective, likely modifying a masculine or neuter noun, indicating someone dressed in clean, new cloth. The form suggests a sandhi combination where 'ahatavattha' (new cloth) serves as the object of 'nivattho' (clothed in).

ahatavatthanivattheheva.meaning_1: in that very turning away from new cloth
ahatavatthanivattheheva.meaning_2: in that very turning away from new cloth; in the very act of refusing new garments
ahatavatthanivattheheva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a locative singular form of a compound 'ahatavatthanivatta' (new cloth + turning away), with 'eva' as an enclitic emphasizing 'just that'. The form 'nivatthe' suggests a nominalized locative from the future participle or abstract noun derived from nivattati (to turn away, refuse), common in Pāḷi for expressing 'in the matter of' or 'at the time of'. Likely used in a Vinaya context regarding monastic rules on refusing new robes.

seṭṭhisatehi.meaning_2: with one hundred wealthy men; with a hundred bankers
seṭṭhisatehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form resulting from sandhi resolution of seṭṭhi + satehi ('with a hundred wealthy men'). The ending -hi indicates emphasis or connection, common in lists or enumerations in Pāli texts.

suvaṇṇarasasekapiñjarāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound likely referring to cages or enclosures of reddish color associated with golden juice or nectar, possibly in a metaphorical or poetic context such as birdcages or ritual vessels; plural neuter form suggests objects.

apaṭisamāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form apaṭisamāya is the ablative singular of the adjective apaṭisamā, derived by prefixing 'a-' (negative) to paṭisamā ('having an equal'). It likely functions adverbially or in a compound, indicating 'without a counterpart' or 'incomparably'. No contextual sentence provided, so meaning is based on morphological analysis.

jetavanavihāraṃ.meaning_2: Jeta's monastery; the monastery in Sāvatthī known as Victor's Grove
jetavanavihāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of the compound name for the famous monastery donated by Anāthapiṇḍika in Sāvatthī, where the Buddha often resided and taught.

leṇatthañca.meaning_2: for the sake of shelter and security; for the purpose of refuge and benefit
leṇatthañca.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi form functioning as a compound adverb, combining 'leṇa' (shelter, security) with 'atthaṃ' (for the sake of, purpose) and 'ca' (and), likely indicating dual purposes of physical and spiritual refuge in a doctrinal context.

vihārānisaṃsaṃ.meaning_2: benefit of dwelling; advantage of monastery; profit from mode of living
vihārānisaṃsaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where vihāra (dwelling, monastery, etc.) is the upapada to ānisaṃsa (benefit, advantage). Without the sentence context, the precise nuance is unclear, but it likely refers to the benefits associated with monastic life or meditation practices in a Buddhist setting.

pāsādamaho.comment: [openrouter: qwen/qwen3-235b-a22b:free] A sandhi compound combining `pāsāda` (mansion, building) with `maha` (great, venerable) to denote a grand or revered edifice, likely used in a religious or royal context.

vihāramaho.meaning_2: great monastery; great dwelling; great residence
vihāramaho.comment: [openrouter: z-ai/glm-4.5-air:free] This is a compound noun combining 'vihāra' (monastery/dwelling) with 'mahā' (great), meaning 'great monastery' or 'great dwelling'. The form 'maho' instead of 'mahā' might indicate a specific grammatical form or variation common in compounds.

vihāramahepi.meaning_2: even in the great monastery; even in the great dwelling
vihāramahepi.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a sandhi compound. The word 'vihāramahā' likely refers to a 'great monastery' or 'great dwelling'. The particle 'api' adds the meaning of 'even' or 'also'.

catupaṇṇāsakoṭisaṅkhyaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word indicating a large numerical quantity, specifically fifty-four crore. The word 'catupaṇṇāsā' means fifty-four, 'koṭi' represents ten million, and 'saṅkhyā' means number or numeral. When combined, they form a very large number.

punabbasumitto.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a sandhi compound. The word "punabbasu" refers to a specific individual, and "mitta" means friend. Therefore, "punabbasumitto" translates to "friend of Punabbasu".

suvaṇṇiṭṭhakāsanthārena.meaning_2: a covering or flooring made of golden bricks; a beautiful brick covering
suvaṇṇiṭṭhakāsanthārena.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound. 'suvaṇṇa' means beautiful or golden. 'iṭṭhakā' means brick. 'santhāra' means covering or flooring. Therefore, the compound literally means 'a beautiful golden brick covering' or 'a covering of golden bricks'.

suvaṇṇaphālasanthārena.meaning_2: a couch or covering made of golden ploughshares
suvaṇṇaphālasanthārena.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound of 'suvaṇṇa' (golden), 'phāla' (ploughshare), and 'santhāra' (covering or bedding). It describes a luxurious or perhaps symbolic covering made from golden ploughshares.

tigāvutappamāṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word formed from 'tigāvuta' (measuring three gāvutas) and 'appamāṇa' (immeasurable). The combination suggests something whose immeasurable quality is expressed in terms of a measurement of three gāvutas. This could be a paradoxical or idiomatic expression, perhaps emphasizing the vastness or significance of something by relating it to a fixed measurement while simultaneously calling it immeasurable.

suvaṇṇahatthipadasanthārena.meaning_2: a spread (of a mat) like a golden elephant's footprint
suvaṇṇahatthipadasanthārena.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This compound word describes a mat or spread that is compared to a golden elephant's footprint. The 'suvaṇṇa' part means 'golden', 'hatthipada' means 'elephant footprint', and 'santhāra' means 'spread' or 'covering'. The combination suggests a luxurious or auspicious mat.

aḍḍhayojanappamāṇaṃ.meaning_2: approximately ten kilometres; lit. half a yojana
aḍḍhayojanappamāṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound of 'aḍḍha' (half) and 'yojana' (a unit of distance). Together, it signifies half a yojana, which is further explained as approximately ten kilometres.

gāvutappamāṇaṃ.meaning_2: a measure of length; quarter yojana
gāvutappamāṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] The word 'gāvuta' refers to a unit of distance. The suffix '-ppamāṇa' suggests an immeasurable or boundless extent, so 'gāvutappamāṇaṃ' likely means 'immeasurable gāvuta' or 'an extent comparable to immeasurable gāvuta'.

suvaṇṇakacchapasanthārena.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word. 'suvaṇṇa' means golden, 'kacchapa' means tortoise, and 'santhāra' means covering or flooring. The entire phrase likely refers to a golden tortoise-shaped covering or carpet.

aḍḍhagāvutappamāṇaṃ.meaning_2: half a gāvuta (a measure of distance)
aḍḍhagāvutappamāṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This compound word is formed by 'aḍḍha' (half) and 'gāvuta' (a measure of distance, a quarter of a yojana). Therefore, it means 'half a gāvuta'.

suvaṇṇakaṭṭisanthārena.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound. 'suvaṇṇa' means gold, and 'kaṭṭi' refers to a girdle or belt. Thus, 'suvaṇṇakaṭṭi' means a golden girdle or belt.

soḷasakarīsappamāṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This entry is for the cardinal number 'sixteen'.

kahāpaṇakoṭisanthārena.meaning_2: by a covering of ten million silver coins
kahāpaṇakoṭisanthārena.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word formed from 'kahāpaṇa' (silver coin), 'koṭi' (ten million), and 'santhāra' (covering/flooring). The instrumental plural ending '-ena' indicates 'by means of' or 'with'.

aṭṭhakarīsappamāṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is the cardinal number 'eight' used as a prefix in a compound word.

avijahitaṭṭhānameva.meaning_2: in the place/position which is not abandoned; in the uninterrupted position; in the very place that is not left
avijahitaṭṭhānameva.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] The word is a compound of 'avijahita' (not abandoned, uninterrupted), 'ṭhāna' (place, position), and the indeclinable 'eva' (indeed, only). The construction suggests an adverbial usage, emphasizing the 'place' which is 'not abandoned' or 'uninterrupted'. The meaning is best captured as 'in the very place that is not abandoned' or 'in the uninterrupted position'.

mahābodhimaṇḍe.meaning_2: great seat of awakening; great bodhi throne; great platform of enlightenment
mahābodhimaṇḍe.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a three-part compound (bahubbīhi) referring to the sacred seat or platform where the Buddha attained enlightenment. The 'great' (mahā) prefix emphasizes the supreme importance of this enlightenment seat, distinguishing it as the specific site of the Buddha's awakening under the Bodhi tree.

sabbaññutappattito.meaning_2: attainment of omniscience; reaching omniscience; acquisition of infinite knowledge
sabbaññutappattito.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word is a compound of sabbaññutā (omniscience) + patti (attainment), referring to the achievement or realization of complete, all-encompassing knowledge, typically associated with the enlightenment of a Buddha.

mahāparinibbānamañcā.meaning_2: the bed of the great final emancipation; the couch of the great final nirvana
mahāparinibbānamañcā.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound noun referring to the bed or couch on which the Buddha attained his final nirvana (parinibbāna). The term combines 'great' (mahā), 'final emancipation' (parinibbāna), and 'bed' (mañca), specifically denoting the historical bed associated with the Buddha's passing.

sabbajātakāni.meaning_2: all birth stories; complete collection of Jātakas; every Jātaka tale
sabbajātakāni.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound word meaning 'all the Jātakas' or 'the complete collection of birth stories'. The Jātakas are stories of the Buddha's previous lives, forming an important part of Buddhist literature. The plural form 'sabbajātakāni' indicates multiple or all of these stories collectively.

apaṇṇakajātakavaṇṇanā.meaning_2: the commentary on the Apaṇṇaka Jātaka; the exegesis of the Incontrovertible Birth Story
apaṇṇakajātakavaṇṇanā.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound word referring to the specific commentary on the first Jātaka story in the Pāḷi canon. The Apaṇṇaka Jātaka (Jātaka 1) is known as 'The Incontrovertible Truth' or 'The Guaranteed Teaching' story, and this word specifically refers to its traditional commentary.

apaṇṇakadhammadesanaṃ.meaning_2: teaching of the unquestionable Dhamma; discourse on the incontrovertible truth
apaṇṇakadhammadesanaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound term describing a type of Dhamma teaching that is fundamentally true and beyond dispute. The 'apaṇṇaka' element emphasizes the irrefutable nature of the teaching, suggesting it leads to certain, guaranteed results when practiced correctly, as opposed to speculative or doubtful doctrines.

jetavanamahāvihāre.meaning_2: great monastery of Jetavana; Jetavana Great Monastery
jetavanamahāvihāre.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound of two proper names: Jetavana (the famous monastery in Sāvatthī donated by Anāthapiṇḍika) and Mahāvihāra (Great Monastery), likely referring to a specific important monastery complex at the Jetavana site.

aññatitthiyasāvake.meaning_2: disciple of another sect; follower of another religion; adherent of another teacher
aññatitthiyasāvake.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound noun (samāsa) consisting of three elements: añña (other/different) + titthiya (sect/religious group) + sāvaka (disciple/follower). It refers specifically to followers or disciples of non-Buddhist religious traditions, contrasting with Buddhist disciples.

mālāgandhavilepanañceva.meaning_2: garlands, perfumes and oils; garlands, perfumes and unguents; floral decorations, fragrances and ointments
mālāgandhavilepanañceva.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word appears to be part of a compound noun phrase 'mālāgandhavilepanañceva' where 'ñceva' represents sandhi of 'ca + iva' or 'ca + eva'. The compound refers to luxurious items typically offered to honored persons - flowers/garlands (mālā), perfumes/scents (gandha), and ointments/cosmetics (vilepana).

sappitelamadhuphāṇitavatthacchādanāni.meaning_2: clothes anointed with ghee, oil, honey, and molasses; garments smeared with clarified butter, oil, honey, and treacle
sappitelamadhuphāṇitavatthacchādanāni.family_compound: sappi tela madhu phāṇita vattha acchādana
sappitelamadhuphāṇitavatthacchādanāni.construction: sappi + tela + madhu + phāṇita + vattha + acchādana
sappitelamadhuphāṇitavatthacchādanāni.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This appears to be a compound describing luxurious or medicinal garments treated with various substances. In context, it likely refers to special cloths used in medical treatments or royal contexts where fabrics were anointed with these substances for therapeutic or ceremonial purposes.

nisajjādose.meaning_2: fault in sitting; error regarding sitting posture; defect in the manner of sitting
nisajjādose.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The compound appears to refer to some fault or error related to sitting posture or the manner of sitting, possibly in a monastic or meditative context where proper posture is important.

aññatitthiyasāvakā.meaning_2: disciple of another religious teacher; adherent of another religion; follower of another sect
aññatitthiyasāvakā.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The compound consists of three elements: añña (other/different), titthiya (ford/religious sect), and sāvaka (disciple/hearer). It refers specifically to followers of non-Buddhist religious traditions, contrasting them with Buddhist disciples.

puṇṇacandasassirikaṃ.meaning_2: resplendent like the full moon; having the glory of the full moon; full-moon splendiferous
puṇṇacandasassirikaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a three-part compound adjective describing something with the glorious, resplendent quality of a full moon. The word combines 'full moon' (puṇṇacanda) with 'splendid/glorious' (sassirika) to create an intensified meaning of radiant brilliance.

lakkhaṇānubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.meaning_2: adorned with major and minor characteristics; decorated with distinguishing marks and secondary features
lakkhaṇānubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound adjective describing something (likely a Buddha or divine being) that is adorned with both the 32 major physical characteristics (lakkhaṇa) and 80 minor characteristics (anubyañjana) of a great person as described in Buddhist texts.

byāmappabhāparikkhittaṃ.meaning_2: encircled by a halo extending around; surrounded by a radiant aura
byāmappabhāparikkhittaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a bahubbīhi compound describing something (likely the Buddha) that is surrounded or encircled by a radiant halo (byāmappabhā). The past participle 'parikkhitta' (thrown around, encircled) functions adjectivally in this compound structure.

āveḷāveḷā.meaning_2: wreath upon wreath; garland upon garland
āveḷāveḷā.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This appears to be a sandhi compound of āveḷā (wreath/garland) + eva (emphatic particle meaning 'indeed' or 'just'). The repetition suggests an emphatic meaning like 'wreath upon wreath' or 'garland indeed', possibly indicating multiple layers or an abundance of garlands. The context would determine if this is literal (multiple physical garlands) or metaphorical (abundant praise or honor).

yamakayamakā.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word appears in a reduplicated form 'yamakayamakā' which suggests an emphatic or distributive usage, possibly meaning 'in pairs' or 'twin by twin'. This is likely an adjectival form describing something that occurs in pairs or has a twin nature.

ghanabuddharasmiyo.meaning_2: solid/dense rays from the Buddha; compact rays of the Buddha
ghanabuddharasmiyo.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word appears to be a compound where 'ghana' (solid/dense) qualifies 'buddharasmi' (Buddha's rays), suggesting rays that are particularly intense, concentrated, or substantial rather than ethereal or diffuse.

taruṇasīho.meaning_2: young lion; young hero; brave young man
taruṇasīho.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] A bahubbīhi (descriptive) compound meaning 'having the qualities of a young lion' - referring to a brave, vigorous young man. The compound combines 'taruṇa' (young) with 'sīha' (lion), creating a metaphorical expression for youthful strength and courage.

pāvussakamegho.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This appears to be a compound of pāvussaka (rainy season) and megha (cloud), forming 'rainy season cloud' or 'monsoon cloud'. The word is in nominative singular form, likely serving as the subject of a sentence describing a cloud characteristic of the monsoon period.

ratanadāmaṃ.meaning_2: jewel wreath; garland of gems; necklace of precious stones
ratanadāmaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The compound 'ratanadāma' combines 'ratana' (jewel/gem) with 'dāma' (wreath/garland), creating a term for an ornamental necklace or garland made of precious gems. In context, this likely refers to a luxurious piece of jewelry worn as adornment.

nānānayavicittaṃ.meaning_2: diverse in methods and variegated; various in approach and decorated; manifold in inference and embellished
nānānayavicittaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound adjective combining three elements: nānā (various/diverse), naya (method/approach/inference), and vicitta (variegated/decorated). It describes something that is both diverse in its methods/approaches and variegated or decorated in appearance. The compound suggests richness and variety both in methodology and visual presentation.

aññatitthiyasaraṇaṃ.meaning_2: the refuge of another sect; the shelter of other religions
aññatitthiyasaraṇaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The compound combines 'aññatitthiya' (belonging to another sect) with 'saraṇa' (refuge/shelter), creating a tatpurusa compound meaning 'the refuge of another sect'. In context, this likely refers to taking refuge in or seeking shelter from religious traditions outside of Buddhism.

gatakāle.meaning_2: time that has passed; past time; gone time
gatakāle.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a kammadhāraya compound where 'gata' (gone/past) functions as an adjective modifying 'kāla' (time), creating the meaning 'past time' or 'time that has gone by'.

mūlaṭṭhāneyeva.meaning_2: original place; root position; fundamental location; primary site
mūlaṭṭhāneyeva.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word mūlaṭṭhāneyeva appears to be a compound of mūla (root, original, primary) + ṭhāna (place, position) in the locative case with the emphatic particle eva. The context suggests a meaning of 'right at the original place' or 'exactly at the root position', emphasizing the fundamental or primary location of something.

gahitasaraṇaṃ.meaning_2: taking refuge; having grasped refuge; seeking shelter
gahitasaraṇaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a kammadhāraya compound where 'gahita' (taken, grasped) functions as an adjective modifying 'saraṇa' (refuge). The compound describes someone who has taken or grasped refuge, typically in the context of going for refuge to the Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha.

aññatitthiyasaraṇameva.meaning_2: refuge of another sect; shelter of another religion
aññatitthiyasaraṇameva.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a sandhi compound formed from 'aññatitthiya' (belonging to another sect) and 'saraṇa' (refuge/shelter). The word appears to be in the accusative case, functioning as the object in the sentence. The context suggests a reference to taking refuge in or seeking shelter from other religious traditions outside of Buddhism.

aparimitakappakoṭiyo.meaning_2: immeasurable aeons of ten millions; countless millions of aeons
aparimitakappakoṭiyo.construction: na > a + pari + √mā > mi + ta + kappa + koṭi
aparimitakappakoṭiyo.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound describing an immense, immeasurable period of time. The word combines 'immeasurable' (aparimita) with 'aeons' (kappa) and 'ten million' (koṭi), creating the sense of countless millions of cosmic time periods. In Buddhist context, this typically refers to the vast spans of time required for spiritual development and accumulation of merit.

pavattitavacīsucaritānubhāvena.meaning_2: power of good verbal conduct that has been practiced; majesty of good speech behavior that has been maintained; splendor resulting from well-practiced virtuous speech
pavattitavacīsucaritānubhāvena.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a complex compound (samāsa) consisting of three elements: pavattita (past participle 'practiced/maintained'), vacīsucarita ('good verbal conduct'), and ānubhāva ('power/majesty'). The compound describes the majestic power or splendid effect that results from having consistently practiced virtuous speech behavior.

dibbagandhagandhitaṃ.meaning_2: perfumed with divine fragrance; scented with heavenly perfume
dibbagandhagandhitaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a bahubbīhi compound describing something that is perfumed or scented with divine fragrance. The word combines 'divine' (dibba) with 'fragrance' (gandha) and the past participle 'perfumed' (gandhita), creating an adjective meaning 'perfumed with divine scent'.

nānāgandhapūritaṃ.meaning_2: filled with various scents; perfumed with many fragrances
nānāgandhapūritaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a bahubbīhi compound adjective describing something that is filled or permeated with various fragrances. The word pūrita functions as the final element meaning 'filled with', while nānāgandha serves as the object of that filling - 'various scents'. The compound as a whole modifies a noun (likely implied or mentioned in the broader context).

ratanakaraṇḍakaṃ.meaning_2: jewel casket; gem box; treasure basket
ratanakaraṇḍakaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] A compound word meaning 'jewel casket' or 'gem box', likely referring to a container used for storing precious jewels or treasures. The -ka suffix may indicate a diminutive or specialized form of a container.

mukhapadumaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a bahubbīhi (possessive) compound describing something that has the quality of a lotus at the mouth. The word appears to be describing a person or being whose mouth is like a lotus, suggesting beauty, purity, or pleasant speech.

paṭicchādetuṃ.meaning_2: to cover; to conceal; to hide
paṭicchādetuṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The infinitive form paṭicchādetuṃ shows the verbal action of covering or concealing in its abstract, goal-oriented sense. This is a causative formation from the root √chad (to cover), with the prefix pati- adding a sense of 'against' or 'in return', giving the meaning of covering something up or hiding it from view.

pasannānantiādīhi.meaning_2: by those who have faith, by those who say 'thus', by those who are beginning with, etc.
pasannānantiādīhi.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a sandhi compound combining multiple elements: pasanna (faithful ones) + iti (thus/saying) + ādi (beginning with/and so on). The -hi ending indicates instrumental plural ('by means of' or 'by'). The word appears to describe a group of people characterized by faith, affirmation ('thus'), and other similar qualities.

ratanattayaguṇe.meaning_2: qualities of the Triple Gem; virtues of the Three Treasures; characteristics of the Buddha, Dhamma and Saṅgha
ratanattayaguṇe.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound word consisting of 'ratanattaya' (Triple Gem) and 'guṇa' (qualities/virtues). In context, it likely refers to the excellent qualities or virtues possessed by the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha collectively.

uttamaguṇehi.meaning_2: highest qualities; supreme virtues; excellent characteristics
uttamaguṇehi.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word is in instrumental plural (uttamaguṇehi), meaning 'with the highest qualities'. This is a kammadhāraya compound where uttama (supreme) qualifies guṇa (quality), indicating qualities of the highest degree or excellence.

nirayādīsu.meaning_2: in hells and so on; in hells, etc.
nirayādīsu.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word appears to be a sandhi compound of 'niraya' (hell) + 'ādīsu' (locative plural of ādi, meaning 'and so on', 'etc.'). In context, it likely refers to various unpleasant realms including hells and similar states of suffering.

apāyanibbattito.meaning_2: production of loss; generation of misery; arising of downfall
apāyanibbattito.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a tatpurusa compound where 'apāya' (loss/misery) modifies 'nibbatti' (production/becoming). The compound describes the generation or arising of states of loss or misery, likely referring to negative karmic consequences or unfortunate rebirths in Buddhist context.

mokkhavasena.meaning_2: by the power of liberation; through the means of freedom
mokkhavasena.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This appears to be a sandhi compound combining 'mokkha' (liberation) with 'vasena' (by means of, through the power of). The word likely functions adverbially, indicating that something is accomplished through or by means of liberation or freedom.

uttamavasena.grammar: ind, adv, in comps, instr sg of uttamavasa
uttamavasena.meaning_2: by the highest power; through supreme control; by ultimate authority
uttamavasena.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] The word appears to be a compound of uttama (supreme) + vasa (power/control) in instrumental case, functioning as an adverbial phrase meaning 'by means of supreme power/control'. The construction suggests authority or capability at the highest level.

abhāvadīpanatthaṃ.meaning_2: for the purpose of explaining the absence; for the purpose of illuminating the non-existence
abhāvadīpanatthaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a compound (samāsa) consisting of three elements: abhāva (absence/non-existence) + dīpana (illuminating/explaining) + attha (purpose). The compound functions as a dative/tatpurusa compound indicating the purpose or goal of an action - specifically the purpose of explaining or illuminating the concept of absence or non-existence.

dhammānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: meditation subject of recollection of the Dhamma; theme for reflection on the qualities of the teaching
dhammānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a complex compound term from Buddhist meditation practice, specifically referring to one of the six recollections (anussati) where a practitioner reflects on the qualities of the Dhamma as a meditation subject. The term combines four elements: dhamma (teaching), anussati (recollection), kamma (work/activity), and ṭhāna (place/subject), literally meaning 'the workplace/subject for the work of recollecting the Dhamma'.

saṅghānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: meditation subject of recollection of the (qualities of the) community; theme for reflection on the monastic order
saṅghānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a three-part compound (tappurisa + tappurisa) where 'kammaṭṭhāna' (meditation subject) is the main element, modified by 'saṅghānussati' (recollection of the community). In Buddhist meditation practice, this refers to one of the six recollections (cha anussati) used as objects for developing concentration and faith.

detītievamādīhipi.meaning_2: gives thus, etc. even; donates like this and so on, indeed
detītievamādīhipi.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This appears to be a complex sandhi compound combining a verb (deti) with particles (iti, api) and an adjective (evamādi). The meaning suggests a pattern of giving or donating that is being described with examples ('thus, etc.') and emphasized ('even, indeed'). The construction likely represents a rhetorical pattern found in doctrinal or instructional texts.

buddhānussatikammaṭṭhānādīnaṃ.meaning_2: of meditation subjects beginning with reflection on the Buddha; of the meditation subjects starting with recollection of the Buddha
buddhānussatikammaṭṭhānādīnaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a genitive plural form of a compound meaning 'beginning with the meditation subject of recollection of the Buddha'. The word functions as a bahubbīhi compound in context, indicating that these meditation subjects (including Buddha-recollection and others) belong to a particular category or are being referred to collectively.

sotāpattimaggādippadānaṃ.meaning_2: giving of the path of stream entry; offering of the stream-entry path
sotāpattimaggādippadānaṃ.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This is a tatpurusa compound where 'dāna' (giving/offering) is the main component, and 'sotāpattimagga' (path of stream entry) specifies what is being given. The word appears to be in accusative singular case, functioning as the object of a verbal action.

buddhānussatītievamādīhi.meaning_2: reflection on the Buddha, thus, and so on; mindfulness of the Buddha, in this way, etc.
buddhānussatītievamādīhi.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] This appears to be a sandhi combination of three separate words joined together: buddhānussati (feminine noun) + iti (indeclinable) + evamādi (adjective). The context suggests a listing or enumeration of meditation subjects, beginning with 'recollection of the Buddha' and continuing with other similar practices indicated by 'thus and so on'.

viraddhaggāhena.meaning_2: grasping at what is failed; holding onto failure; obsession with mistakes
viraddhaggāhena.comment: [deepseek: deepseek-chat] A compound noun formed from viraddha (failed, neglected) + gāha (grasping, holding). In context, this likely refers to the psychological state of clinging to or being obsessed with one's failures or mistakes rather than letting them go.

amanussapariggahite.meaning_2: not possessed by non-human beings; uninhabited
amanussapariggahite.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound of the negative prefix 'a-', the adjective 'amanussa' (non-human, uninhabited), and the past participle 'pariggahita' (possessed, acquired). In the context of a sentence, it would mean 'not possessed by non-human beings' or 'uninhabited'.

yakkhabhakkhā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound adjective meaning 'eating yakkhas' or 'feeding on yakkhas'. It is formed by combining the noun 'yakkha' (spirit, daemon) with the adjective 'bhakkha' (eating, feeding on).

mahāvināsaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word. 'mahā' means great, and 'vināsa' means destruction. Together, 'mahāvināsa' signifies a complete and utter destruction.

apaṇṇakaggāhaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound, meaning 'unquestionable' or 'guaranteed'. The base 'apaṇṇaka' is derived from 'na paṇṇa', literally 'not a fifth', implying something complete or absolute. Here it is used adjectivally with 'gāha' meaning grasp or conviction, indicating an unquestionable conviction.

ekaṃsikaggāhaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This refers to a definite or certain grasp, as opposed to a wavering or uncertain one. The root 'ekaṃsika' means 'one-sided' or 'definite', and when combined with 'gāha' (grasp), it signifies a firm and unwavering hold on an idea or concept.

aviraddhaggāhaṃ.meaning_2: unfailing grasp; unwavering holding; not missing the mark
aviraddhaggāhaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound of 'aviraddha' (unfailing, not missing) and 'gaha' (grasp, holding). In this context, it signifies a firm and unwavering grip or understanding, implying a thorough and accurate perception.

gahitamanussā.meaning_2: humans who are seized; captured men; enslaved people
gahitamanussā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word formed from 'gahitā' (past participle of 'gaṇhāti', meaning 'seized' or 'captured') and 'manussā' (plural of 'manussa', meaning 'humans' or 'people'). In the context of a sentence, it would refer to humans who have been seized, captured, or enslaved.

uttamasaraṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word. 'Uttama' means best or supreme, and 'saraṇa' means refuge. Therefore, 'uttamasaraṇa' means 'having the best refuge' or 'supreme refuge'.

takkaggahaṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound of 'takka' (reasoning, logic) and 'aggahaṇa' (not taking; lit. not grasping). However, given the usual meaning of 'gahaṇa' as 'taking' or 'grasping', and 'takka' as 'reasoning', the more likely interpretation of 'takkaggahaṇa' in context would be the 'taking or grasping of reasoning', implying the act of understanding or comprehending logical arguments. The dictionary entry for 'aggahaṇa' seems to be a typo and should likely be 'gahaṇa' in the compound form. Considering the common usage, 'gahaṇa' meaning 'taking' or 'grasping' is more appropriate.

gahitamanussānañca.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a sandhi compound. The word `gahitamanussānañca` is a genitive plural form. The `gahitamanussa` part refers to humans who have been 'taken' or 'grasped', possibly in a negative context of capture or possession, and the `ca` at the end signifies 'and'.

aparimitakālaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This compound is formed by 'aparimita' (immeasurable, limitless) and 'kāla' (time). It refers to a duration of time that cannot be measured or is without limit.

kaṅkhacchedanatthameva.meaning_2: removal of doubt; dispelling of uncertainty
kaṅkhacchedanatthameva.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound of 'kaṅkhā' (doubt) and 'accheda' (removal, literally 'not-cutting'). The construction indicates that 'accheda' is derived from the root √chid (to cut) with the prefix 'a-' (negation) and the suffix '-a' forming a noun. The resulting compound means the removal or cutting away of doubt.

himagabbhaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word formed from 'hima' (snow) and 'gabbha' (womb). In the context of clouds, it refers to the origin or dwelling place of snow. The provided dictionary entries for 'gabbha' include meanings like 'womb', 'embryo', 'room', and 'offspring', all of which imply an inner space or origin. Given 'hima' means snow, 'himagabbha' literally translates to 'snow-womb' or 'snow-chamber', suggesting the source or formation of snow.

paṭicchannakāraṇaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word formed from 'paṭicchanna' (covered, concealed) and 'kāraṇa' (cause, reason). In this context, it likely refers to a hidden or concealed reason behind an action or event.

bārāṇasinagare.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a sandhi compound of bārāṇasī (a city name) and nagara (city). The locative case ending is implied by the context of the sentence.

satthavāhakule.meaning_2: belonging to the family of a caravan leader
satthavāhakule.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This word is a compound of 'satthavāha' (leader of the caravan) and 'kula' (family). The meaning 'belonging to the family of a caravan leader' is derived from the grammatical analysis of the compound and the meanings of its constituent parts.

dasamāsaccayena.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] This is a compound word formed from 'dasa' (ten) and 'māsa' (months).

satthavāhaputto.meaning_2: son of a caravan leader; son of a company leader
satthavāhaputto.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite] The word is a compound of 'satthavāha' (leader of the caravan) and 'putta' (son). Therefore, it means 'son of a caravan leader'.

anupāyakusalo.meaning_2: unskilled in means; incompetent; lacking proper method
