The ending "-e" indicates the locative singular case, therefore the meaning is rendered as "in such and such seniority" or "in this or that seniority" pertaining to monks.

ṭhitavelāya.meaning_2: at the time of standing; at the time of remaining; when standing; when remaining
ṭhitavelāya.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] ṭhitavelāya is a compound word formed by ṭhita (past participle of tiṭṭhati, meaning 'stood', 'remained', 'standing') and velā (feminine noun, meaning 'time'). The word is an inflected form of the compound, specifically in the locative/dative/genitive singular case as indicated by the ending -āya. The combined meaning is 'at the time of standing/being/remaining'.

mandatarā.meaning_2: duller; slower; more stupid; softer; more tender; weaker; more undeveloped; lazier; more idle
mandatarā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] mandatarā is the feminine nominative singular form of the adjective mandatara. It is formed by adding the comparative suffix -tara to the adjective manda. The various meanings are derived from the different senses of manda (dull, soft, weak, lazy) expressed in a comparative degree.

mandataresu.meaning_2: in those who are more dull; among those who are slower; to the more stupid ones; in the weaker ones; among the more lazy; regarding the more undeveloped
mandataresu.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a compound adjective formed from 'manda' (dull, slow, tender, weak, lazy) and 'tara' (surpassing, going beyond). In this context, 'tara' functions as a comparative element, indicating 'more' or 'surpassing in'. The word 'mandataresu' is in the locative plural form, hence the meaning refers to 'in/among/to those who are more X'.

lekhāsaññāya.meaning_2: by perceiving writing; by knowing writing; through the perception of writing; by conceiving writing; with the idea of writing
lekhāsaññāya.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `lekhāsaññāya` is a compound formed from the feminine noun `lekhā` (meaning 'writing' or 'art of writing') and the gerund `saññāya` (meaning 'knowing' or 'perceiving'). As a compound including a gerund, it functions adverbially, indicating the means or manner by which something is done. The meaning is 'by perceiving writing' or 'by knowing writing'.

asukavassaggeti.meaning_2: to deem as such and such seniority; to attribute such and such seniority; to call by such and such seniority
asukavassaggeti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a present tense, 3rd singular denominative verb. It is formed from the compound noun 'asukavassagga', which combines 'asuka' (meaning 'such and such') and 'vassagga' (meaning 'seniority of monks'). The denominative verb 'asukavassaggeti' thus means to attribute or denote 'such and such seniority' to someone.

paṭippharanto.meaning_2: blasting back; lashing out; opposing; objecting
paṭippharanto.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word "paṭippharanto" is the nominative singular masculine form of the present participle "paṭippharanta". It is derived from the verb "paṭippharati", meaning to blast back, lash out, oppose, or object.

lāludāyi.meaning_2: giver of greed; greedy giver; one who gives rise to longing
lāludāyi.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a compound of `lālu` (an adjective meaning greedy, desirous, longing) and `dāyin` (a noun/adjective meaning giving, a giver, derived from the root `√dā`). It can be interpreted as 'one who gives greed or desire' (where `lālu` is the object of giving) or 'a giver who is greedy/desirous' (where `lālu` describes the giver).

lābhahāniṃ.meaning_2: gain and loss; profit and disadvantage
lābhahāniṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word "lābhahāniṃ" is the accusative singular of a feminine compound noun. It is formed by combining 'lābha' (gain, profit) and 'hāni' (loss, decrease), representing a common Pāḷi idiom for a pair of opposites, often referring to worldly fortunes or vicissitudes.

akāsiyevāti.meaning_2: only in the royal tax-gatherer, thus; indeed in the royal tax-gatherer, thus
akāsiyevāti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word akāsiyevāti is a sandhi compound of three components: akāsiye, eva, and iti. akāsiye is an inflected form of the masculine noun akāsiya (royal functionary to gather taxes); it is most likely the locative singular form (in the royal functionary) or possibly the vocative plural (O royal functionaries). eva is an indeclinable emphasizing particle meaning 'only; just; indeed; really'. iti is an indeclinable adverb meaning 'thus; like this; and so'. The sandhi formation follows the rule of 'e' + 'e' (from eva) becoming 'e', and then the final 'a' of 'akāsiyeva' combining with the initial 'i' of 'iti' to form 'āti' (akāsiyevāti).

hatthiassādīni.meaning_2: elephants and horses and so on; elephants and horses etc.
hatthiassādīni.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word hatthiassādīni is a compound formed by `hatthiassa` (elephants and horses) and `ādi` (and so on; etc.). The plural neuter ending `īni` indicates that it refers to multiple items of this category. The `ādi` suffix is commonly used in Pāḷi to indicate that the mentioned items are merely examples, and there are other similar items belonging to the same group or class.

maṇisuvaṇṇādīni.meaning_2: jewels, gold, and so on; jewels, gold, etc.
maṇisuvaṇṇādīni.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a sandhi compound formed from 'maṇi' (jewel), 'suvaṇṇa' (gold), and 'ādi' (etc.). The ending 'īni' indicates a neuter plural form, referring to 'jewels, gold, and other similar things'. The `lemma_2` is given as the nominative singular neuter of the compound.

agghāpetvā.meaning_2: having caused to be valued; having appraised; having estimated the price of
agghāpetvā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is an absolutive (also known as gerund) formed from the causative verb `agghāpeti`. The root `√aggh` means 'to be worth, to cost, to value'. The causative suffix `-āpe-` indicates causing someone or something to perform the action, or causing something to be in a certain state (in this case, to be valued or appraised). The suffix `-tvā` denotes an action completed before the main verb of the sentence, meaning 'having done X'.

bhaṇḍasāmikānaṃ.meaning_2: of the owners of the goods; to the owners of the goods
bhaṇḍasāmikānaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a compound of 'bhaṇḍa' (goods, merchandise, nt) and 'sāmika' (owner, masc). The compound 'bhaṇḍasāmika' means 'owner of goods'. The ending '-ānaṃ' indicates the genitive or dative plural case, hence 'of the owners of the goods' or 'to the owners of the goods'.

bhaṇḍānurūpameva.meaning_2: exactly according to the goods; just like the merchandise; suitably to the articles
bhaṇḍānurūpameva.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a sandhi compound formed from `bhaṇḍa` (neuter noun, meaning goods, merchandise), `anurūpaṃ` (an indeclinable adverb meaning suitably, in accordance with, which is the accusative singular of the adjective `anurūpa`), and the emphatic indeclinable particle `eva` (just, exactly). The final `ṃ` of `anurūpaṃ` elides before the initial `e` of `eva`.

lobhapakatitāya.grammar: ind, adv, fem instr sg of lobhapakati
lobhapakatitāya.meaning_2: on account of the natural state of greed; because of the nature of greed; due to greed's nature
lobhapakatitāya.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `lobhapakatitāya` functions as an adverbial phrase. It is formed by combining `lobha` (greed) with `pakati` (natural state/condition) to create the compound noun `lobhapakati` (greed's nature or natural state of greed). The instrumental singular suffix `-tāya` is then added to this feminine compound noun, giving the meaning 'on account of' or 'because of' this state.

gāmikamanussaṃ.meaning_2: villager; rustic man; person from the village
gāmikamanussaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `gāmikamanussaṃ` is the accusative singular form of the masculine compound noun `gāmikamanussa`. It is formed by combining `gāmika` (meaning 'villager' or 'rustic') and `manussa` (meaning 'human being', 'man', or 'person'), thus referring to a 'villager' or 'man from the village'.

lolabālaṃ.meaning_2: restless child; agitated fool; eager person; longing fool
lolabālaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `lolabālaṃ` is an accusative singular form of a compound noun. It combines `lola` (restless, agitated, eager, longing) and `bāla` (child, fool, immature person). Therefore, it refers to a person who is a 'restless child', 'agitated fool', 'eager person', or 'longing fool'. Without a sentence context, multiple interpretations of the component meanings are possible.

agghāpanikakammaṃ.meaning_2: act of appraisal; procedure of evaluation; formal valuation; appraiser's legal act
agghāpanikakammaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `agghāpanikakammaṃ` is a nominal compound. It is formed by `agghāpanika` (evaluator, appraiser) and `kamma` (action, legal act). The ending `ṃ` indicates it is in the accusative singular case (or potentially nominative singular neuter). Given the meaning of `agghāpanika`, `kamma 5` (legal act; legal procedure; formal action) is the most contextually relevant meaning for `kamma` in this compound, suggesting an official act or procedure of appraisal.

dhanarakkhaṇatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of protecting wealth; for the sake of guarding riches
dhanarakkhaṇatthāya.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a compound noun, formed by `dhana` (wealth, riches), `rakkhaṇa` (protection, guarding), and `atthāya` (for the purpose of, for the sake of). The dative singular ending `āyā` on `attha` indicates the purpose or benefit, translating to "for the purpose of protecting wealth".

agghāpanikakamme.meaning_2: in the appraiser's act; in the formal act of appraisal; in the valuation procedure
agghāpanikakamme.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a compound word formed from `agghāpanika` (appraiser, evaluator) and `kamma` (act, deed). The `e` ending indicates the locative singular case. Therefore, the compound means 'in the appraiser's act' or 'in the formal act of appraisal'. The dictionary entry for `kamma 5` is particularly relevant, suggesting a 'legal act' or 'formal action' often found in the Vinaya context, aligning with the role of an 'appraiser'.

yathāruciyā.meaning_2: according to one's preference; according to one's liking; as one pleases; at will
yathāruciyā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word yathāruciyā is an adverbial compound formed from the indeclinable yathā (meaning 'according to', 'as per') and the instrumental singular of the feminine noun ruci (meaning 'preference', 'liking'). The entire phrase means 'according to one's preference' or 'as one pleases'.

uttarāpathato.meaning_2: from the northern road; from the northern path
uttarāpathato.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word uttarāpathato is an adverbial ablative formed by adding the suffix -to to the compound noun uttarāpatha. The compound uttarāpatha is composed of uttarā (north; northern direction, fem) and patha (path; road; way, masc), thus meaning 'northern path' or 'northern road'. The suffix -to indicates movement or origin 'from' that place.

taṇḍulanāḷikaṃ.meaning_2: a measure of dehusked rice; a rice measure
taṇḍulanāḷikaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word taṇḍulanāḷikaṃ is the accusative singular form of the feminine compound noun taṇḍulanāḷikā. It is formed by combining taṇḍula (dehusked rice) and nāḷikā (a measure of rice), hence meaning 'a measure of dehusked rice'. The use of nāḷikā (fem) as the final component determines the feminine gender of the compound.

agghamakāsi.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a sandhi compound of 'aggha' (neuter noun meaning 'offering') and 'akāsi' (aorist of the verb 'karoti' meaning 'made' or 'performed'). Therefore, the combined meaning is 'made an offering'.

porāṇaagghāpanikassa.grammar: masc, comp, gen sg; masc, comp, dat sg
porāṇaagghāpanikassa.meaning_2: ancient evaluator; old appraiser; former valuator
porāṇaagghāpanikassa.pattern: a masc gen sg; a masc dat sg
porāṇaagghāpanikassa.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a compound of the adjective porāṇa ("ancient; old") and the masculine noun agghāpanika ("evaluator; appraiser"). The ending -assa indicates the genitive or dative singular case. Therefore, it refers to "of the ancient evaluator" or "to the ancient evaluator".

ñātametaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a sandhi compound of the past participle 'ñāta' (known) and the neuter singular pronoun 'etaṃ' (this). The compound form creates the meaning 'this is known' or 'this known thing'.

taṇḍulanāḷiyā.5_meaning_2: a measure of dehusked rice; a nāḷi of rice
taṇḍulanāḷiyā.14_comment: The word `taṇḍulanāḷiyā` is an inflected feminine nominal compound. It is composed of `taṇḍula` (dehusked rice) and `nāḷi` (a measure of volume). The ending `iyā` typically indicates the instrumental singular or genitive/dative singular case for feminine nouns ending in `i`.

jānitukāmamhā.meaning_2: we are wishing to know; we are desirous of knowing
jānitukāmamhā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `jānitukāmamhā` is a sandhi compound. It consists of `jānitukāma` and `amhā`. `jānitukāma` is an adjective meaning 'wishing to know' or 'desirous of knowing', formed from the infinitive `jānituṃ` ('to know') and the adjective `kāma` ('wishing, wanting'). `amhā` is the 1st person plural present tense of the verb 'to be' (√as), meaning 'we are'. Thus, the compound translates to 'we are wishing to know' or 'we are desirous of knowing'. The `m` is an epenthetic consonant inserted in sandhi.

taṇḍulanāḷikā.meaning_2: measure of dehusked rice; rice measure
taṇḍulanāḷikā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `taṇḍulanāḷikā` is a compound noun formed by combining `taṇḍula` (dehusked rice) and `nāḷikā` (a measure, specifically of rice). The compound refers to a 'measure of dehusked rice' or simply a 'rice measure', often a specific quantity used in Pāḷi texts.

taṇḍulanāḷiṃ.meaning_2: a measure of dehusked rice; a nāḷi of rice
taṇḍulanāḷiṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `taṇḍulanāḷiṃ` is the accusative singular form of the feminine compound noun `taṇḍulanāḷi`. It combines `taṇḍula` (dehusked rice) and `nāḷi` (a measure of volume). The compound takes the gender of its final component, `nāḷi`, which is feminine. The `ṃ` ending indicates the accusative singular case.

agghāpetunti.meaning_2: to cause to be worth; to appraise; to value; to estimate
agghāpetunti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word 'agghāpetunti' is the 3rd person plural present tense form of the causative verb 'agghāpeti'. It is derived from the root '√aggh', which in its base form 'agghati' means 'to be worth' or 'to deserve'. The causative suffix '-āpe-' transforms the meaning to 'to cause to be worth', 'to make valuable', 'to appraise', or 'to estimate the value of'. The '-unti' ending indicates the 3rd person plural subject.

agghanakabhāvaṃ.meaning_2: state of having value; condition of being worth; worthiness
agghanakabhāvaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `agghanakabhāvaṃ` is the accusative singular of the masculine compound noun `agghanakabhāva`. It is formed by combining `agghanaka` (worth, valuable) and `bhāva` (state, condition) to denote "the state or condition of being valuable" or "worthiness".

taṇḍulanāḷi.meaning_2: a nāḷi of dehusked rice; a measure of rice
taṇḍulanāḷi.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a compound formed from 'taṇḍula' (dehusked rice) and 'nāḷi' (measure of volume). The compound takes the feminine gender of its final component, nāḷi.

bālapuriso.meaning_2: foolish man; ignorant man; stupid person; immature person
bālapuriso.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word "bālapuriso" is a compound noun formed from "bāla" and "purisa". "Bāla" can mean foolish, ignorant, stupid, or immature, and "purisa" means man or person. Therefore, the compound generally refers to a foolish, ignorant, stupid, or immature man/person. In Pāḷi literature, "bāla" often implies a lack of wisdom or spiritual understanding, contrasting with a "paṇḍita" (wise person), rather than simply referring to young age, although that is also a possible nuance.

taṇḍulanāḷikāya.grammar: fem, comp, instr sg; dat sg; gen sg
taṇḍulanāḷikāya.meaning_2: by a measure of dehusked rice; to a measure of dehusked rice; of a measure of dehusked rice
taṇḍulanāḷikāya.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `taṇḍulanāḷikāya` is a compound of `taṇḍula` (dehusked rice) and `nāḷikā` (a measure, especially for rice). The form `taṇḍulanāḷikāya` is the instrumental singular, dative singular, or genitive singular of this feminine compound noun. The meaning chosen combines 'dehusked rice' from `taṇḍula` with 'measure of rice' from `nāḷikā 1`.

pākāraparikkhepo.meaning_2: enclosure of an encircling wall; rampart enclosure; circumference of a wall
pākāraparikkhepo.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a nominal compound, likely a Tatpuruṣa, combining `pākāra` (encircling wall, rampart) and `parikkhepa` (enclosure, boundary, circumference). The compound therefore refers to the protective perimeter or the entire system of an encircling wall and its enclosure.

dvādasayojaniko.5. meaning_2: twelve yojanas in length; approximately 240 kilometres long
dvādasayojaniko.14. comment: This is a tatpurisa compound indicating length. 'dvādasa' means twelve, and 'yojanika' is an adjective derived from 'yojana', meaning 'approximately twenty kilometres in length'. Therefore, 'dvādasayojaniko' describes something that is twelve times twenty kilometres long, or approximately 240 kilometres in length. The '-o' ending marks it as masculine nominative singular, suggesting it modifies a masculine noun.

sarājakaṃ.meaning_2: with a king; having a king; royal; accompanied by a king; under a king; royally; monarchically
sarājakaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `sarājakaṃ` is a compound formed by the prefix `sa-` (meaning "with" or "having") and the adjective `rājaka` (meaning "royal" or "regarding the ruler"). The suffix `-aṃ` indicates that this form can function as either a neuter nominative or accusative singular adjective, or as an adverb meaning "royally" or "with a king".

bārāṇasirajjaṃ.meaning_2: Bārāṇasī's kingship; rulership of Bārāṇasī; sovereignty of Varanasi; dominion over Varanasi; power in Varanasi
bārāṇasirajjaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a sandhi compound formed by combining the feminine noun 'bārāṇasī' (Varanasi) and the neuter noun 'rajja' (kingship, rulership). The final 'ṃ' indicates that the compound is in the accusative singular neuter form. The meaning refers to the royal power or dominion associated with the city of Bārāṇasī.

taṇḍulanāḷimattaṃ.meaning_2: a measure of dehusked rice; only a measure of dehusked rice
taṇḍulanāḷimattaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a compound word derived from 'taṇḍula' (dehusked rice), 'nāḷi' (a measure of volume), and 'matta' (a suffix indicating 'only' or 'as much as'). The overall meaning refers to a quantity of rice that is approximately one nāḷi. The final 'ṃ' in the provided word 'taṇḍulanāḷimattaṃ' suggests its usage as a neuter nominative/accusative singular adjective or adverb in context.

ñāṇasampadā.meaning_2: attainment of insight; achievement of understanding; blessing of knowledge; endowment with knowledge
ñāṇasampadā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a compound of `ñāṇa` (knowing, understanding, insight) and `sampadā` (attainment, accomplishment, blessing, endowment). Therefore, `ñāṇasampadā` refers to the attainment or endowment of insight and knowledge.

taṇḍulanāḷikāyaṃ.meaning_2: in a measure of dehusked rice
taṇḍulanāḷikāyaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a locative singular of a feminine compound noun. It combines 'dehusked rice' (taṇḍula) and 'measure of rice' (nāḷikā) to form 'rice-measure', which is then inflected to 'in a rice-measure'.

ayamagghati.meaning_2: this is worth; this has the value (of); this deserves; this person is worth; this thing is worth
ayamagghati.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word 'ayamagghati' is a sandhi compound of the pronoun 'ayaṃ' (this, this person/thing) and the present tense verb 'agghati' (is worth, deserves). The final 'ṃ' (anusvāra) of 'ayaṃ' assimilates to 'm' before the initial vowel 'a' of 'agghati', forming 'ayamagghati'. Since no specific context is provided, the meaning combines the possible senses of both components.

nikkaḍḍhāpetvā.meaning_2: having caused to pull out; having expelled; having caused to drag forth
nikkaḍḍhāpetvā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `nikkaḍḍhāpetvā` is an absolutive (gerund) form. It is derived from the causative verb `nikkaḍḍhāpeti` (to cause to pull out, to expel), which itself is formed by adding the prefix `ni-` to the root `√kaḍḍh` (to pull, drag) and then applying the causative suffix `-āpe`.

agghāpanikaṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: the appraiser's place; place of valuation; valuation office
agghāpanikaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a compound of `agghāpanika` (appraiser, valuator) and `ṭhāna` (place). The `ṃ` ending signifies the accusative singular case of this neuter compound noun. The gemination of `ṭh` to `ṭṭh` is a common phonetic change observed in Pāḷi compounds.

gāmikabālaagghāpaniko.meaning_2: rustic foolish evaluator; rustic foolish appraiser
gāmikabālaagghāpaniko.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a Tatpuruṣa compound noun. `gāmika` (from gāma) is used here as an adjective meaning 'rustic' or 'belonging to a village', and `bāla` is used as an adjective meaning 'foolish' or 'ignorant'. These two adjectives collectively describe the head noun `agghāpanika`, meaning 'evaluator' or 'appraiser'. Thus, the compound refers to an evaluator who possesses the qualities of being both rustic and foolish.

lāludāyī.meaning_2: giver of desired things; one who fulfills wishes; benevolent giver
lāludāyī.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a compound formed from 'lālu' (meaning desirous, longing, or greedy) and 'dāyin' (meaning giver, from the root √dā, to give). It denotes a person who gives things that are desired or longed for by others, thus implying someone who is generous or fulfills wishes.

paṇḍitaagghāpaniko.meaning_2: wise evaluator; intelligent appraiser; learned valuator
paṇḍitaagghāpaniko.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a Tatpuruṣa compound, where paṇḍita (wise, intelligent) qualifies agghāpanika (evaluator, appraiser). It describes an evaluator who possesses wisdom or intelligence. The first component paṇḍita acts adjectivally to describe the second component agghāpanika.

devadhammajātakavaṇṇanā.meaning_2: Commentary on the Devadhamma Jātaka; Explanation of Jātaka 6
devadhammajātakavaṇṇanā.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a compound of `devadhammajātaka` (Jātaka 6) and `vaṇṇanā` (commentary), thus meaning 'Commentary on Jātaka 6'. The feminine gender and declension pattern are determined by the final element `vaṇṇanā`.

bahubhaṇḍikaṃ.meaning_2: having much baggage; having many bundles; much property; burdened with much goods
bahubhaṇḍikaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word 'bahubhaṇḍikaṃ' is a compound formed from 'bahu' (many, much) and 'bhaṇḍa' (goods, property, baggage), to which the taddhita suffix '-ika' is appended, forming an adjective 'bhaṇḍika' meaning 'having goods/baggage'. The complete compound 'bahubhaṇḍika' therefore means 'having much baggage' or 'burdened with much goods'. The ending '-ṃ' in the provided word 'bahubhaṇḍikaṃ' indicates an accusative singular neuter form, or an adverbial usage of this adjective.

kireko.meaning_2: it is said one; allegedly one; apparently one; one, it is said
kireko.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word 'kireko' is a sandhi compound formed from 'kira' (an indeclinable meaning 'it is said', 'allegedly', or 'truly') and 'eko' (the masculine nominative singular form of 'eka', meaning 'one', 'a', or 'a certain'). The sandhi rule 'a + e > e' applies here. Without a sentence context, the exact nuance of 'kira' (whether 'allegedly' or 'truly') cannot be definitively chosen, so both possibilities from the dictionary entries are considered in the meaning.

bhaṇḍagabbhañca.meaning_2: and the store-room for goods; and the treasury
bhaṇḍagabbhañca.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word bhaṇḍagabbhañca is a sandhi compound formed from bhaṇḍagabbhaṃ (the accusative singular of the compound noun bhaṇḍagabbha) and the indeclinable conjunction ca ('and'). The final nasal 'ṃ' of bhaṇḍagabbhaṃ undergoes sandhi with the initial palatal consonant 'c' of ca, transforming into 'ñ'. bhaṇḍagabbha is composed of bhaṇḍa ('goods') and gabbha ('room'), thus meaning 'store-room for goods' or 'treasury'. The full word therefore translates to 'and the store-room for goods' or 'and the treasury'.

bhaṇḍagabbhaṃ.meaning_2: store-room for goods; treasury; inner chamber for wares
bhaṇḍagabbhaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a tatpurisa compound formed from `bhaṇḍa` (goods, wares, from lemma_1: bhaṇḍa 1, nt) and `gabbha` (room, inner chamber, from lemma_1: gabbha 3, masc). The compound functions as a masculine noun, and the ending `ṃ` in `bhaṇḍagabbhaṃ` indicates its form as accusative singular. It literally means 'room for goods' or 'goods room', thus referring to a store-room or treasury.

sappitaṇḍulādīhi.grammar: sandhi, nt + masc + masc, instr pl
sappitaṇḍulādīhi.meaning_2: with ghee and dehusked rice, etc.; with ghee, dehusked rice and so on
sappitaṇḍulādīhi.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a sandhi compound formed by 'sappi' (ghee, neuter), 'taṇḍula' (dehusked rice, masculine or neuter), and 'ādi' (meaning 'etc.', masculine or neuter). The resulting compound 'sappitaṇḍulādi' is then inflected in the instrumental plural, yielding 'sappitaṇḍulādīhi'. The 'ī' in 'ādīhi' represents the lengthening of the 'i' from 'ādi' before the instrumental plural ending 'hi'.

vihārapaccante.meaning_2: in the remote district of the monastery; on the borderland of the monastery
vihārapaccante.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `vihārapaccante` is a Tatpuruṣa compound of `vihāra` (monastery) and `paccanta` (borderland, remote district). The form `vihārapaccante` is the locative singular, indicating location "at/in the remote district of the monastery".

tassekadivasaṃ.meaning_2: on that one day; one day regarding that
tassekadivasaṃ.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a sandhi compound formed by joining `tassa` (an indeclinable adverb meaning 'therefore, regarding that') and `ekadivasaṃ` (an indeclinable adverb meaning 'one day'). The sandhi rule `a + e > e` has been applied. The compound functions as an adverbial phrase, specifying a particular day in relation to a previously mentioned context.

cīvarapaccattharaṇādīni.meaning_2: robes, covers, etc.; robes and spreads and so on
cīvarapaccattharaṇādīni.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a Dvandva (copulative) compound ending with `ādi`, which signifies 'etc.' or 'and so on'. The form `ādīni` is the neuter nominative or accusative plural, indicating multiple items in a list. The compound specifically refers to robes (`cīvara`) and covers/spreads (`paccattharaṇa`) and other similar items.

cīvarādīni.meaning_2: robes, etc.; robes and so on
cīvarādīni.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word 'cīvarādīni' is a compound formed from 'cīvara' (robe, cloth) and 'ādi' (etc., and so on). The suffix '-ādīni' indicates a nominative/accusative plural neuter form, meaning 'robes and other things of that kind' or 'robes, etc.'. This aligns with 'ādi 3' in the dictionary entries, which specifies 'nt, in comps' with the meaning 'etc.'.

kassimānīti.meaning_2: dragged, imagining thus; dragged, thinking thus; dragged, proud thus
kassimānīti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word kassimānīti is a sandhi compound formed from kassi (aorist of kassati, meaning 'dragged'), mānī (an adjective from maññati, meaning 'imagining, thinking, or proud'), and iti (an indeclinable meaning 'thus'). Without a contextual sentence, multiple interpretations for mānī are provided.

tuyhamevāti.meaning_2: it is indeed yours, thus; only yours, thus; your very own, thus
tuyhamevāti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `tuyhamevāti` is a sandhi compound formed by the pronoun `tuyhaṃ` (your/yours/for you), the emphatic particle `eva` (indeed/only), and the quotative particle `iti` (thus). The anusvāra `ṃ` of `tuyhaṃ` becomes `m` before the vowel `e` of `eva`. The final `a` of `eva` then lengthens before `iti`, resulting in `evāti`. The overall meaning combines these elements, suggesting 'indeed your/yours, thus' or 'only your/yours, this is (it)'.

mayhamevāti.meaning_2: mine indeed, thus; only to me, this is; for me alone, it is said
mayhamevāti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `mayhamevāti` is a sandhi compound formed from three components: `mayhaṃ` (pronoun), `eva` (indeclinable particle), and `iti` (indeclinable particle). The sandhi occurs in two stages: first, `mayhaṃ` + `eva` becomes `mayhameva` (the anusvāra `ṃ` becomes `m` before the vowel `e`); second, `mayhameva` + `iti` becomes `mayhamevāti` (the final `a` of `eva` coalesces with the initial `i` of `iti` to form `āti`). `mayhaṃ` can mean 'to me' or 'my/mine', `eva` functions as an emphasizing particle ('only', 'just', 'indeed'), and `iti` marks reported speech or conclusion ('thus', 'this is'). Without contextual sentences, multiple interpretations are possible.

anicchamānakaṃyeva.meaning_2: even while not desiring; just by not wishing; merely by being unwilling
anicchamānakaṃyeva.construction: (na > an + iccha + māna + ka + ṃ) + eva
anicchamānakaṃyeva.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This word is a sandhi compound of `anicchamānakaṃ` and `eva`. `anicchamānakaṃ` is derived from the negative prefix `an-` (from `na`), the verbal root `√is` (to wish/desire, appearing as `iccha`), the present participle suffix `-māna`, the nominalizing/adjectival suffix `-ka`, and the adverbial ending `-ṃ`. `eva` is an emphatic indeclinable particle. The `y` is an epenthetic consonant for euphony in sandhi. The entire phrase functions adverbially, emphasizing the state of not desiring or being unwilling.

upatthambhayamāno.grammar: prp of upatthambheti, masc, nom, sg
upatthambhayamāno.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is a present participle, masculine, nominative singular, derived from the causative verb `upatthambheti` (to cause to support, to strengthen, to uphold). It describes someone who is actively supporting, propping up, or maintaining something.

hirottappagavesako.meaning_2: who seeks for conscience and concern; who seeks for respect for oneself and others
hirottappagavesako.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a compound of 'hirottappa' and 'gavesaka'. 'Hirottappa' itself is a compound formed from 'hiri' (shame/conscience) and 'ottappa' (remorse/concern). 'Gavesaka' means 'one who seeks or looks for'. Thus, the compound means 'one who seeks for conscience and concern' or 'one who seeks for respect for oneself and others'.

dakarakkhasakālepi.meaning_2: even at the time of the water-sprite; also during the water-sprite's time
dakarakkhasakālepi.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word 'dakarakkhasakālepi' is a sandhi compound composed of three parts: 'dakarakkhasa', 'kāle', and 'api'. 'Dakarakkhasa' means 'water-sprite'. 'Kāle' is the locative singular form of 'kāla', meaning 'at the time' or 'during the occasion'. 'Api' is an indeclinable particle meaning 'even' or 'also'. Therefore, the entire compound translates to 'even at the time of the water-sprite' or 'also during the water-sprite's time'.

ṭhitosīti.meaning_2: you are thus stood; you are thus situated; you are thus remaining
ṭhitosīti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word ṭhitosīti is a sandhi compound. It breaks down into ṭhito (a form of the past participle ṭhita), asi (the second person singular present tense verb 'you are'), and iti (an indeclinable meaning 'thus'). The `asīti` part is explicitly given as a sandhi compound of `asi + iti` in the dictionary entries. The `o` in `ṭhito` becomes `o` before `a` in `asi` via sandhi rules.

nāmaggahaṇadivase.5_meaning_2: on the day of christening; on the day of naming
nāmaggahaṇadivase.14_comment: The word is a sandhi compound of 'nāmaggahaṇa' (neuter, meaning 'christening' or 'taking a name') and 'divasa' (masculine, meaning 'day'). The form 'nāmaggahaṇadivase' is the locative singular, indicating 'on the day of christening' or 'on the day of naming'.

mahisāsakumāroti.meaning_2: Thus, the prince with great asthma; This is the prince with great asthma.
mahisāsakumāroti.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `mahisāsakumāroti` is a sandhi compound of `mahisāsakumāro` and the indeclinable `iti`. The first part, `mahisāsakumāro`, is a masculine nominative singular compound noun. It appears to be composed of `mahī` (from `mahī 3` meaning 'greatness; excellence'), `sāsa` (meaning 'asthma; breathing' from the provided dictionary entry), and `kumāra` (meaning 'youngster; prince'). Interpreting `mahī` as an intensifying adjective modifying `sāsa`, `mahisāsa` could mean 'great asthma'. Thus, `mahisāsakumāra` could mean 'a prince with great asthma' (a Bahubbihi compound, 'one who has great asthma'). The `iti` concludes the phrase, indicating 'thus' or 'this is'.

aggamahesiṭṭhāne.meaning_2: in the position of the first queen; at the station of the chief consort; in the role of the principal queen
aggamahesiṭṭhāne.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `aggamahesiṭṭhāne` is a compound noun in the locative singular. It is formed from `aggamahesī` (first queen, derived from `agga` + `mahesī`, where `mahesī` is `mahā` + `īsī`) and `ṭhāna` (place, position, role). The doubling of `ṭh` to `ṭṭh` is a result of sandhi between the preceding long vowel `ī` of `aggamahesī` and the initial `ṭh` of `ṭhāna`. The meaning is 'in the position/place/role of the first queen'.

sūriyakumārotissa.meaning_2: Sūriyakumāra and Tissa; Sūriyakumāra, also known as Tissa
sūriyakumārotissa.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word 'sūriyakumārotissa' is a sandhi compound formed by the proper names 'Sūriyakumāra' and 'Tissa'. 'Sūriyakumāra' is itself a compound meaning 'prince sun' and refers to a prince or a previous incarnation of Ānanda. 'Tissa' is a common Pāḷi name for monks, deities, or Buddhas. The 'o' vowel serves as a linking sandhi between the two names, a common phenomenon in Pāḷi for proper nouns in compounds. Without sentence context, the compound could denote 'Sūriyakumāra and Tissa' (referring to two distinct individuals) or 'Sūriyakumāra, who is also Tissa' (identifying one person by two names or titles).

icchitakāle.meaning_2: at the desired time; at the preferred time; at the appropriate time as wished for
icchitakāle.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word is a sandhi compound of 'icchita' (past participle meaning 'wished for' or 'desired') and 'kāle' (locative singular of 'kāla', functioning adverbially, meaning 'at time' or 'at the right time'). Therefore, it signifies 'at the desired time' or 'at the preferred time'.

jātakāle.meaning_2: at the time of birth; when born; at the time of occurrence; at the time it happened
jātakāle.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] This is an adverbial compound formed from the past participle `jāta` ('born; arisen; happened') and the adverbial form `kāle` (locative singular of `kāla`, meaning 'at the time'). The compound thus means 'at the time of being born/arising/happening'.

paduminipaṇṇehi.meaning_2: leaves of a lotus pond; lotus leaves; with lotus leaves; by means of lotus leaves
paduminipaṇṇehi.comment: [gemini: gemini-2.5-flash] The word `paduminipaṇṇehi` is an instrumental plural form of the compound noun `paduminipaṇṇa`.
